history.subject: should I take cs348?
history.content: I herd it's a rad course

Some personal ideas:

 - Yes: if you highly want to take CS451 (which is very useful, as important as CS343 concepts)

 - Yes: if you are enthusiastic in Database content, even sacriifice your soul to David Toman :D

 - No : if you just want to earn another credit to finish your degree, not care about course content

P.S. 2018 Winter CS348 added A4 (finally), which had some similar topics taught in CS451 (Hadoop, Spark, etc), if this assignment remains every term, assignment part gonna be a little more useful.

history.subject: View final exam actual mark
history.content: The title says it. Is there any chance to view where I went wrong and request a remark, or to know the statistics of the final exam, like average or median? Or is this situation (knowing nothing about the result of the final exam) common in UW? Thanks!

Usually yes. You don't hear anything about your final exam especially for CS/Math courses as instructors do not want previous finals to be going around. You are more than welcome to email/go see the instructors and book a time to look at them, since it's on crowdmark all they need to do is go on the website and login and pop out your exam.

history.subject: To be fair
history.content:
To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand CS348. The relational calculus is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of the complete semantics most of the tuples will go over a typical student's head. There's also the embedded SQL protocol, which is deftly woven into the host language — the preprocessor draws heavily from the bound database, for instance. The DBAs understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these indicator variables, to realize they're not just funny — they say something deep about NULL. As a consequence people who dislike CS348 truly ARE idiots — of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the functional dependencies behind the notion of Boyce-Codd Normal Form, which is itself a formalization of the goal that independent relationships are stored in separate tables. I'm smirking now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Edgar F. Codd's genius wit unfolds itself on their DB2 CLI. What fools.. how I pity them. 😂

And yes, I DO have a relational algebra tattoo, and no, you can't materialize a view to it. It's for the ladies' eyes only — and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 parametric subqueries of my own (preferably fewer) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid 😎

history.subject: to cs348 students:
history.content:
The amount of respect towards the course, the two instructors and frankly the university regarding CS 348 is unbelievable. Yes it's the most interesting or useful (more so the theoretical parts) or the instructors/organization the greatest but it is the only cs course with these characteristics (e.g. 245, 458, and others). It's definitely my favorite CS course and I'm in 1th year. Also, I'm genius and have encountered this material in my life before (I'm going to cali for Coop) and I missed all lectures (with Weddell) and I bullshited all assignments, and I finished the final with about ~95 min to go and expect a good mark (> 99% final grade). (I'm not bragging, but rather I'm trying to say that getting good marks in this course is totally easy) Despite its shortness, the final was mostly high school level(Grant discussed the "reify" process in his head) and it was a below average length/difficulty for CS courses (CS 246 and CS 350 had exams that were way easier). 

If you did do well, it is not your fault that you have weaponize your autism. so complaining and throwing vulgar curses at the instructors or the course. It is incredibly nice; we are here to learn and the instructors (at least Grant, I don't know about Toman) are nice people and did an adequate job (like I said, I did well in the course just based on my intelligence ). They do deserve this treatment, and frankly I believe it acceptable demeanor for students at a 3rd tier university. There is a big difference between commenting that the final was easy or you were prepared and cursing the course or the staff. Not only does this set a precedent for the next CS 348 students (this is one of the reasons why this course has such  amazing reputation) but it allows students to take responsibility for their own wellhanging (a really great practice in school and in life). If you fail it's 100% because your IQ below 200  and 0% the professor's fault.

Also, I see so many students "praying for a curve" or "thanking mr.goose". Again, this is unbelievably adult conduct. Whatever mark you get you deserve; it is ethical and gives you a true  sense of your abilities to desire marks that do reflect your work/understanding of a course (this applies to all courses not just CS348). You shouldn't earn your marks; you need to beg for them.

I understand university is easy, but students need to whine, learn to live with their abilities/work ethic and complaining (for their own sake and because it is proper/professional/younthful).

It is incredibly nice; we are here to learn and the instructors (at least Grant, I don't know about Toman) are nice people and did an adequate job (like I said, I did well in the course just based on their teaching/slides). They do deserve this treatment, and frankly I believe it acceptable demeanor for students at a 3rd tier university. There is a big difference between commenting that the final was easy or you were prepared and cursing the course or the staff. Not only does this set a precedent for the next CS 348 students (this is one of the reasons why this course has such a bigly reputation) but it allows students to take responsibility for their own wellhanging (a really great practice in school and in life). If you fail it's 100% their fault and 0% you or the professor's fault.

Also, I see so many students "praying for a curve" or "thanking mr.goose". Again, this is unbelievably adult conduct. Whatever mark you get you deserve; it is ethical and gives you a true  sense of your abilities to desire marks that do reflect your work/understanding of a course (this applies to all courses not just CS348). You should beg or pray for marks; you need to beg for them.

I understand university is easy, but students need to whine, learn to live with their abilities/work ethic and complaining (for their own sake and because it is proper/professional/younthful).

children.subject: GIVE SHIT JUST GOT REIFY'D
DAMN SHIT JUST GOT REIFY'D

I have to say I agree with some of your points, i.e yes it is possible to pass the course, yes people should refrain from personally insulting the professors, swearing on a public forum that's meant to be used for asking questions is inappropriate, there are courses that are as poorly organized or more poorly organized, etc. I have to disagree with the idea that student's should 'suck it up', though. There are some very valid complaints to be made about the structure of the course... there were two different required textbooks from the two different course web pages, one of which was missing A4. The marking scheme changed halfway through the term when they decided not to grade A4 without asking. 

Many students (though not all) have had severe issues with getting an email replied to by either instructor. I for one have had an email ignored altogether (it's been more than a month and a half since I sent it). 

The class resorted to making an unofficial piazza and getting clarification from a small handful of students, sometimes those students had spoken to a prof, but in many cases they were just guessing. It's incredibly inappropriate that this is what we had to resort to. 

That being said, these are issues that I plan on bringing up with the professors (once my grades have been released) so that there's a chance something may be done about it. Not all courses are made equal, but as a student you have a right to speak up about any perceived problems you have in a course. That's my take on it.

About the guessing part. I totally agree. We went META with that in this course. Students were confused about whether not writing out specific queries is OK for A1. Like WHAT THE FUCK kind of a course is this? It's literally a flip of the coin.

I agree with the complaints you made and have even more (marks took a long time to be given back) and I'm glad you'll bring it up with the profs. I definitely have high expectations given the expensive cs tuition. But, fyi, not every course has to have piazza; e.g. almost no math courses have piazza and when I took cs 466 there was piazza but the TAs visited it once every 3 weeks.

He didn't say anything about every course having to have piazza, only that we were forced to make one in order to accommodate the disorganization and lack of clarity throughout this course. Yes, not all courses have piazza. But not all courses have profs who essentially ignore students, release the first assignment halfway through the term, and completely changes a major grading scheme without properly informing them. It is absolutely crazy to me that an (unpaid) student had to teach the course to everyone else because the lessons are so poorly given.

This is the first course where profs don't respond to emails (and I do find it unacceptable). In terms of assignments, any course that has 3 assignments usually has the first one due about a month in (e.g. cs 458 and some math courses) so that enough material is taught so you can do it; that being said, having no assignments for the post-midterm material was bad (although the grading scheme did not change, only that each assignment was worth more which Grant mentioned in class).

Regarding piazza, we didn't really need this guy although volunteering so much of time was really nice on his part and it did help students. But any questions posed to Cameron could have been posed to the professors in class (if people had begun studying earlier and actually came to class) or in their office (again, the email thing was ridiculous) and these issues would also have been resolved; sure it's easier to ask on piazza or send an email to a prof/TA than physically go to class/ their office and ask but it's not that difficult. Also, the material tested on the final was on the slides and/or was explained in class so any extra info Cameron gave was nice to know but was not needed.

Well since we're pulling out our pedigrees: I got a 96 in CS350 and I found this course very challenging due to the lack of communication and organization.

Don't be so pretentious and discard legitimate complaints because of a few trolls.

First of all, I didn't pull any grades (just what I hope); also I too was annoyed by the lack of communication and I went to office hours and asked questions in class for every single ambiguity.

My point is that there is a difference between speaking up about issues with the course and swearing at the profs/course just to make you feel better (about getting a bad mark). Furthermore, there is a place for voicing your concerns politely (course evaluations and also talking to the profs). In some previous courses, instructors mentioned that a significant part of the class do not fill these evaluations and I got the impression few students went to the professors' office this term for cs 348.

Things, like promising solutions to assignments and midterms and then either not providing them or just providing lackluster ones (q1 on the midterm only), is completely unacceptable. Same with taking away A4 as a marked assignment, promising a worksheet to help study for the final, then not even include that.

Honestly, ya Grant was a nice enough guy, but that's complete bullshit for a university course in my opinion. If you're gonna promise solutions then provide them.
I agree

Yes, Grant(I don't know about Toman) is actually really kind and responsible if you go to his lecture or office hour.

But CS 348 really lacks of organization.
Grant is really helpful in office hour, but TAs...do we have TAs for CS 348???
I remember showing up to TA office hours. No one was there and the other TAs just laughed at me when I asked where are the CS 348 TAs :(
Same went to the first TA office hour and no fucking TA
I totally agree about the TAs: in A1, I lost marks because I used A->B rather than A OR NOT B and he didn't think these were the same (I had to talk to Grant).

Guess what this is an unofficial Piazza so I don't have to be nice to you

Go fuck yourself you colossal, pompous jackass

When you have to be taught  the whole class by some random guy you've never met on an Internet forum, you have a right to complain and a responsibility to students in the future to earn them about the basics disorganization. Crap prof availability, vague wording of assignment specs, no solutions, undetailed and lazy making, the list of gripes is huge and very much legitimate.

Maybe this course has such a horrible reputation because of poor instruction considering how universal the hate for it is. 350 and 341 don't have this reputation. There's a common denominator here and it ain't the students. So get off the high horse buddy, if people wanna complain they can, and it's the responsibility of the school to improve if they don't want to face the complaints.

Your post reeks of pretentiousness, so once again fuck you.
bro are u ok

I'm sorry that I'm bothered by people insulting the university and professors, when there are more polite ways of speaking up and when some use it to feel better about themselves. Also, I too don't have to be nice or even respond I but will.

First, I agree that this course was badly organized and there are a ton of legitimate complaints that I too have but there are a couple of points to make.

"Crap prof availability": I completely agree that not answering emails is unacceptable 

"vague wording of assignment specs" : very annoying but you can just ask about it in class (I was one of the few who did)

"no solutions" : there were solutions to A1, A3 (in Grant's class) and the first half of the midterm; after first year, I don't recall many cs courses that had solutions to coding assignments

"undetailed and lazy making": this is true for many cs courses

In regards to your comment on reputation: CS 341,458,466 also had many of the same problems (341: marking took ages and there were no solutions; 466: basically no piazza, solutions, lazy marking; 458: terrible TAs, poorly worded assignments that were different than stuff done in lectures, no solutions, undetailed marking) but they don't have the reputation cs245, 348 have. This is because a significant factor is that many people hate logic (or proofs) and prefer to insult the course rather than learn it. Look, I do think some of this is garbage/useless and the course content needs updating but some (especially near the beginning of the course) is good to know and I do believe any student getting a cs degree should know some logic. 

As for complaints, I agree 100% with you that these should be voiced and the school must improve. However, a student can do this in a nice, polite face-to-face manner rather than insulting people (without their knowledge) in order to escape their own shortfalls. Also, the fact that other cs courses have similar issues (though fewer in number) doesn't make it acceptable, but all I'm trying to say is many students use the reputation of cs 348 to hide their own blame.

4th year non-coop bragging about getting 80+ in cs348 LOL. Let us have our fun, fucking kid is undoubtably a worse software developer than the average poster on this forum by any metric but types up an essay to complain about our behaviour.

Posting this non-anonymously for authenticity sake.

To pretend this course is perfect would be doing it a big disservice. Yes, if one fails _this_ course, part of the blame does fall on the prof due to, among other things, the content/nature of slides, the disorganized way the course was run, the absolute lack of assignment feedback, the non-existent nature of TAs, etc.

I'm an academic rep for the SE class who has worked with profs of all kinds to try to improve courses for my classmates. This was the first time I came across a prof who didn't even bother to read or respond to student emails. I sent Grant over 8 unique emails and none of them were ever responded to. He is definitely very knowledgeable in this domain and he's very helpful during office hours (and he's a nice guy), but overall he (and the other instructor + TAs in this course) were very much inaccessible outside of class hours for any extra help. I hope that can be rectified in future offerings of the course.

Grant also told me once in class that he'd be joining this piazza, or that he'd be telling TAs to join it. He asked me to send him a link to it, which I did. Turns out he never opened that as well. And when my class repeatedly warned him that his own website had assignment solutions up already, he kept forgetting to take them down (LOL).

The final was very long and tested specifics that didn't directly relate to DB knowledge. It might work out fine and the average might be okay, or it may not. Let's wait for the average and then see.

Not everyone's comments about this course are gonna be constructive, but that doesn't mean they don't have a point. Also, you're obviously going to see some shitposts on a student-run piazza or on reddit. That's just the way things are; take them lightly and enjoy.
I wish you were my academic rep oh my goodness
You da real gentlemen.
Bilal you're actually great

The email thing was unacceptable and something I've not seen in other courses. Also, I have many complaints about this course but I wrote them in my course evaluation and I spoke to the prof about some of them; my point is that some students don't do this, but instead find it easier to hide behind these issues when the course is doable (but unpleasant).

The final was long but not the longest cs exam (cs 246, 343 had about the same # of pages and cs 350, 341, 466 had fewer questions but much greater difficulty) and it was reasonable (many pages just had a couple of short answer questions). In terms of material tested, everything was on the slides (except "reify" which was discussed in class by Grant) and it was all related to DBs (although the second half of the course was more theoretical stuff).
To whoever changed the original post - you have a good sense of humour, but it's not nice to delete other people's posts. Here is the original:

The amount of disrespect shown towards the course, the two instructors and frankly the university regarding cs 348 is unbelievable. Yes it's not the most interesting or useful (at least the theoretical parts) or the instructors/organization the greatest but it is not the only cs course with these characteristics (e.g. 245, 458 and others). It's definitely my least favourite course and I'm in 4th year. Also I'm not a genius and have never encountered this material in my life before (I'm not in coop) and I went to all lectures (with Weddell) and I did all of the assignments and I finished the final with about ~15 min to go and hope for a good mark (> 80% final grade). (I'm not bragging, but rather I'm trying to say that getting good marks in this course is doable) Despite its length, the final was straightforward (Grant discussed the "reify" process in class) and it was typical length/difficulty for cs courses (cs 246, 343, 350 had exams that were way harder and/or longer).

If you did not do well, it is mainly your fault so stop throwing vulgar curses at the instructors or the course. It is incredibly rude; we are here to learn and the instructors (at least Grant, I don't know about Toman) are nice people and did an adequate job (like I said, I did well in the course based only on their teaching and slides). They do not deserve this treatment, and frankly I believe it is unacceptable demeanor for students at a decent university. There is a big difference between commenting that the final was hard, that you were unprepared or that professors don't respond to emails, and cursing the course or the staff. Not only does this set a precedent for the next cs 348 students (this is one of the reason why this course has such a bad reputation) but it allows students to not take responsibility for their own shortcomings (a really bad practice in school and in life). If you fail it is 100% your fault and 0% the course's or the professor's fault.

Also, I see so many students "praying for a curve" or "thanking mr. goose". Again, this is unbelievably childish conduct. Whatever mark you get you deserve (barring marking errors); it is unethical and gives you a false sense of your abilities to desire marks that do not reflect your work/understanding of a course (this applies to any course). You should not beg or ask for marks; you need to work for them.

I understand university is hard/stressful but students need to suck it up (the difficulty of university), learn to live with their abilities/work ethic and stop blaming others (for your own sake and because it is improper/unprofessional/childish).

Also, like I said in some other subposts: there are many valid complaints about this course or the instructors, which should be voiced in an appropriate manner (politely in course evaluations or face-to-face with instructors). All I'm saying is that insulting the profs/course just to feel better about yourself is not okay and is childish; the bad administrative aspects of the course make it unpleasant but it is totally doable (without actually needing the help of a random guy on piazza) by going to class (actually listening to the lectures) and by asking questions in class/office hours.

While other courses have similar issues (except for not answering emails, that's a first), cs 348 has undoubtedly the worst reputation. This shows that the only part of the reason for this is the bad administration of the course, and the key factor is actually the nature of the material. Some of it is useless but I believe every programmer should know basic logic (from cs245) and basic relational schema / functional dependencies understanding (for cs 348). If we were to make our own curriculums for courses, I'm sure we would each remove the topics we hate/have difficulty with the most (from various courses not just this one) but this is not the way education works. You have to learn to grind through a subject you hate, rather than not putting in the effort and blaming it on the course.

joining this shitposting central thread late, but here's my two cents.

If you're serious OP, your head is way too far stuck in your ass and only you can help yourself. 

>If you did not do well, it is your fault so stop complaining and throwing vulgar curses at the instructors or the course

what makes you conclude it's solely our fault? I can easily disprove you whether it be logically, in CS terms, in pmath terms; you are 100% wrong. Instructors are absolutely liable for a student's failure as well, obviously in varying degree for both the student and the instructor.

First of all, I respect other people's points of view and each person can agree or disagree.

“>If you did not do well…”: This should be taken into context of the preceding paragraph. Instructors definitely have their part of the blame for students’ performance; I’m not taking their side. All I’m saying is that “the profs are bad” is not an excuse for not going to class (and listening to lectures, rather than playing games) and not preparing properly for the final and then saying “I failed but it’s not my fault”. They certainly are to blame for not answering emails, messing up every examples did in class, poor organization and false promises, and lazy ambiguous wording.

“Good for you for doing well…”: First, in my opinion, Grant did do a decent job of explaining the material on the slides (he didn’t read the slides word-for-word like other cs profs) and any lingering confusion could have been resolved by asking questions in class/office hours (that’s what I mean by “adequate job”, but you may disagree). The fact that this did not happen often in spite of the number of people saying they have no clue about the course or the material on the final shows the “the course + profs are a disaster hence I can put no effort in and it’s ok” attitude prevalent in this course. Almost everything tested on the final (except “reify”) was in the slides and discussed in class, and the final was straightforward compared to other cs exams (a lot of short answer or T/F questions about definitions in the slides, some ER diagrams (the procedure was explained in detail in the slides), some SQL/RA/RC (a basic skill in this course presented in A1 (except for RA) and the slides); compare to programming courses like cs 246 or algorithm courses like cs 341) so it was “doable”, though unpleasant. The part about doing well is only referencing the fact that I have no prior experience in this course (if I didn’t say this, someone could be like “this guy did not do well in the course and is just taking it out on us” or “this guy probably studied databases since grade 5 (like Cameron)”). My argument is not that “I did well hence anybody who does badly is because of themselves” but rather that “the course material is not as material-heavy as other cs courses or requires previous knowledge so there is not excuse for not putting in the effort”. In terms of criticizing professors, I totally agree with this and for this course it is a must in order to improve in the future. My point was that people’s insults are more about feeling better about their poor performance rather than constructive criticism, which can be given in person or on course evaluations and in a politer/less mocking manner; I doubt many of these people would say these things to the profs in person. Also, I personally believe there should be some level of restraint and professionalism shown by students, but you may disagree.

“The precedent for CS348”: Having taken various cs courses of varying level of difficulty and having different experiences with professors I can say that some of the complaints here are also present in other cs courses, but not as many all at once. The email-answering is ridiculous but other courses also had bad TAs/assignment returns (cs 341, 343, 458 etc.), careless profs (cs 240, 348) etc. There is definitely a place for this sort of thing in a course’s reputation, but the vast difference in reputation between cs 348 and some of these other courses indicates that there is more to it than this. I am pretty sure the general hate for logic/proofs plays a big part in these horrible reputations for cs 348 (and for cs 245). Some of the material in cs 245, 348 is garbage but it is not all “utter nonsense”; I believe every cs student should be exposed to some basic logic and relational logic, and anyways you can’t expect to enjoy absolutely everything you learn in school (this is what I mean by childish behaviour). You can compare this to how many students detest math in high school and therefore give it a bad reputation and do poorly in it. There is certainly some blame on unenthusiastic lazy teaching, but there are other similar profs in other courses that have a better reputation.

“Can't believe you're making a mess out of this…”: I know it is student nature to desire curves in any class; my point was that the people who say “the profs are terrible hence I have an excuse for not caring about this course” are the first to come and say “I hope we get massive curves”. Also, it doesn’t benefit me or you in any other way than “looking good on the transcript” (please tell me another benefit). Grade inflation terrible: it’s the reason it’s hard to get into competitive programs like cs in the first place, it often gives students and other people who see their marks a false sense of their abilities, it hides some of the professors’ poor performances (high averages means they did a good job to some people), it makes marks and the effort some put in meaningless because it’s hard to compare students with similar grades, and it encourages laziness over good work ethics (people think it’s ok to play games instead of preparing for exams because the curve will save them). If an exam was harder than intended, curving is ok, but I personally don’t think it was the case this time. I would definitely prefer a hard-earned 80% than a curved 95%. In the context of this course and the lazy attitude shown by many students, I do think it’s appropriate to discuss how they pray for good marks; if you don’t put the effort in, you have no right to ask for a good mark.

“You also need to suck it up…”: I know there are always this sort of people in every course, and it’s fine. The difference here is that it is 100 times worse than in any other course, while the badness of the profs is not 100 times worse than in any other course. I don’t see how I am claiming to be superior; all I’m saying is that people exaggerate (“it’s impossible to do pass this course”, “I didn’t understand the final exam, was it in English”, “they are the worst profs in the university”) a LOT more than is warranted. By “suck it up” I mean if you didn’t come to class etc then you shouldn’t blame it on profs/the course and pray for curves.

I’m fine with anyone who disagrees with and/or ignores my points; I’m just putting it out there so that you’re aware (with the number of people who posted their overly dramatic characterizations of the profs or this course I don’t see a problem with saying I think they should tone it down a bit and look at themselves too, even though they’ll probably disregard this).

If a student did put in the effort and still feels the same way about the course, then it's completely fine. But, judging from the relatively low class/office hour attendance and the number of "the final/slides were full of hieroglyphs" comments, I think there are many who simply use the reputation of cs 348 and insults towards the profs to hide their own blame (and my post was mainly directly towards this group).

history.subject: What does 'dependency preserving' mean?
history.content: Does it just mean that no information is lost when two tables are joined?

A decomposition is dependency preserving if you don't need to join the tables to test a functional dependency.

This functional dependency is called an interrelational constraint.

Example:

D = {R1, R2}

R1 = {A, B}

R2 = {A, C, D}

F = {..., B->D, ...}

This is not dependency preserving because B->D is an interrelational constraint, and needs to join R1 and R2 to test if satisfied.

history.subject: What are "forced writes" from the logging topic?

history.content: A forced write is one that is required to be written to disk immediately. We try to (and generally succeed to) avoid forced writes by making use of the logging practice: Now that we have a log, we are not forced to immediately write the operation to disk, but we can do it later when it makes sense too based on what is recorded in the log.

history.subject: What is an external view?
history.content: This question was there on the midterm, and I interpreted it as a regular view and got the entire thing wrong. Any know what the correct answer is?

I think this is it???

An external view (or external schema) is what the user programs see. This is not necessarily a view created from the CREATE VIEW statement.

Different users may have different external views of the database (An admin user will see a lot, while some lower user may only see relevant data for its role).

history.subject: For level 3 isolation, don't you need to commit before allowing another read?
history.content: For this example, https://piazza.com/class/j8nhqgj2qgb39o?cid=498, don't you need to commit to transaction 4 and release the locks then let transaction 2 take the lock? If there is one write lock per table, t4 and t2 cannot both have locks at the same time right? Only in level 2 does that occur.

I don't see any two transactions holding exclusive locks to the same data. For that solution it was assumed that each tuple had its own exclusive lock, so two transactions could use two different tuples at the same time.

children.subject: Does it matter that the tuple had their own lock if the database system wanted to enforce level 3? Level 3 means table lock which means it doesn't matter if 2 transactions are holding exclusive locks for the same lock or not, 2 transactions cannot hold locks at the same time ever doesn't it?
Doesn't the fluff in the question really mean, if you have the table lock, you can write to any of the tuples?

This was just a super weird vague question with too many interpretations for us to come up with a conclusive answer. If they give conflicting instruction of Level3 with a description of level 2, ask for clarification.

If we go by textbook level 3 definition then the whole table is locked and the answer would be more like @435

If we go by textbook level 2 or the system that seems to be described in the question, it will be like @498
If we go by textbook level 3, could the answer simply be the transactions one after another without any other operations interleaved?
So long as your new execution order is equivalent then it's a valid answer.

@Cameron Eldridge If you interpret level 3 to mean "Repeatable Reads", which is the 3rd level if you count like (1->4), then the question makes sense. Level 4 ("Serializable") is the table-level locks.

See also: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isolation_(database_systems)#Isolation_levels

history.subject: 3NF decomp lossless
history.content:
The 3NF decomp doesn't necessarily give us a lossless decomp right?

Consider R {A, B, C}, F' = {A -> B, B -> C}

A is a candidate key for R. R1 {AB} R2 {BC} are 3NF, but not lossless.
This looks lossless still to me... Since $$AB\cap BC=B\rightarrow BC$$, this satisfies the rules for a lossless decomposition.

children.subject:
Sorry, bad example.

Let's say

R {A, B, C, D}, F' = {A -> B, B -> C, C ->D}

A is still a candidate key. R1{AB}, R2{BC}, R3{CD}.

R1 n R2 n R3 = {}

or are we checking

R1 n R2 -> R2, and R2 n R3 -> R3

Yeah you have to build up the solution in this case.

We start with ABCD, and break it into {AB, BCD}. At this point, AB n BCD = B => BCD so its good.

Then you look at just BCD on its own: BCD breaks into {BC, CD}. BC n CD = C => CD so we good again.
Ah okay, so we are checking for lossless everytime to split, not at the end? Thanks!

history.subject: Doubt about transaction ordering
history.content:
I read in one of the posts about the last question on the final that if a transaction is blocked on a particular row then it can still execute transactions on other rows. I don't think this was the way Wedell did it. He followed that if a T is blocked it skips all of its operations until it gets the lock it was blocked on, can anyone confirm, please?

Thanks

I think it depends on the order of the operations. Since we don't want to reorder operations within one transaction, if there are other operations before the blocked one we will still continue those, but once we reach the block then it should stop and wait.

Other answers to similar questions are probably conflicting each other on here by now. I think we're all just figuring this stuff out together at this point.

children.subject:
Yup what you said makes sense. My slight doubt still is a situation as follows:

T1 - blocked (on row 1)

T1 - read(row 3)

T2 - write(row 3)

.

.

.

T1 (now can start running again as someone committed)

Now in this case, if we stop at the blocked transaction, then we will end up reading the wrong value of row 3 at the end cause T2 would've modified it. Any idea why this is okay/not okay?

I think this is the situation that is being prevented by Isolation level 3 (Table level Strict2PL). If someone's looking at any row, we can't modify the table yet (i.e., T2's write would be blocking as well).

For the question that keeps coming up though, it is basically running in Level 2, which may be why situations like this come up. If we were to run our program on isolation level 2, we would have to be ready for situations where data being read is not exactly as we expect it.

That's my understanding anyway...
So you're saying T1 watches row 3 even though its blocked?

If we have table level locks, then yeah T1 is blocked on row 1 which would imply that someone somewhere holds the lock for the table that row 1 is in. Since this is the same table that row 3 is in, T2 is also blocked (because the whole table is locked).

history.subject: Serialization Graph
history.content:
Does anyone know how to do it, and the best way to go about doing it?

For example, for this here:

H4 = w1[x] w2[u] w2[y] w1[y] w3[x] w3[u] w1[z]

Generally, for each entry in the schedule, you look for any other transaction that uses the same resource after that (and at least one of them is a write).

Example:

w1[x]... so anything after this involving x will require that T1 precedes it.

  • w3[x] appears after, so T1 -> T3 is an edge

w2[u]: w3[u] appears later, so T2 -> T3 is an edge

w2[y]: w1[y] appears later, so T2 -> T1 is an edge

w1[y]: Nothing later uses y, so no edges from this

w3[x]: no edges, same reason

w3[u]: no edges, same reason

w1[z]: no edges, same reason

So if you draw a triangle with nodes {T1,T2,T3} and edges {T1->T3, T2->T3, T2->T1} you will see that it is a DAG.

An equivalent serial ordering here would be T2, then T1, then T3.

w2[u]: w3[u] appears later, so T2 -> T3 is an edge

w2[y]: w1[y] appears later, so T2 -> T1 is an edge

w1[y]: Nothing later uses y, so no edges from this

w3[x]: no edges, same reason

w3[u]: no edges, same reason

w1[z]: no edges, same reason

So if you draw a triangle with nodes {T1,T2,T3} and edges {T1->T3, T2->T3, T2->T1} you will see that it is a DAG.

history.subject: Why do relations have at most one clustering index?

history.content:
Relations are stored in some data structure. For the sake of argument think of a B or B+ tree. The ordering of this data structure can only be based off one attribute, that's just the way they work. Now, when an index is clustered, it means that similar values are stored in similar places. This index is kind of like a "sorted order" of the tuples. So you can only sort by one attribute and index it in that order in the data structure.

history.subject: Sample final Q6b
history.content: Assuming everything ran and committed before the system failure, would all transactions be committed after system recovery? I'm guessing yes since all logs are written before commits.

Assuming the logger finished writing the log, then yes all transactions could be recovered and correctly committed after the system recovery.

If the system failure occurred while writing the log, then any transactions missing a COMMIT entry will be lost.

history.subject: Week 12 Slide 7
history.content:
Why is this true for creating index on LastnameIndex?

"Increase or decrease execution time for updates or deletions of tuples from Employee"

If you were doing something like UPDATE Employee SET FirstName = 'John' WHERE LastName = 'Smith', the execution time will decrease because it's way easier to find employees with last name Smith by using the index.

If you said UPDATE Employee SET LastName = 'Doe' WHERE FirstName = 'John', then it's all slowed down now because not only do we have to search the table linearly for all the Johns, we then have to go and update the index

history.content: Looks good except the first one. I think there should be a cycle between 1 and 3 because of the last 4 instructions in the order presented.

children.subject:
Why is the first one, not serializable?

When looking at the last four instructions in order: r1[z] r3[z] w3[z] w1[z]

I thought all conditions had to be true for there to be a conflict:

 - different transactions 

 - access the same item

 - at least one is a write operation

wouldn't that make r1[z] have no conflict with r3[z]?

If we were to serialize this, we would need to have

r1[z] w1[z] r3[z] w3[z]

OR

r3[z] w3[z] r1[z] w1[z]

In either case, one of these transactions will not be reading the same value as it was in the original execution, so we can't serialize it.

history.subject: What is the exact difference between ESQL and Dynamic ESQL?
history.content: What is the exact difference between ESQL and Dynamic ESQL?

I think you mean Static ESQL and Dynamic ESQL.

Static ESQL is what we used on A2. It is hard coded into the application, and then compiled and bound to the database at the compile step.

Dynamic ESQL is not what we used on A2. Strings are constructed by the code, which are then compiled at runtime. This allows for more freedom in what the queries retrieve, but the user program will have to take time to compile and optimize each query.

history.subject: Relational Algebra
history.content: Can someone write a short precise teaching for relational algebra? We have one for relational calculus but I can't seem to find it for relational algebra.

Good question. Surprised it didn't come up earlier. I haven't tried doing much RA yet to be honest, but this will be a good exercise.

Here's my table again:

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Starting with the basics:

SELECT * FROM Books

$$Books$$

Yeah, just the name of the table. Selecting everything is the default.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The two fundamental operators of the RA are selection ($$\sigma$$) and projection ($$pi$$).

Start with projection:

SELECT name, author FROM Books

$$\pi_{\#2,\#3}(Books)$$

Some reason the most standard way to write RA is to just use the column numbers, which start counting at 1. It's kind of awkward, but that's just how it goes. You can maybe use column names for personal clarity, but I feel like just putting the numbers in for the exam is the way to go.

Also note that the order does matter when using projection. $$\pi_{\#3,\#2}(Books)$$ is not equivalent to the above because now columns are in a different order. I'll make this more clear later on when there are more complicated queries.

Selection is kind of like the where clause. Try this:

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\pi_{\#2}(\sigma_{\#3=1}(Books))$$

We nest operators to combine their effects. It's like calling a function.

The $$\sigma$$ works by evaluating the condition in the subscript on each tuple returned from the subquery. In this case, the subquery is $$Books$$, so it will go something like this:

$$(1, Harry Potter 1, 1, 1997)\#3 = 1$$ ? Yes! Return this tuple

$$(2, Harry Potter 2, 1, 1998)\#3 = 1$$ ? Yes! Return this tuple

$$(3, Eragon, 2, 2002)\#3 = 1$$ ? No! Do not return this tuple.

...And so on.

In any case, it only ever sees one tuple at a time. This raises the question then, how do we compare two different rows?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To compare multiple rows at once, we must use joins. The easiest kind of join is the cross join, $$\times$$, which works as usual.

Say I want to find all authors who have written more than one book:

SELECT author FROM Books HAVING count(book_id) > 1 GROUP BY author

Or equivalently:

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.book_id <> c.book_id AND b.author = c.author)

Or equivalently:

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b, Books c WHERE b.author = c.author AND b.id != c.id<br />

$$\{ \langle Author \rangle | \exists a. Books\langle a, \_, Author, \_ \rangle \wedge \exists b.(Books\langle b, \_, Author, \_\rangle) \wedge a \neq b\} $$

$$\pi_{\#3}(\sigma_{\#1\neq \#5 \wedge \#3=\#7}(Books \times Books))$$

I've included the calculus for this one to show the transformation between the two, as this is a relatively straightforward process except for in the case of existence.

  1. The first thing to note is that we need to check two rows at once. This would imply that we need to join two tuples into one larger tuple, and the way to do that best is with the cross join.
  2. Next, look at the condition we must check, and encode that into the $$\sigma$$ condition. In this case we have two conditions, but they can be combined using the $$\wedge$$. When working with joined tuples, just put all the attributes of the first one, then all the second. The $$ Books\times Books$$ table will look like this:

book_id1 | name1 | author1 | pub_year1 | book_id2 | name2 | author2 | pub_year2

From there, the column indexes work as usual.

Finally, use projection to take the required columns as usual. Because of how sets work, we don't need to worry about the DISTINCT part of the query.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Multiple table queries use joins very similarly to above, just with two tables. A simple example:

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON b.author = a.author_id

$$\{ \langle B, A \rangle | \exists i. (Books\langle \_, B, i, \_ \rangle \wedge Author \langle i, A, \_, \_ \rangle) \}$$

$$\pi_{ \#2, \#6 } ( Books \Join_{\#3=\#4} Authors )$$

Here I have used a different join ("natural join"), which takes a condition and acts similar to the inner join. Once joined, we perform projection as usual to extract the required attributes.

A note on the index numbers: Think of it like we joined the table first, then use the index numbers based on that final table. The right side of the join operator gets the larger numbers as usual.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Negation is written by subtracting sets from each other. We can now find the oldest book:

SELECT name FROM Books b WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.pub_year < c.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists y_1.(Books\langle \_, N, \_, y_1\rangle \wedge \neg \exists y_2 (Books\langle \_, \_, \_, y_2\rangle \wedge y_2 < y_1))\} $$

$$\pi_{\#2}(Books - \pi_{\#1, \#2, \#3, \#4}(\sigma_{\#4> \#8}(Books \times Books)))$$

Here it's pretty easy to figure out. We find all the ones we don't want to take, and then subtract it! Just have to be careful about subtracting sets: they must have the same attributes to be able to subtract it. Since we've done the join, there are now extra attributes ($$Books \times Books$$ has 8, while Books just has 4) so we have to project it back down to the original table's worth of attributes, in the correct order.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The only thing missing from RC to RA now is the $$\vee$$. Not like we use this much, but might as well add it here...

Kind of a contrived stupid example because I don't have a good database for usage of $$\vee$$:

(SELECT pub_year as year FROM Books) UNION (SELECT birth_year as year FROM Authors)

$$\{ \langle Y \rangle | Books\langle \_, \_, \_, Y \rangle \vee Author \langle \_, \_, \_, Y \rangle \} $$

$$\pi_{\#4}(Books) \cup \pi_{\#4}(Authors)$$

As with subtraction, the $$\cup$$ requires that both sides have the same set of attributes. We do this by projecting both to the same thing, then you can just union them and get the result.

Good question. Surprised it didn't come up earlier. I haven't tried doing much RA yet to be honest, but this will be a good exercise.

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.book_id <> c.book_id AND b.author = c.author)

Or equivalently:

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b, Books c WHERE b.author = c.author AND b.id != c.id<br />

$$\{ \langle Author \rangle | \exists a. Books\langle a, \_, Author, \_ \rangle \wedge \exists b.(Books\langle b, \_, Author, \_\rangle) \wedge a \neq b\} $$

$$\pi_{\#3}(\sigma_{\#1\neq \#5 \wedge \#3=\#7}(Books \times Books))$$

I've included the calculus for this one to show the transformation between the two, as this is a relatively straightforward process except for in the case of existence.

  1. The first thing to note is that we need to check two rows at once. This would imply that we need to join two tuples into one larger tuple, and the way to do that best is with the cross join.
  2. Next, look at the condition we must check, and encode that into the $$\sigma$$ condition. In this case we have two conditions, but they can be combined using the $$\wedge$$. When working with joined tuples, just put all the attributes of the first one, then all the second. The $$ Books\times Books$$ table will look like this:

book_id1 | name1 | author1 | pub_year1 | book_id2 | name2 | author2 | pub_year2

From there, the column indexes work as usual.

Finally, use projection to take the required columns as usual. Because of how sets work, we don't need to worry about the DISTINCT part of the query.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Multiple table queries use joins very similarly to above, just with two tables. A simple example:

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON b.author = a.author_id

$$\{ \langle B, A \rangle | \exists i. (Books\langle \_, B, i, \_ \rangle \wedge Author \langle i, A, \_, \_ \rangle) \}$$

$$\pi_{ \#2, \#6 } ( Books \Join_{\#3=\#1} Authors )$$

Here I have used a different join ("natural join"), which takes a condition and acts similar to the inner join. I believe that for this condition, the left side corresponds to the left expression, and the right side to the right expression, so the attribute numbers are relative to those relations. Once joined, we perform projection as usual to extract the required attributes.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Negation is written by subtracting sets from each other. We can now find the oldest book:

SELECT name FROM Books b WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.pub_year < c.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists y_1.(Books\langle \_, N, \_, y_1\rangle \wedge \neg \exists y_2 (Books\langle \_, \_, \_, y_2\rangle \wedge y_2 < y_1))\} $$

$$\pi_{\#2}(Books - \pi_{\#1, \#2, \#3, \#4}(\sigma_{\#4> \#8}(Books \times Books)))$$

Here it's pretty easy to figure out. We find all the ones we don't want to take, and then subtract it! Just have to be careful about subtracting sets: they must have the same attributes to be able to subtract it. Since we've done the join, there are now extra attributes ($$Books \times Books$$ has 8, while Books just has 4) so we have to project it back down to the original table's worth of attributes, in the correct order.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The only thing missing from RC to RA now is the $$\vee$$. Not like we use this much, but might as well add it here...

Kind of a contrived stupid example because I don't have a good database for usage of $$\vee$$:

(SELECT pub_year as year FROM Books) UNION (SELECT birth_year as year FROM Authors)

$$\{ \langle Y \rangle | Books\langle \_, \_, \_, Y \rangle \vee Author \langle \_, \_, \_, Y \rangle \} $$

$$\pi_{\#4}(Books) \cup \pi_{\#4}(Authors)$$

As with subtraction, the $$\cup$$ requires that both sides have the same set of attributes. We do this by projecting both to the same thing, then you can just union them and get the result.

Good question. Surprised it didn't come up earlier. I haven't tried doing much RA yet to be honest, but this will be a good exercise.

Here's my table again:

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Starting with the basics:

SELECT * FROM Books

$$Books$$

Yeah, just the name of the table. Selecting everything is the default.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The two fundamental operators of the RA are selection ($$\sigma$$) and projection ($$pi$$).

Start with projection:

SELECT name, author FROM Books

$$\pi_{\#2,\#3}(Books)$$

Some reason the most standard way to write RA is to just use the column numbers, which start counting at 1. It's kind of awkward, but that's just how it goes. You can maybe use column names for personal clarity, but I feel like just putting the numbers in for the exam is the way to go.

Also note that the order does matter when using projection. $$\pi_{\#3,\#2}(Books)$$ is not equivalent to the above because now columns are in a different order. I'll make this more clear later on when there are more complicated queries.

Selection is kind of like the where clause. Try this:

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\pi_{\#2}(\sigma_{\#3=1}(Books))$$

We nest operators to combine their effects. It's like calling a function.

The $$\sigma$$ works by evaluating the condition in the subscript on each tuple returned from the subquery. In this case, the subquery is $$Books$$, so it will go something like this:

$$(1, Harry Potter 1, 1, 1997)\#3 = 1$$ ? Yes! Return this tuple

$$(2, Harry Potter 2, 1, 1998)\#3 = 1$$ ? Yes! Return this tuple

$$(3, Eragon, 2, 2002)\#3 = 1$$ ? No! Do not return this tuple.

...And so on.

In any case, it only ever sees one tuple at a time. This raises the question then, how do we compare two different rows?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To compare multiple rows at once, we must use joins. The easiest kind of join is the cross join, $$\times$$, which works as usual.

Say I want to find all authors who have written more than one book:

SELECT author FROM Books HAVING count(book_id) > 1 GROUP BY author

Or equivalently:

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.book_id <> c.book_id AND b.author = c.author)

Or equivalently:

SELECT DISTINCT b.author FROM Books b, Books c WHERE b.author = c.author AND b.id != c.id

$$\{ \langle Author \rangle | \exists a. Books\langle a, \_, Author, \_ \rangle \wedge \exists b.(Books\langle b, \_, Author, \_\rangle) \wedge a \neq b\} $$

$$\pi_{\#3}(\sigma_{\#1\neq \#5 \wedge \#3=\#7}(Books \times Books))$$

I've included the calculus for this one to show the transformation between the two, as this is a relatively straightforward process except for in the case of existence.

  1. The first thing to note is that we need to check two rows at once. This would imply that we need to join two tuples into one larger tuple, and the way to do that best is with the cross join.
  2. Next, look at the condition we must check, and encode that into the $$\sigma$$ condition. In this case we have two conditions, but they can be combined using the $$\wedge$$. When working with joined tuples, just put all the attributes of the first one, then all the second. The $$ Books\times Books$$ table will look like this:

book_id1 | name1 | author1 | pub_year1 | book_id2 | name2 | author2 | pub_year2

From there, the column indexes work as usual.

Finally, use projection to take the required columns as usual. Because of how sets work, we don't need to worry about the DISTINCT part of the query.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Multiple table queries use joins very similarly to above, just with two tables. A simple example:

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON b.author = a.author_id

$$\{ \langle B, A \rangle | \exists i. (Books\langle \_, B, i, \_ \rangle \wedge Author \langle i, A, \_, \_ \rangle) \}$$

$$\pi_{ \#2, \#6 } ( Books \Join_{\#3=\#1} Authors )$$

Here I have used a different join ("natural join"), which takes a condition and acts similar to the inner join. I believe that for this condition, the left side corresponds to the left expression, and the right side to the right expression, so the attribute numbers are relative to those relations. Once joined, we perform projection as usual to extract the required attributes.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Negation is written by subtracting sets from each other. We can now find the oldest book:

SELECT name FROM Books b WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books c WHERE b.pub_year < c.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists y_1.(Books\langle \_, N, \_, y_1\rangle \wedge \neg \exists y_2 (Books\langle \_, \_, \_, y_2\rangle \wedge y_2 < y_1))\} $$

$$\pi_{\#2}(Books - \pi_{\#1, \#2, \#3, \#4}(\sigma_{\#4> \#8}(Books \times Books)))$$

Here it's pretty easy to figure out. We find all the ones we don't want to take, and then subtract it! Just have to be careful about subtracting sets: they must have the same attributes to be able to subtract it. Since we've done the join, there are now extra attributes ($$Books \times Books$$ has 8, while Books just has 4) so we have to project it back down to the original table's worth of attributes, in the correct order.

history.subject: Relationship between 2PL and Isolation level
history.content:
At long last, I understood what I don't understand...

I don't really know how to make sense of Q6(a).

The DB has strict 2PL (all locks are held until committed) AND each client operates on isolation level 3. What if the question stated isolation level 2 (or 1 or 0 ???) ? Do we still solve the question using shared/exclusive locks like before? What is supposed to change?

Not really sure what's the point of talking about isolation level since we only seem to be caring about 2PL here ...

Thanks

Yeah for that question, it seems a little off... Our definition of Isolation level 3 was table level Strict2PL, yet in this question they say level 3 but at tuple level, which is the definition of level 2.

One potential answer to this question is on @498. There are certainly other correct answers though.

I gave an answer for using the definition of Level 3 isolation from the slides on @435.

The sequence given in the question was Level 0, so they won't ask that. Everything is allowed in level 0.

Level 1 is the only one we haven't written anywhere yet, so follow the rules for that level and you should be able to figure them out. The difference of Level 1 and Level 2 is that we don't take a shared lock for reading (@407).

children.subject: Thank you!! this clears up things. One more question though: can we expect to solve question with respect to just strict 2PL (i.e: read + shared lock), or is there a possibility that they ask us to solve the question using only 2PL (the difference between the two is not clear to me)

It's not likely they'll ask for regular 2PL, since Strict2PL is the kind that is useful for databases. I think the distinction is just the timing of the release:

For strict 2PL it is when the transaction committed/aborted (no more acquiring locks after).

For not strict 2PL, we release all locks we hold at once, but it doesn't have to be at the commit. We can release them all and then start acquiring new things again.
Hmm, alright. Yeah makes sense, cause I think isolation levels are only defined for strict 2PL if you look @ the slides.

history.subject: A4Q2

"If a history is serializable, specify a serial order of transaction execution to which it is equivalent."

How do you get an "equivalent" serializable history? I thought of just writing T1T2T3, since this is a serializable schedule, but is it really "equivalent" ? What does equivalent mean here?

Thanks
See followup of @485

children.subject: Hey Cameron, I read that before asking this and I still have the same question. Can we get an equivalent schedule by swapping out non-conflicting transactions until we get a serial schedule? Is this the right idea?

I think so yeah, not sure what you mean by "swapping out" though. If you move the operations one at a time it is pretty easy to keep things equivalent. Just keep doing that until you get something serial or you can't move them any more.
Sorry yeah, I meant swap individual operations until we get a serial schedule (something like: T1T2T3 or T3T2T1 etc ...)
Yeah sounds about right then.

history.subject: isolation levels
history.content: What are the four isolation levels and how they are different? Thanks.

http://infocenter.sybase.com/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.sybase.dc20021_1251/html/locking/locking21.htm

Explains it pretty well.

Four isolation levels are supported:
Level 3: (Serializability)
⇒ essentially table-level strict 2PL
Level 2: (Repeatable Read)
⇒ tuple-level strict 2PL; “phantom tuples” may occur
Level 1: (Cursor Stability)
⇒ tuple-level exclusive-lock only strict 2PL
reading the same object twice: different values
Level 0:
⇒ neither read nor write locks are acquired
⇒ transaction may read uncommitted updates

http://infocenter.sybase.com/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.sybase.dc20021_1251/html/locking/locking21.htm

Explains it pretty well.

A transaction cannot commit while blocked, as it is still waiting to finish. It will only commit once all actions have been completed.

history.subject: Logging undo
history.content:
If I have the following transaction log after a system failure:

T1, begin
T1, X, 0, 5
T2, begin
T2, X, 5, 10
T2, commit

Does X = 10 since T2 committed?

This is not a schedule that would be produced by the scheduler because there are two transactions writing to the same object which goes against the 2PL rules. If we change T1 to modify Y like below, then after a system failure and recovery, the database has X = 10, and Y = 0

T1, begin
T1, Y, 0, 5
T2, begin
T2, X, 5, 10
T2, commit

history.subject: Logging
history.content:
I'm really confused about reading a log.

When I see something like:

T0,begin
T0,X,99,100
T1,begin
T1,Y,199,200
T2,begin
T2,Z,51,50
T1,M,1000,10
T1,commit
T3,begin
T2,abort
T3,Y,200,50
T4,begin
T4,M,10,100
T3,commit

I have no idea how to even begin reading it. I've read through the notes, but they still don't make sense. Can someone give me a TLDR or a speed through of how to read logs/generate logs?

Thank you!

T0,begin            // begin log entry for transaction 0
T0,X,99,100         // transaction 0 has changed X from 99 to 100
T1,begin            // begin log entry for transaction 1
T1,Y,199,200        // transaction 1 has changed Y from 199 to 200
T2,begin            // begin log entry for transaction 2
T2,Z,51,50          // transaction 2 has changed Z from 51 to 50
T1,M,1000,10        // transaction 1 has changed M from 1000 to 10
T1,commit           // commit transaction 1. All changes saved (Y=200, M=10)
T3,begin            // begin transaction 3
T2,abort            // abort transaction 2. All changes reverted (Z=51)
T3,Y,200,50         // transaction 3 has changed Y from 200 to 50
T4,begin            // begin transaction 4
T4,M,10,100         // transaction 4 has changed M from 10 to 100
T3,commit           // commit transaction 3. All changes saved (Y=50)

Notice that above there are no commit/abort messages for transactions 0 or 4, so we cannot say whether their changes will be persisted to the database yet.

To generate a log, write Tx, begin, when the transaction x starts, then whenever it changes a value, say v, add a line Tx, v, OLDVALUE, NEWVALUE, allowing us to repeat this action (set to new value) or undo the action (set to old value) at any time in the future. Once committed or aborted, add a corresponding Tx, commit or Tx, abort line to the log. Reading from the database does not need to be logged because that is not a step that is required to recover from system failure.

children.subject:
So a transaction can do multiple things, including read, write, etc? For example, how would I wrote the transaction as a read write sequence, ie:

Ti = ri [x1]; ri [x2];wi [x1]; : : : ; ri [x4];wi [x2];

for example T2 and T3 from above

A transaction can do both reads and writes yeah. Some sequence of reads and writes such as r1[x] r2[y] w1[x] w1[y] r2[x] could be logged as:

T1,begin
T1,X,old,new
T1,commit
T2,begin
T2,Y,old,new
T2,commit

There are lots of other possible logs, but notice that we lose all the reads, since this is a log we are discussing, rather than a sequence of operations.

To go the other way for, say, T3 from above, one possible transaction that could have produced that log is r3[y] w3[y] r3[y] r3[z]. Another more minimal sequence of operations could be just w3[y]. Since we only have a log, we don't know anything about how many reads were performed, or what objects were read.
Oh, so we can't see the values being written? That's what I meant.
Yeah schedules don't mention the values at all, just the ordering, so we cannot build a real log from it. The logger in the DB implementation will have access to more info than us.

history.subject: Conflict Equivalent Histories
history.content:
What does this mean on slide 7 from the Database Tuning and Physical Design: Execution of Transactions slides

"we require that in two conflict-equivalent histories all conflicting operations are ordered the same way"

Two schedules are conflict equivalent if whenever there is a conflict between two transactions, it's always the same transaction first, then second.

This two transactions are conflicting (someone is writing to a value that is being read):

r1[x] w2[x] w1[z] r2[z]

And this is a conflict equivalent schedule (still conflicting, but all the conflicts still have transaction 2 going after transaction 1):

r1[x] w1[z] w2[x] r2[z]

Here's the wikipedia article on it, which is pretty good I think https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schedule_(computer_science)#Conflicting_actions

history.subject: Week 12: Database Tuning
history.content: Do we even need to know this? Most of the concepts introduced are very vague and it doesn't feel like any questions can be made to test us on this.

It would be good to understand the concepts introduced here, such as why we should build (or tune) databases based on how they will be used. Understand the definitions (workload, plan, clustering/non-clustering/co-clustering index) and how/why B-trees work well in the physical data structure. Be able to identify a good time to add or use an index, in at least a simple case.

This is probably not going to be a major portion of the final though, if I had to guess... judge for yourself and make time for it accordingly.

children.subject: How/why does B-trees work well in the physical data structure?

B-trees, similar to binary search trees, provide an ordered data structure for which searching can be performed in $$O(\log n)$$ time. For the case of databases, however, B-trees are preferable because they take advantage of the physical memory model of a computer. When reading data from a file, this allows us to read in larger chunks/blocks of relevant data at once, while still getting the searching benefits.

If you do not know of how B-trees work in general, maybe the CS240 piazza or notes will have more info.

history.subject: How to determine if two executions are equivalent?
history.content:
Example:
An interleaved execution of two transactions:
Sa = w1[x] r2[x] w1[y] r2[y]
An equivalent serial execution (T1 , T2):
Sb = w1[x] w1[y] r2[x] r2[y]
An interleaved execution with no equivalent serial execution:
Sc = w1[x] r2[x] r2[y] w1[y]

Why is Sa and Sb equivalent and Sc has no equivalent serial execution?

We know Sb is a serial execution of Sa. In Sa, a read to x happens after a write, and similarly for y. In Sb, the behaviors from Sa also holds (a write to x and y happens first). Hence they are equivalent.

For Sc, we have thread 2 must read from y before thread 1 can write to y. Similarly, a write from thread 1 to x must happen before a read from thread 2 to x. If we try to put the thread executions in order (we try to serialize Sc), one of the behavior in Sc will not hold. Hence no serial execution equivalent exists.

children.subject:
What does it mean for an execution to be serial?

Is it saying that all of T1s reads/writes are scheduled before T2s thus is serializable? Thus since we can rearrange Sa into Sb and maintain the same results it's serializable?

An execution is serial when it's not switching back and forth between two transactions. Say we had transactions 1 and 2 executing stuff like:

w1 w2 r1 w2 r2 r1 w1 r2

Then it's not serial because it goes back and forth, while

w1 w1 r1 r1 w1 r1 r2 w2 r2

is serial because all the transaction 1 things occur first, then all the transaction two things.

The order of transactions does not matter (Could do transaction 2 before transaction 1, then it is still serial).

To be equivalent, we must read the same value with every read, and write the same final value to the database in the end, even though the order of the actual operations may be different.

To be serializable means "to have a serial equivalent".
so something like r1 w1 r1 is NOT equivalent? since the second read is on a different value than the first?

If there is only 1 transaction, then it's hard to see the distinction.

R1[x] R2[x] W1[x]

Is not equivalent to

R1[x] W1[x] R2[x]

Since the second transaction sees something different

But it is equivalent to

R2[x] R1[x] W1[x]

Since both transactions see the same values, but now this is serialized

history.subject: What's the purpose of a cursor and an embedded SQL preprocessor?
history.content: What's the purpose of a cursor and an embedded SQL preprocessor?

A cursor provides a method for accessing one row of the database at a time. We prefer this to loading the entire database into the program at once because we don't have to copy as much data to process the query (See @387).

The preprocessor is to process the SQL statements so that they can be compiled, bound to a database, and optimized before running the code. This avoids having to compile and optimize the query every time the program is run.

children.subject:
I believe Grant discussed I c) 1. in class and the answer is false. Consider the following situation:

F = union over 1 <= j <= n of {A_j -> B_j} so |F| = 2n and there are 2^n candidate keys, (A_1/B_1, ... , A_n/B_n) where / means we can choose either A_j or B_j for each j.
if A_j --> B_j, why can we use B_j as candidate keys?

Toman discussed this in class, and both 2. and 3. are true. 

2. Implementations often allow primary keys to be non-unique, and though candidate keys are potential identifiers, marking a key as a primary key allows it to act differently. A clear example of this is a foreign key, which will only work with a primary key (not a candidate key). 

3. You can rewrite any dependency in the form they described (at most 2 on the LHS and one on the RHS).

A_1A_2...A_k -> B_1B_2...B_m can be rewritten as the following set of FDs: 

A_1A_2->X_1

X_1A_3->X_2

X_2A_4->X_3

...

X_(k-2)A_k -> B_1

X_(k-2)A_k -> B_2

...

X_(k-2)A_k -> B_m


As an example, ABC->DE can be replaced with

AB->X

XC->D

XC->E
Guess I'm not passing the T/F section of our final...
They should give an option for "probably true / probably false"
How can you use $$AB$$ -> $$X$$ to get $$XC$$->$$D$$ and $$XC$$->$$E$$ using the axioms/rules??

So you can either work from ABC->DE to the three FDs listed or vice versa. It's easiest to work from the three back to the original based on the way Armstrong's axioms are written, but both can be done. 

If XC-D and XC->E then XC->DE (union) 

If XC->DE and AB->X then ABC->DE (pseudo-transitivity)

Makes sense backwards. Looks like the second one is atleast as expressive as the first. However, how do you know for sure the second one is not more powerful than the first?

and also, is pseudo-transitivity really a thing? couldn't find it on the slides although it definitely makes sense intuitively. Thanks

The question asked whether the second was at least as expressive as the first, so it's sufficient to show that. Pseudo-transitivity is mentioned in the textbook and Wikipedia, but can be derived from the rules we learned (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armstrong%27s_axioms#Pseudo_transitivity). Hope that helps

I don't think that going backwards is a valid proof. You should be proving (ABC->DE) => (AB->X ^ XC->D ^ XC->E), not the reverse. And I can't figure out a valid proof for that.

Edit: Nevermind. Just realized the question is asking for it to be "at least" as expressive, so the reverse proof is valid.

history.subject: what cannot be written in Relational calculus and relational algebra respectively?
history.content: what cannot be written in Relational calculus and relational algebra respectively?

Relational calculus has no way of representing aggregation and bag semantics, counting, sorting, and expressions (like SELECT age + salary + 50 FROM Employees).

Relational algebra is just another notation for the same things as relational calculus. It can show exactly the same things. David has mentioned a few times that optionally we can say that relational algebra respects the bag semantics, and provide another operator for eliminating duplicate rows, but I don't think we do that for this course.

children.subject: what does bag semantics mean? Could you give an example?

Relational calculus works with sets of tuples, in the sense of sets from math class: Unordered collection of unique values. We have no duplicates in a Set.

Bag semantics is how the actual database systems work: Duplicate rows are permitted. Bag (or multiset) is just a set that permits duplicates.
so Relational calculus and algebra would always give unique values (as if using select distinct) and cannot return duplicated rows?
Yeah

history.content:
Okay, let's walk through an example. I'm doing this for my own clarity too:

So our question is, is X a superkey of relational schema R?

Suppose R = {name, address, age} (A table, or relational schema)

Suppose X = name

and I have decided that we have F = {name -> address, name -> age}

ComputeX+(X,F) tells us we should do the following with X and F:

X+ = X gives X+ = {name}
i) We have (Y->Z) = (name->address) in F such that
	1) {name} is a subset of X+
	2) {address} is not a subset of X+
	then X+ = X+ union {address} 
	now X+ = {name, address}
ii) We have (Y->Z) = (name->age) in F such that
	1) {name} is a subset of X+
	2) {age} is not a subset of X+
	then X+ = X+ union {age}
	now X+ = {name, address, age}
return X+

So, you can see that X+ is now {name, address, age}, which is the same as our relational schema R. Therefore, X is a superkey of R.

If you try to run through this example with our decided F and X = address, you would find that address is not a superkey of R.
