Suppose X = name

and I have decided that we have F = {name -> address, name -> age}

ComputeX+(X,F) tells us we should do the following with X and F:

X+ = X gives X+ = {name}
i) We have (Y->Z) = (name->address) in F such that
	1) {name} is a subset of X+
	2) {address} is not a subset of X+
	then X+ = X+ union {address} 
	now X+ = {name, address}
ii) We have (Y->Z) = (name->age) in F such that
	1) {name} is a subset of X+
	2) {age} is not a subset of X+
	then X+ = X+ union {age}
	now X+ = {name, address, age}
return X+

So, you can see that X+ is now {name, address, age}, which is the same as our relational schema R. Therefore, X is a superkey of R.

If you try to run through this example with our decided F and X = address, you would find that address is not a superkey of R.

history.subject: Question about execution order
history.content:
Say the database system uses strict two-phase locking and these are the following transactions

T1: read x

T2: read x

T3: write x

T4: read x

(more transactions follow this)

Would the execution order make T4:read x go right after T2: read x because T4 only needs the shared lock or will it wait until T3 unblocks and then do T4:read x after T3: write x runs because then T4 will read the correct value for x.
The latter. A sound scheduler would have T4 execute after T3 (and T2 and T1). Check out week 11 slide 5.

children.subject:
So for another scenario:

T1: read x

T2: write x

T1: read x

would this result in a deadlock because T2 can't write until T1 releases the lock but T1 can't release the lock until it's done and that's after T2 writes

Remember that a single transaction is a set of ordered instructions, and that our scheduler is the one doing the job of running multiple schedules here all at once. So if T1 = r[x], r[x] and T2 = w[x], our scheduler should arrange these so that they appear as if they're running in that order. In this case, it would be doubly faulty if it created the schedule T1.r[x], T2.w[x], T1.r[x] since T2 will not have an exclusive lock and also because T1 would not appear to have committed before T2 is run.
So if somehow such a schedule were created, it's not actually a deadlock, since we can simply delay T2, commit T1 (and release the shared lock), then run T2.
But what if that scenario was given in the strict twophase locking question where it asks to give executing order? What should we do?
I think you should read through slides 7-10 of week 11 (https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~david/cs348/lect-TPEXEC-handout.pdf). If you have any more questions, feel free to keep asking.

Sorry, I misread that last comment. Where's the locking question you're talking about?

e: I'm walking through it right now, give me a few.

Say we had these transactions:

T1: read x

T2: write x

T1: read x

and we were asked to use a strict two-phase locking protocol, with locks being granted on individual tuples. How would we schedule this because based on how Grant did it in class I though you only release a lock if the transaction commits or aborts.
Yeah, I believe T2 would abort in this case. I think I was wrong earlier. I'd take it in to office hours if you really want to make sure.
Yeah thats what i think too because slides say "in practice: detection (or often just a timeout) and abort" on slide 11

Ahh, after rereading question VI part a) on the sample final, I think it's asking you to give a possible schedule assuming isolation level 3. So, the original schedule that goes: (T1: begin, T1: read, T2: begin) etc is a schedule that's possible under isolation level 0, since we allow reads and writes on uncommitted updates. It wants you to give an alternate order of execution under strict table-level 2PL. Basically, it's asking for (T1: begin, ... , T1: commit , T2: begin , ... , T2: commit , ... ).

history.subject: Bag Operations expressed in Relational Calculus
history.content: Is it possible to express bag operations in relational calculus (like union all, intersect all, etc.)?

No we do not use bag semantics in relational calculus. Duplicate rows are always eliminated.

Usually this shouldn't be an issue because there should be a unique primary key on each table you can use to differentiate the rows, while aggregation is simply not supported by the RC

history.subject: Difference between clustering index and primary index?
history.content: As far as I know, both require the records in the file to be sorted with respect to some search key.

A primary index is a clustering index. The difference is between a clustering (primary) and non-clustering (secondary) index.

A clustering index actually rearranges the whole table, with all the other data as well.

A non-clustering index is a separate table holding only the columns that are being used to sort, plus the primary key of the relation (so that we can find the rest of the related data as well).

Based on this fact, we can determine that only one clustering index will exist (since we only want the data copied once) and then we can have more secondary (non-clustered) index as well. A clustering index is faster than the non-clustered one because the data is always there already once we have found the keys, while a non-clustered one requires more lookups (which may not necessarily even be on the same block in the file system, if you want to think this deep).

Some example of this, and some stuff on the co-clustering idea (clustered index, but on 2+ columns) is on @385.

history.subject: What is this relational calculus symbol that looks like an and?
history.content: It looks like an upside down for all. Thanks!

I believe it is notating an aggregation of the AND operator.

That is

(^(j in X) v_j = w_j) -> (^(i in Y) v_i = w_i)

means

(v_j-1 = w_j-1 AND v_j = w_j AND ... etc) -> (v_i = w_i AND ... etc)

children.subject: B is superkey for BC, but not for R, how is "t1[B] = t2[B] => t1[ABCD] = t2[ABCD]" correct? shouldn't it be "t1[B] = t2[B] => t1[BC] = t2[BC]" only?

Oh I took that as an example of a definition of superkey. For this relation that is not what occurs, rather that is what must occur for us to be able to call B a superkey for R.

"t1[B] = t2[B] => t1[BC] = t2[BC]" is what we have

"t1[B] = t2[B] => t1[ABCD] = t2[ABCD]" is what we need

history.subject: query using the described index
history.content:
Consider a relation mark with schema (student, course, term). Assume that the instance of mark has 40,000 tuples covering 1000 students, 50 courses, and 10 terms, and that 20 records fit on each page (i.e., each disk access to the relation retrieves 20 records). Furthermore, assume that the data is clustered by student. Now consider the query select count (distinct student) from mark where course = 'CS246' and assume that the system returns the value 300 for this query.

(b) (3 marks) Assume now that there is a B+ tree index on mark (course, student) having 5 levels (i.e., it takes 5 disk accesses to find a given course-student pair in the index), and that 50 course-student pairs fit on each leaf page (i.e., each disk access to a leaf page in the B+ tree retrieves 50 index records). Which of the following best approximates how many disk accesses would be needed to answer this query using the described index?

a. Less than 5

b. Between 5 and 15

c. Between 15 and 75

d. Between 75 and 350

e. More than 350

Briefly explain the algorithm you are assuming that the system uses to answer the query with this index.

can anyone solve b)?

thx

Thanks to anon, we have a more correct answer now! Probably best to just look at the solutions PDF (https://www.student.cs.uwaterloo.ca/~cs348/W10/assignments/A2Soln.pdf

==== Below is previous incorrect answer, so don't make this mistake lol

I think between 15 and 75?

To find any student we have to execute $$\sigma_{Course=CS246}(Mark)$$. Since we use the index on Mark, it will cost 5 disk accesses per block of students. We can get 50 students at a time, so it will take either 6 (if all 300 lie directly within the blocks) or 7 (if the ends are overlapping the neighbouring blocks) blocks to be loaded from the Mark index, which leaves us with around $$6 \times 5 = 30$$ disk accesses in total.

I think between 15 and 75?

To find any student we have to execute $$\sigma_{Course=CS246}(Mark)$$. Since we use the index on Mark, it will cost 5 disk accesses per block of students. We can get 50 students at a time, so it will take either 6 (if all 300 lie directly within the blocks) or 7 (if the ends are overlapping the neighbouring blocks) blocks to be loaded from the Mark index, which leaves us with around $$6 \times 5 = 30$$ disk accesses in total.

children.subject: @"where is A4": https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~gweddell/cs348/a4.pdf

So all objects must be modified in some way correct?

as in even if an object is incomplete/aborted, it gets undone

and if an object is committed it's redone. so in some way, all the objects are modified?
As in, when performing the recovery? Every log entry is used for recovery as you describe yes.

oh I mistook "objects" to be the transactions not A X Z Y.

since the question is asking us to indicate which objects must be modified would you say the following when we apply the undo information in the log

 A goes from 3 2 

 X goes from 0 to 400

 skip T5 since it was committed

 A goes from 1 to 0

 skip T3 since it was committed etc...

 if we skip committed transactions when applying UNDO information what's the point of  redoing when we go back down from tail to head again?

Yes this looks correct. It's not necessarily going from 3 to 2, however. Just "A is set to 3" would be more accurate. The reasoning behind this is the same as why we have to redo everything:

At the point in time when we are performing the recovery process, we don't know what is currently in the database. It could be pretty much anything since the crash occurred somewhere in the middle of execution. The log entries are written, but that does not mean that the database currently reflects the final entry of the log. The only way to guarantee that everything is correct is to pretend everything in the database is broken and just do it all again from the start of time. Undo uncommitted operations because maybe the database executed that step, but it was going to be aborted later. Redo committed actions because maybe the database had half-processed that transaction but the last modification of the transaction was never completed.

Hopefully this helps... I'm not sure how to explain this exactly yet without waving my arms and drawing pictures and things.

history.subject: Candidate and Primary Keys
history.content:
Can someone explain the just of these definitions:

In the textbook the definition of a superkey makes sense, that a superkey of a relation R is a subset of the attributes such that for any tuples t1 and t2 if t1 != t2 then the t1[k] != t2[k] as in there's no tuple in the instance that shares the subset of attributes K.

Are these definitions implying the same thing? They don't make too much sense to me

Yes these imply the same thing. The definition of superkey here says that the superkey of the relation R is some K such that $$K \rightarrow R$$. By the definition of functional dependency then, this means that if we have two tuples, $$T_1$$ and $$T_2$$, if $$T_1[K] = T_2[K]$$ then $$T_1 = T_2$$. This is just the contrapositive (I think?) of your definition.

For candidate key, it's the minimal superkey. Not sure what the textbook definition of this one is, so can't compare them, but it will mean the same thing as the textbook one for sure :P

Yeah I believe (according to the slides definition from week 2) the relation schema R are the k attributes of our database. That is, if R is our relational schema, and $$r_1, \ldots r_k$$ are the attributes, then $$R=\{ r_1, \ldots, r_k \} $$. This seems consistent with the definitions of super/candidate key

history.subject: Anomalies (Week 8)
history.content: What exactly is an anomaly? From what I understand, is it just a desired action that breaks the integrity of a (bad) schema? Like on slide 4 week 8, the deletion problem/anomaly is that we want to retain that Budd is a supplier even though he no longer sells screws in the schema instance.

Yeah sounds about right.

The insertion anomaly occurs when we are trying to insert something that should be easily insertable but we cannot because it needs more information. In this example, it's trying to add a new part that nobody sells yet. We can't do this because every part is in the same row as a supplier.

The deletion anomaly is as you say: Budd no longer sells screws, but to delete that row would be deleting Budd from the database entirely even though he still exists.

The change anomaly is when we want to update something, but because it's duplicated all over we have to change it more than once, such as the sname from the slides.

Yeah sounds about right.

The insertion anomaly occurs when we are trying to insert something that should be easily insertable but we cannot. In this example, it's trying to add a new part that nobody sells yet. We can't do this because every part is in the same row as a supplier.

The deletion anomaly is as you say: Budd no longer sells screws, but to delete that row would be deleting Budd from the database entirely even though he still exists.

The change anomaly is when we want to update something, but because it's duplicated all over we have to change it more than once, such as the sname from the slides.

history.subject: Why is it possible that no lossless join dependency preserving BCNF decomposition exists?
history.content: Why does the example on slide 27 of FD show that no lossless join dependency preserving BCNF decomposition exists?

For the example on slide 27, they are showing that there can exist a BCNF decomposition that is not dependency preserving. The schema mentioned has attributes {A, B, C} and FDs {AB->C, C->B} which would result in a BCNF decomposition of {C, B} and {A, C}. That decomposition can't be joined back in a way that will satisfy our original dependency AB->C, so that dependency is not 'preserved'. Since we are losing information about the original schema this way, this is undesirable.

Another way to think about it is to assign real names to the attributes like the textbook example. If you have a schema Advisor{instr_id, student_id, dept_name} with dependencies {student_id, dept_name -> instr_id; instr_id -> dept_name} and have a resulting decomposition of {instr_id, dept_name} and {student_id, instr_id} you lose the fact that each student can have a different advisor for each department. 

In general, BCNF can result in a decomposition that is dependency preserving, but it is not guaranteed (unlike 3NF which guarantees this).

Strict 2PL by the Textbook doesn't mean that you need full table locking, it only means that you must hold your exclusive locks all the way until the transaction commits. Therefore it is still tuple-locked and you can have concurrency.

history.subject: Q4 from unofficial A4
history.content:
Question 4 from: https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~gweddell/cs348/a4.pdf

I know T1, T3, T5 is committed before system failure, and others are aborted, but what should I do with these committed or aborted transactions?


Anyone has the solution for this question?

@380 describes the procedure for recovery.

Basically, go through the entire log in reverse, setting the values back to what they used to be. (start with "set A to 2", "set X to 400") and determine which parts were actually committed. Then repeat everything that was committed, and leave out the aborted stuff.

children.subject: I'm still a bit confused about this question. Do I literally go from (T$$_{6}$$,A,2,3) all the way to the beginning of the log, and just redo the entire thing without transactions from T$$_{2}$$, T$$_{4}$$, and T$$_{6}$$ since they never commit?
Yeah. Have to undo everything :P
So dont need to redo any transactions from T2, T4 and T6?
Yup, those are all lost. Only committed transactions must be redone

Ok nvm turns out you don't have to undo everything, just the uncommitted stuff. Thanks to whoever that was on the other thread hah. Then we redo the things that were committed.

In the end we have to undo all of T6 and T2 then redo all of T1 T3 and T5. 4 was successfully aborted, so I believe it can be ignored?
yeah it can

If anyone sees this before the exam - what's the state of A after (T6, A, 2, 3) after this log is complete, since it is neither aborted or committed? I guess it wouldn't impact the answer since it is undone but just curious.
One more - if (T4, 0, 1) occurs and then T4 aborts, should (T5, A, 0, 2) still happen or in the end is A = 0?

At this point we don't know what the state of A is. Before the system crash, it is most likely still 2, and has never yet been set to 3 (since there is no commit message yet), but this depends on the database implementation (some may write log entries and then update the database immediately after, while others will wait until the entire transaction is logged before updating the database).

When (T4, A, 0, 1) aborts, it is set back to 0. T5 comes along after, not caring about anything else, sees that A = 0, sets it to A = 2, then commits. A = 2 in the end.
@490 explains somewhat how to read a log if you are unsure of anything. You can try adding similar annotations to the A4 log if you like.
In this question, are the transactions aborted just T4? Or do we consider T2 and T6 aborted as well after recovery?
T4's abortion has been committed. T2 and T6 have no effect after the recovery is complete but they will not be part of the history (unlike T4).

history.subject: Sample Final ER diagram Q4
history.content:
For the following point:

Each patient has a number of billing records, with each billing record recording the medical procedure, the date on which the procedure was performed, the examining doctor and some additional comments on the part of the examining doctor.

Does this mean that the billing record entity must have a relationship with procedure and doctor? I am confused because procedure and doctor are attributes of the billing record table that are foreign keys, so it seems pointless to have a relationship since that would imply that we need relationship tables. Is this logic correct?

Remember that a relationship table may have attributes of its own, making it both a relationship and an entity.

Additionally, we can have more than two entities as part of a relationship. In this case, it sounds like we have 3 foreign keys (3 related entities) making up one billing record (patient + doctor + procedure) plus some extra attributes (date + comments).

Remember that a relationship table may have attributes of its own, making it both a relationship and an entity.

Additionally, we can have more than two entities as part of a relationship. In this case, it sounds like we have 3 entities making up one billing record (patient + doctor + procedure) plus some extra attributes (date + comments).

history.subject: Why is Dept a superkey here?
history.content: To be a lossless decomposition then the common attributes of R1 and R2 must be a superkey. So given F above, Dept must be a superkey. I guess you could say that transitivity implies that Dept -> Div is the same as Dept, Prof -> Div, Prof. But then can't you just use transitivity to argue that any key is a superkey lol
To be a lossless decomposition, the common attributes of R1 and R2 have to be a candidate of one of the two relationships. Since Dept is a candidate key of R2, this is lossless.

history.subject: 2PL
history.content:
I was reading the slide about strict 2PL, but not quite sure what it means by "held until committed"

Could anyone give me an example of what strict 2PL vs. 2PL?

Held until committed means that you don't release the lock until you have committed or aborted the transaction. Say I were reading from 3 tables, and then writing to one, at the end of the transaction I would still be holding the locks on all three of the tables, as well as a 4th lock for the table I was writing to. All 4 of these locks are then released at the very end.

To my understanding, 2PL does not require all locks are released at the end of the transaction (they can be released part way, but it still occurs in the two phases of "acquire all then release all") while Strict 2PL does not allow release until the commit/abort. We didn't talk too much about non-strict 2PL because Strict 2PL is the one that gives us the properties we need for guaranteed serializability

children.subject: why is strict 2PL essential for guaranteed serializability?

I think just because Strict 2PL is the easiest way to get such a guarantee.

By making sure that no-one can read any uncommitted data, we will always be able to just delay transactions since there will be no interweaving conflicts like the one on @418

history.subject: Isolation Level
history.content: What is the difference between level 2 and level 3 isolation level?

Level 3 you lock the entire table (i.e. no insert/delete)

Level 2 you lock tuples which mean insert/delete to a table can happen anytime. If you have a transaction counting tuples it may miscount.

history.subject: Pre-midterm: ER relationship types arrow
history.content:
I followed the examples on the slides to solve our assignment questions and stuff, but I'm still not 100% confident about where to point the arrows at:

What do the arrows mean? (ER slide 15) and

How do we know where to point the arrows at?

ex) Many-to-one:

EMPLOYEE -> <WorksIn> - Department

A line with no arrow is a "many" line, indicating that "a department can be worked in by many things".

An arrow means a "one" line, so "an employee can only work in one place".

For the example of the one to one relationship on the slides: Employee $$\rightarrow$$ Manages $$\leftarrow$$ Department

An employee can only manage one thing.

A department can only be managed by one person.

I find it helps to consider the meaning of each line/arrow separately, rather than the entire relationship at once. Don't say "many employees can work in one department" because then the line/arrow seems backwards.

As for direction of the arrows, you'll want to point them at the relationship, and away from the entity set. (You're putting employee information, like an ID, into the WorksIn table, not the other way around)

history.subject: What if we have an abort?
history.content:
in the question where it asks to list out a potential execution order of transactions, what happens if a transaction aborts? I would assume it releases all of the locks it is holding, but do the operations written for that transaction earlier go away?

Also, how does aborting affect serializability, can we just ignore all operations of that transaction when considering serializability?

In a log, the operations are still listed but they end with an ABORT log entry, meaning to just undo them all instead of persist it to the database. If asked to write them, you should probably write them and end with an abort as well (See the log on slide 18 of concurrent access). All the locks are released for sure, and the effects of the operations are reversed.

Aborting has some nasty effects on serialization.We can't just ignore it at the time of the operations being received because we don't yet know if it will be aborted or not.

This is discussed some on slide 8 of the concurrent access slides, but basically we do what we can to keep everything working, but sometimes aborting one transaction will require aborting a bunch of other transactions as well if they had been allowed to read from the transaction which was aborted (transactions may end up reading not quite committed data using the "conflict equivalence" scheduling idea).

I think this is why the 2PL thing exists. If we cannot read data that is not yet committed, we can abort easily. Sticking to the strict 2PL rules (isolation level 3) will always guarantee serializability, even with aborts.

In a log, the operations are still listed but they end with an ABORT log entry, meaning to just undo them all instead of persist it to the database. If asked to write them, you should probably write them and end with an abort as well (See the log on slide 18 of concurrent access). All the locks are released for sure, and the effects of the operations are reversed.

Aborting has some nasty effects on serialization.We can't just ignore it at the time of the operations being received because we don't yet know if it will be aborted or not.

This is discussed some on slide 8 of the concurrent access slides, but basically we do what we can to keep everything working, but sometimes aborting one transaction will require aborting a bunch of other transactions as well if they had been allowed to read from the transaction which was aborted (transactions may end up reading not quite committed data using the "conflict equivalence" scheduling idea).

I think this is why the 2PL thing exists. If we cannot read data that is not yet committed, we can abort easily. Sticking to the strict 2PL rules (isolation level 4) will always guarantee serializability, even with aborts.

history.subject: Why is this a deadlock?
history.content: How is w2[x] blocked by T1?

With table level (level 3) 2PL we take a shared lock when we read, and an exclusive lock when we write, but any lock is not released until the entire transaction ends.


Here, transaction 1 takes a shared lock on x, then transaction 2 takes the shared lock on y. Now when transaction 2 tries to write to x, it needs to take the exclusive lock, but since a shared lock is taken it cannot, so it blocks while holding the lock on y. Then transaction 1 comes trying to take the exclusive lock on y, cannot, and blocks holding the lock of x. Now neither one will ever release the lock, since they never reach the end of their transaction, so they will block forever.

With table level (level 4) 2PL we take a shared lock when we read, and an exclusive lock when we write, but any lock is not released until the entire transaction ends.


Here, transaction 1 takes a shared lock on x, then transaction 2 takes the shared lock on y. Now when transaction 2 tries to write to x, it needs to take the exclusive lock, but since a shared lock is taken it cannot, so it blocks while holding the lock on y. Then transaction 1 comes trying to take the exclusive lock on y, cannot, and blocks holding the lock of x. Now neither one will ever release the lock, since they never reach the end of their transaction, so they will block forever.

history.subject: What does this mean?
history.content:
F = { A -> B, B -> C }

Kinda confused what the arrow means exactly.. :S

The arrow means implication, as it does when it was taught in MATH135 or CS245.

In the case of functional dependencies, it signifies the actuall dependency itself: in $$ A\rightarrow B$$, B is dependent on A. This means that if $$A$$ has some value say $$a$$, and $$B$$ has some value $$b$$, then any row which has $$A=a$$, then we know for sure that $$B=b$$. This does not go the other way, however: two values of $$A$$ may correspond to the same $$B$$ value.

There's a lot more detail on this stuff in @372

history.subject: Week 9 slide 22
history.content:
The slide says

...All Equivalent Plans

- Cannot be done in general:
=> it is undecidable if a query (un-)satisfiable

equivalent to an empty plan.

I read it a couple times, but I don't get the meaning to this.

Did anyone understand this?

(This is about Query Optimization)

On the previous slide it describes the general approach to query optimization.

1. Generate all equivalent physical plans...

2. Pick the cheapest

The title of this slide you mention then is reacting to the "all equivalent plans" statement, because like !??!?! ALL THE PLANS?!?! That's a lot of plans

Generating all plans can't be done in general, because if a query is unsatisfiable (no results can ever match it) then there are no equivalent plans (since the plan is equivalent to the empty plan)

Even if we take that case out, it's very difficult even for conjunctive queries (conjunctive queries are the simplest remember, back from the relational calculus definitions). The join-ordering problem (what order do we do joins in to make it most efficient) is pretty difficult to solve. idk the details of this problem in particular, but I don't think we need to?

In practice, we just check a few of the obvious plans, skipping some really bad plans, and then pick the best from those. Might not always get the best of all possible plans, but it will generally be good enough.

(next slide)

How do we know which is the best plan? We can't just run every single one and check it right?!

Instead use the cost estimation methods, which are explained on further slides and on @416

history.subject: question 3 ture or false on sample final
history.content:
it is not possible to avoid the overhead of query optimization if one uses the dynamic embedded SQL standard.

Anyone know this one?

Haven't found anything explaining this, but I feel like it is not possible to avoid..? Optimization is likely going to be less time consuming than just running an unoptimized query...

On the other hand, if the dynamic SQL writer is very careful in writing their query, they may make a more efficient query on their own leaving less work to be done for the optimizer (but I think the optimizer will still run??).

Not sure though... email a prof if you want :P

children.subject:
I think it's false. Grant talked about this in class -- he asked whether you always have to pay the overhead of parsing, optimizing, etc. the query every time when using dynamic embedded SQL or JDBC/ODBC. He said the answer is no, because you could use prepared statements to precompile all the queries you're ever going to use when your app starts up, and then always use those (substituting different values for the question marks).

Technically there's still an overhead ... but it only happens once, instead of every time you execute the query. Also, if you can't enumerate all the possible query structures, and have to dynamically generate new queries all the time, then obviously you're paying an overhead. But I don't think the question was talking about that.

Yeah this makes sense as well. We would no longer have to pay the overhead for every query we make in this case, but it would still be included in the program at some time, however negligible, rather than at compile time so the user could never know.

I interpreted this as like, super dynamic though. Like we had a program that allowed users to construct queries and run them (similar to db2 command line program). In this case, as you mentioned, there's no prepared statement we could write, since the structure of statements will be completely unpredictable. Then it is impossible to avoid overhead.

As always the questions of this course are all up to interpretation...

history.subject: week 10 slide 29 (Cost of other Relational Operations)
history.content: I have difficulty understanding all of them, and I'm wondering if they are important enough for me to understand. If they indeed are, could somebody explain this to me? Thanks in advance.

history.subject: week 10 slide 29
history.content: I have difficulty understanding all of them, and I'm wondering if they are important enough for me to understand. If they indeed are, could somebody explain this to me? Thanks in advance.

Probably doesn't hurt to understand these...

All the time stuff is just estimating using some "time unit". See slide 24 for the basic facts we use to produce these estimates, but here's the idea:

  • The cost of retrieving a whole table, one tuple at a time, we can say is $$|R|$$.
  • The blocking factor $$b(R)$$ (or sometimes just $$b$$ for some implied $$R$$ on the slides) is in regards to the blocks that the data is stored in, physically, on the computer. Things like the actual files on the computer, and how they are broken up. When we retrieve multiple records at once because they lie within the same block we save time, and divide by this blocking factor. If we retrieve the table in blocks (which we will always try to do), we say it takes $$|R|/b(R)$$ time units.
    • Most things are dominated by the actual time it takes to read the files the data is in, rather than the "elementary operations" idea we are used to from CS240/CS341. This is why we end up with a lot of things being divided by the blocking factor.

Selection is the simplest operation beyond just taking the whole table. It takes just one time unit (to retrieve/return the tuple) + $$\epsilon_c$$ (the time to compute condition $$c$$). We multiply this by $$cost(E)$$ because we are looking for the cost of retrieving the entire table, rather than just one tuple, but $$1 + \epsilon_c$$ is the a per-tuple additional amount of time. Recall the implementation of selection, in what is hopefully an understandable pseudocode:

class Select(child: Operator, pred: (Tuple -> bool) ): Operator {
  // NOTE: `child` is like the E in the notation on the slides
  //   and `pred` is the predicate condition c
  fetch() -> Tuple {
    let t = child.fetch();
    if t == NULL || pred(t) {
      // the pred(t) takes `ϵ_c` time
      // while the act of passing through this function at all takes 1 unit of time
      return t; 
    } else {
      // recursively retry
      // this is invisible in the total cost because we'll end up calling this function again soon
      //    (this is one tuple remember, but `cost(T)` is for whole table's worth of fetching)
      return fetch();
    }
  }
}

Nested loop join, producing the cross join of two relations, will look something like this:

fn nested_loop_join(R: Operator, S: Operator) -> Tuple[] {
  let output = [];
  for(let i = 0; i < |R|; ++i) { 
    // eventually retrieves all of R, taking `cost(R)`
    let r = R.fetch();
    for(let j = 0; j < |S|; ++j) {
      // retrieves all of S, taking `cost(S)`.
      // then since it's in an inner loop, multiply by |R|
      // then divide by `b` because everything is dominated by the file reading time, rather than the actual loop time
      let s = S.fetch();
      output.push(Tuple(r, s));
    }
  }
  return output;
}

Sort-Merge or Merge-Sort (they called it both ways??) join is dominated by the cost of retrieving and then sorting the two relations, as actually joining two tuples is pretty easy. The cost of sorting is given there, but it is kind of how you'd expect: $$cost(E)$$ for reading in, then $$N\log(N)$$ where $$N = |E|/b$$ for sorting (again because it's mostly the time it took to read in the blocks instead of the time it took to process one record).

Hopefully this is enough to get some understanding of the cost estimation strategies. The slides continue to discuss size estimation, and then cost optimization, but I think if you understand this part you can figure that out?

children.subject: Is b=b(R) in the slides? For the nested loop join, I'm not sure why |R| is divided by b. Isn't |R|/b the cost of fetching R, which is accounted for in cost(R)?

Don't think they explicitly wrote $$b=b(R)$$ on the slides, but that is what I gathered from the math? As for why |R|/b, I am not completely sure either. I gave it my best shot above, which may be enough for the exam...

It is definitely separate from the cost(R) of retrieving R though. I think it's something to do with how blocking works with the for loop, we need to retrieve S a bunch of times.

Might be because my pseudo-implementation is not actually the way they would implement it for a real DBMS...

history.content:
1. Why is "Searching the CourseInd index has a cost of 2"? I read through this question on stackoverflow, and on the slides, there seems to be not enough details to determine the cost of locating a clustering index?

2. should not N/b(R) be ceil(N/b(R)) because N may not be divisible for b(R)?

history.subject: week 10 slide 26
history.content:
1. Why is "Searching the CourseInd index has a cost of 2"? I read through this question on stackoverflow, and on the slides, there seems to be not enough details to determine the cost of locating a clustering index?

2. should not N/b(R) be ceil(N/b(R)) because N may not be divisible for b(R)?

Any suggestions are appreciated.

1. Based of @416's stuff, you should be able to calculate this. A clustered index of 100 courses (say $$I_R$$) has $$|I_R|$$ keys. With a blocking factor $$b(I_R) = 50$$ (same as $$b(Mark)$$ since it's basically the same table), we get $$|I_R|/b(I_R) = 2$$ cost for searching the index. At least, I think that's how it goes. Seems legit enough?

2. $$\lceil N/b \rceil (R)$$ sounds more correct yes, but I think they're just being approximate here. Shouldn't need to worry too much about that...

children.subject: But the non-clustered index in slides 27 is also 2, I previously thought the search time for cluster+noncluster are fixed at 2...If your calculation for clustered index is correct, how will you get 2 for non-clustered index?

Would be the same calculation I think. The non-clustered index is still an index. Non-clustered just means that it's in a separate table so after searching the index we must still do another lookup.

That said, I'm still not completely sure if this is the right idea either. Searching an index should be $$O(\log n)$$ where $$n=|I_R|$$ (that is, the number of levels in the tree), so it may just be chance that that calculation I tried came out to 2 anyway...

This one may explain it: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4694574/database-indexes-and-their-big-o-notation

history.subject: Week 8 sl. 29
history.content: Can someone explain this to me??

1. is pretty straightforward I assume.

2. If there is some FD that we can remove from the set F, and still have the same $$F^+$$, then they are equivalent. Another way to think of it is that if we can derive one of the FDs in F using the rest of the FDs in F, we can remove it, so it is not minimal.

$$S_1 = \{ A\rightarrow B, A\rightarrow C, B\rightarrow C \} \equiv S_2 = \{ A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \}$$, so $$S_1$$ is not minimal ($$ A\rightarrow B, B\rightarrow C \implies A\rightarrow C$$ by transitivity), but $$S_2$$ is (since we've removed that).

3. There is no FD with an extra attribute on the left hand side.

$$ S_1 = \{ A \rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow C \} \equiv S_2 = \{ A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \} $$. Similar to above $$ A\rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \implies AB \rightarrow C$$, so $$S_1$$ is not minimal, while $$S_2$$ is

history.subject: BCNF and 3NF
history.content: Would be eternally grateful if I could get some more example or explanation on these two. The course slides are not very detailed (or I'm just dumb) and I am having trouble understanding these two things. Thank you.

children.subject: "Every non-prime attribute must give you a fact about the key, the whole key, and nothing but the key, so help me Codd"

history.content:
This page explains them all pretty well I think: http://www.studytonight.com/dbms/database-normalization.php

3NF and BCNF are basically just restrictions on how you use primary keys. A table in 3NF must have only one "determining key". From the example on that page, the zip code determines the address stuff, while the student number determines the student related data, so they must be broken.

BCNF is a further restriction of 3NF, which says that every attribute must depend on a whole key. If there is some subset of a candidate key that is determined by the rest of the candidate key, then we don't have BCNF.

This guy explains it with pizza, and second answer is also very good: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8437957/difference-between-3nf-and-bcnf-in-simple-terms-must-be-able-to-explain-to-an-8

children.subject: So that 3rd NF is not BCNF because Zip depends on Student_id? Am I right?

We have the FDs $$\{ [StudentID \rightarrow Name,DOB,Zip], [Zip\rightarrow Street, City, State] \}$$, so that one is actually BCNF as well. Each student has an address, keyed by Zip, so this is alright.

history.subject: is there an efficient way to determine if a schedule is serializable?
history.content: does computing a graph count as efficient?

I believe that is how you are supposed to do it. The textbook also suggests creating a graph. 

----------

I guess you create a graph, with transaction numbers as vertices. There is an edge from T1 to T2 iff T2 depends on T1 (for some definition of "depends" which even I am not so clear about). Then run a topological sort to check if the graph is a DAG. If it is, then the schedule is serializable. If not, then its not.
I believe that is how you are supposed to do it. The textbook also suggests creating a graph.

children.subject: Ya, that is the method I read in the textbook? but is it considered efficient? is creating a graph and running topological order consider efficient?

If it wasn't efficient, why would it be mentioned in the textbook? Topological sort is linear in the number of vertices and edges. Graph construction should not take a ridiculous amount of time as well.

Topological sort is a accomplished through a depth first search, which is $$O(|V| + |E|)$$, aka linear time. That is considered efficient in this case, and indeed any linear time algorithm on a graph is usually considered to be efficient.

history.subject: how do exclusive locks work?
history.content:
My understanding is that if a transaction holds an exclusive lock on table A, then no other transaction can hold a shared lock or exclusive lock on same table A.

If that is the case then how is this possible?

If a transaction has a exclusive lock on that tuple, then how can any other transaction read from that tuple?

I believe it is referring to having a lock for every row in your table.

Level 3 locks a whole table so that you have full control of that table and everything will be very predictable.

Level 2 locks every tuple that is read, and only releases them when you have finished reading everything (close the cursor or something). This ensures that if you read a tuple again the second time, it will still be the same. It doesn't lock the table though, so other transactions may still create new records/delete records you haven't looked at yet,.

Level 1 locks a tuple, reads it, and then unlocks it. This means that if you go and re-read that tuple, it may have been changed by someone else since the last time. It uses the locks just to ensure that the data is in fact committed already by the time you read it.

Level 0 just doesn't check any locks, so it can read everything, even if it's not committed.

children.subject: So does level 3 essentially allow a transaction to perform all of its writes and reads for a table and commit before releasing the locks?
Yes
Thanks :) also one more question. For level 3 other transactions cannot read a table until another transaction that acquired the locks first releases them is that right?
Read locks are shared, so two transactions who are only reading a table can both access it at the same time. If either of them has to write though then they'll have to wait.

history.subject: Sample Final - Number of candidate keys
history.content:
The question:

Given a set of attributes $$R$$ and a set of functional dependencies $$F$$ over those
attributes, the number of candidate keys on R is $$O(|F|^{k})$$, where $$k$$ is some constant
and where $$|F|$$ is the number of occurrences of attributes in $$F$$

I'm not really sure about this one. My thought is that the number of potential candidate keys the number of subsets of attributes, which would be $$2^{|F|}$$ and not some polynomial, but I'm wondering if there's some relation to $$F$$ that I am missing. Hope someone can clarify, thank you.

This was discussed in @325

There are $$2^{|R|}$$ possible superkeys in a relation, and at most $$\binom{n}{|R|}$$ candidate keys, where n is chosen to maximize the number.

Don't remember them discussing a fact exactly like this question, bringing in the FDs, in class... but I'll keep thinking about it or maybe someone will figure it out.

This was discussed in @325

There are $$2^{|R|}$$ possible superkeys in a relation, and at most $$\binom{n}{|R|}$$ candidate keys, where n is chosen to maximize the number.

This was discussed in @325

There are $$2^{|F|}$$ possible superkeys in a relation, and at most $$\binom{n}{|F|}$$ candidate keys, where n is chosen to maximize the number.

This was discussed in @325

There are $$2^|F|$$ possible superkeys in a relation, and at most $$\binom{n}{|F|}$$ candidate keys, where n is chosen to maximize the number.

children.subject:
I believe to get a candidate key, we can do the following:

1. Start off with X = set of all attributes in R

2. Let X' = X - y for some value y in X.

3. Call computeX'+(X', F). If X'+ contains y, then y is not a part of the candidate key for R.

4. Repeat until we cannot remove anymore attributes from X' and the result is a candidate key for R.

Now the complexity of this algorithm is:

- computeX'+ requires us to iterate through F. So it's O(|F|).

- We need to go though this at most |X| times. So let k = |X| and we get O(|F|^k) for the complexity of this algorithm

history.subject: Losing expressiveness
history.content: Can someone give me a quick rundown on what Prof. Wedell said about losing expressiveness by limiting the number of attributes on either side of an FD?

I wasn't there, but I'm pretty sure that:

  • You lose no expressiveness by restricting the RHS to contain only 1 attribute. You can always replace X->YZ by X->Y and X->Z. This is one of the things that is required in a minimal cover.
  • You do lose expressiveness by restricting the number of attributes in the LHS. It is impossible to express XY->Z with FDs having only one attribute in the LHS, or XYZ->W with ones that have only 2 attributes in the LHS.

children.subject: What does it mean to "lose expressiveness"? change the meaning of original dependency?
If you lose expressiveness by restricting the form of the FDs, that means that not all functional dependency sets F can be rewritten to an equivalent set F' restricted in that way.
Great answer! thanks

history.subject: Equivalence of closures
history.content:
Any hint on how we can prove equivalence of closures of FD. I know that two FD's are equal if their closures are the same, but how do we take it a step further? I have a feeling its something to do with Minimal Covers but can't say conclusively.

Thanks!

I think you don't want to prove equivalence of closures, but rather prove equivalence of the bases.

If all the FDs in $$F$$ can be derived using the FDs in $$G$$, and all the FDs in $$G$$ can be derived by the FDs in $$F$$, then the two sets are equivalent, and so will be their closures.

http://www.exploredatabase.com/2016/02/how-to-prove-that-two-sets-of-functional-dependencies-are-equal.html

If we are told what he primary keys are, then we should be able to compute enough of the FDs (The primary key implies the rest of its table).

If we are given some data, we can technically compute what functional dependencies are currently present, but we couldn't say whether those functional dependencies will all still hold in every instance of the database.

If they were to ask for that, I think they are most likely to give us the actual functional dependencies, and the schema listed as a bunch of sets similar to on the slides. This is a good question to bring to the questions lecture tomorrow though...

history.subject: Week 8 Slide 11
history.content: Does anybody know what the set F is supposed to be / what it contains? I don't entirely get what point of these F and F+ sets are supposed to be.

$$F$$ is the set of functional dependencies that make up the database, while $$F^+$$ is the set of all functional dependencies that are implied by $$F$$. Where $$F = \{ A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \} $$, then by transitivity we know that $$A\rightarrow C$$. Thus since $$F$$ implies $$ A\rightarrow C$$, then $$A \rightarrow C \in F^+$$.

The point of $$F$$ is that we can use it to define a database, while $$F^+$$ is used to define and compute the normal forms.

If you recall what a basis is (from MATH135 or 136 or whatever, in first year) then you can think of $$F$$ as a basis for $$F^+$$.

children.subject: Brilliant analogy! :)

history.subject: Week 8, Slide 31
history.content: Could someone explain the algorithm in slide 31 from week 8?

It starts with empty result, and assumes we are able to find a minimal cover. I think they mean the kind of minimal cover after step 4 of the previous slide, where we have merged together all the things with the same left side into one larger bunch.

Lets go with $$R = \{ A, B, C, D, E \}$$ and $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \}$$

Find a minimal cover of F using the steps on slide 30:

Step 1: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 2: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 3: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, A \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 4: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow BD, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Then we construct $$Result$$, by adding $$XY$$ for each $$X\rightarrow Y$$. Basically just turn each dependency into a table:

$$ Result = \{ ABD, CE \} $$

Finally, the part about no candidate keys. If there is no candidate key for R in our Result, we just add a table that is a candidate key. This ensures that no dependencies are lost. In this case, we need to add $$AC$$.

$$ Result = \{ ABD, CE, AC \} $$

I tried to get some FDs that made each step relevant, but turns out its pretty hard. That much will at least explain the algorithm, but if interested in why we need the last step, this guy explains everything better than me, so no point in just repeating everything: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44142492/3nf-normalization-algorithm-step-relation-with-superkey

It starts with empty result, and assumes we are able to find a minimal cover. I think they mean the kind of minimal cover after step 4 of the previous slide, where we have merged together all the things with the same left side into one larger bunch.

Lets go with $$R = \{ A, B, C, D, E \}$$ and $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \}$$

Find a minimal cover of F using the steps on slide 30:

Step 1: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 2: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, AB \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 2: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, B \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Step 4: $$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, B \rightarrow D, C \rightarrow E \} $$

Then we construct $$Result$$, by adding $$XY$$ for each $$X\rightarrow Y$$. Basically just turn each dependency into a table:

$$ Result = \{ AB, BD, CE \} $$

Finally, the part about no candidate keys. If there is no candidate key for R in our Result, we just add a table that is a candidate key. This ensures that no dependencies are lost. In this case, we need to add $$AC$$.

$$ Result = \{ AB, BD, CE, AC \} $$

I tried to get some FDs that made each step relevant, but turns out its pretty hard. That much will at least explain the algorithm, but if interested in why we need the last step, this guy explains everything better than me, so no point in just repeating everything: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44142492/3nf-normalization-algorithm-step-relation-with-superkey

children.subject: Shouldn't Step 2(3) of the minimal cover be A->D rather than B->D?

No, How would you get D if your F looks like

F={A→B,A→D,C→E}

Contrast this with 

F = F={A→B,B→D,C→E} which is equivalent to F={A→B,AB→D,C→E}
^ oops, you can still get D. I think either of them is fine in this case.

I think the algorithm for step 3 wants us to use F = {A→B,AB→D,C→E} to check if 

D is in computeX+(X - A, F) where X = {AB}. In computeX+({B}, F), X+ = {B}. 

Where as in computeX+(X-B,F), X+ = {A,B,D}.
Ahh true, you're right.

I have the same question for step 3. I think it should be F={A→B,A→D,C→E} 

calculate ComputeX + (AB − {B}, F ) =  ComputeX + (A, F ) = {A,B,D} with F = {A→B,AB→D,C→E}
Yeah this is right. I'll update the thing. Good catch.

How did you choose candidate keys in the last step when we add AC to Result? Is it because in the minimal cover for F, both A and C are on the left hand side of the FD so together they must be the minimal superkeys?
Based on the FDs in F, we can determine that $$AC \rightarrow ABCDE$$ (by the union rule), so AC is a candidate key.

history.content:

history.subject: Week 10 - Iterator Model
history.content:
Not sure what's the point of the iterator model

1. How does this solve storing intermediate results? If we're using the same idea as a cursor, shouldn't the temporary results (relations) be stored and then operated on?

2. Can someone explain me what the psuedocode on slide 13 is doing? In particular what do ints i0, j0 represent? Why do we stop when t.attr(i) = t.attr(j) ?

Thanks

I'll start with the second question, because I think this helps explain the first part:

The pseudocode is a class definition implementing one variation of the select operator from the relational algebra, which takes two columns and returns all tuples in which those two columns are equal:

  1. The constructor takes the three parameters, where c is the subquery, and i0 and j0 are the attributes to compare.
  2. The open function doesn't need to do anything (no extra initialization is necessary) so just open the child operator. Same thing for close
  3. The fetch is the main thing, which actually retrieves the data. It does this by first fetching something that matched the child (subquery). If that item satisfies this operator's condition (the ith attribute equals the jth attribute) , then we can return that item. If it doesn't skip it and fetch the next item.

Kind of helps to try working through an example using that class. Imagine we had named the stuff from the slides SelectWhere, and we had some implementation of SelectAllFromTable, for which the fetch method just returned the next item until there were no more items.

Here's some data

Table
A     | B
------|------
1     | 2
2     | 2
3     | 2
4     | 2

And then we run the code (using strings for attributes because its nicer):

OPERATOR query = SelectWhere(SelectAllFromTable("Table"), "A", "B");
query.open();
tuple x;
while((x = query.fetch()) != NULL) {
  printf("%d, %d", x.attr("A"), x.attr("B"))
}
query.close()

Then it would just print 2, 2. Try stepping through what would happen and it should be pretty clear.

Then for your first question, think of how this would go if we took in the entire table at once, rather than iterating over it. The implementations would look something like below:

class SelectAllFromTable {
  tuple[] all_data;
  void open() {
    all_data = // ... get it from the database, but this is a large array now
  }
  tuple[] fetch() {
    return all_data;
  }
}

class SelectWhere {
  int i, j; // the attributes to select
  OPERATOR child; // the subquery
  // ...
  tuple[] fetch() {
    tuple[] all_data = child.fetch();
    tuple[] good_data;
    for(int k = 0; k < all_data.length(); k++) {
      if(all_data[k].attr(i) == all_data[k].attr(j)) {
        good_data.push(all_data[k]);
      }
    }
    return good_data;
  }
}

The problem here is that we have to keep the entire database in memory, copied to each operator as they compute which values to return, rather than just figuring out one value at a time as in the iterated version from the slides.

children.subject:
Thanks a lot Cameron.

It's not entirely clear to me how fetch is retrieving the next tuple in the table looking at the code in the slides.
And also, is the fetch in the slides implemented recursively?

Fetch from the slides is recursive yes.

Say we have some database like this:

Users
UserID | Username | Password
-------|----------|---------
1      | David    | Database
2      | Grant    | Weddell

Then we have this statement from the relational algebra: $$ \sigma_{\#1=\#2}(Users)$$. Basically SELECT * from Users where UserID = Username. In hindsight, this is a terrible example, but it will do. Just pretend it makes sense.

Relating this to the code from the slides, i0 = 1, j0 = 2, and the child relation c is Users. The child relation is intentionally abstract, so that we can represent any arbitrarily nested relational algebra statements as some instances of classes similar to the one from the slides.

The fetch method then calls fetch on its child. In this case, we just have Users, which you can assume returns the first tuple from the Users table. This is implemented elsewhere, and not something we have to worry about.

Then it checks the condition, which is that attr(#i) = attr(#j). Changing the condition here would implement a different operator, but in this case it's just "select where equal".

If they are in fact equal this tuple satisfies the operator, so we can return this tuple.

If they are not equal, recursively fetch again. We fetch from the child table again, check if this new tuple matches the operator, repeating until we find one, or return NULL to signal the end of the table.

history.subject: Week 8, Slide 27
history.content: Why? (pls explain each point, a little lost here)

So this slide is discussing algorithms to compute a lossless-join BCNF decomposition.

  • No efficient procedure to do this exists

So there's that algorithm on the previous slide, but the condition of that while look is real vague (See @377 if confused about the algorithm).

At every step we would have to check every FD in $$F^+$$ across the entire database, which is not really an efficient procedure.

  • Results depend on sequence of FDs used to decompose the relations

The order we check the FDs in might lead to a different decomposition. Not sure how great of an example this is, but maybe gets the idea:

Take $$R = \{ A, B, C \} , F^+ = \{ A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C, A \rightarrow C \} $$.

Choose $$ A\rightarrow B$$, then we get to $$ Result = \{ \{ A, C \}, \{ A, B \}\} $$, and all the FDs are good.

But say we start again and choose $$B \rightarrow C$$, then we end up with $$ Result = \{ \{ A, B \}, \{ B, C \} \} $$, which is also correct, and also in BCNF.

  • It is possible that no lossless join dependency preserving BCNF decomposition exists...

Some data cannot be decomposed while satisfying BCNF. See this by stepping through the example provided using the algorithm:

$$ Result = \{ \{ A, B, C \} \} , F = \{ AB \rightarrow C, C \rightarrow B \} $$

Choose $$AB \rightarrow C$$, and notice that everything is ok.

Choose $$ C \rightarrow B $$. This violates the BCNF constraint ( C is not a superkey of $$R = \{ A, B, C \}$$ ), so we replace it:

$$ Result = \{ \{ A, C \}, \{ C, B \} \} , F = \{ AB \rightarrow C, C \rightarrow B \} $$

But now we have $$\{ A, C \} $$ as a table, but there is no functional dependency there. It's a table with no primary key, and so this is not a lossless join.

So this slide is discussing algorithms to compute a lossless-join BCNF decomposition.

  • No efficient procedure to do this exists

So there's that algorithm on the previous slide, but the condition of that while look is real vague (See @377 if confused about the algorithm).

At every step we would have to check every FD in $$F^+$$ across the entire database, which is not really an efficient procedure.

  • Results depend on sequence of FDs used to decompose the relations

The order we check the FDs in might lead to a different decomposition. Not sure how great of an example this is, but maybe gets the idea:

Take $$R = \{ A, B, C \} , F^+ = \{ A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C, A \rightarrow C \} $$.

Choose $$ A\rightarrow B$$, then we get to $$ Result = \{ \{ A, C \}, \{ A, B \}\} $$, and all the FDs are good.

But say we start again and choose $$B \rightarrow C$$, then we end up with $$ Result = \{ \{ A, B \}, \{ B, C \} \} $$, which is also correct, and also in BCNF.

  • It is possible that no lossless join dependency preserving BCNF decomposition exists...

Some data cannot be decomposed while satisfying BCNF. See this by stepping through the example provided using the algorithm:

$$ Result = \{ \{ A, B, C \} \} , F = \{ AB \rightarrow C, C \rightarrow B \} $$

Choose $$AB \rightarrow C$$, and notice that everything is ok.

Choose $$ C \rightarrow B $$. This violates the BCNF constraint ( C is not a superkey of $$R = \{ A, B, C \}$$ ), so we replace it:

$$ Result = \{ \{ A, C \}, \{ C, B \} \} , F = \{ AB \rightarrow C, C \rightarrow B \} $$

But now we have $$\{ A, C \} $$ as a table, but there is no functional dependency there. It's a table with no primary key, and so this is not a lossless join.

Have you read and understood the algorithm used to compute the BCNF decomposition on @377? This is just a result of applying that algorithm.

"But say we start again and choose B→C, then we end up with Result={{A,B},{B,C}}, which is also correct, and also in BCNF."

I don't understand why it is in BCNF.  B is not a superkey of R?

I think you misunderstand the meaning of R from the definition. The definition discusses a single relation (table) R, and whether it is, by itself, in BCNF. When going to a whole relation schema (database), we simply require that all the relations that make up the schema are also in BCNF.

Notice that "Result" from the algorithm is a relation schema, while each element $$R_i \in Result$$ is an individual relation.

A is a superkey of R1 = AB, so the relationship AB is in BCNF.

B is a superkey of R2 = BC, so the relationship BC is in BCNF.

Since both relations R1 and R2 are in BCNF, R = { AB, BC } is in BCNF.

yo dude cameron,

quick question, why is the answer {AC, AB} not a lossless join? (can u explain your last line a little more; why is A not a primary key)

Thanks!
Now that I look back at this, it seems maybe it is still lossless, just not BCNF because of the definition of BCNF.

history.subject: Why is co-clustering useful for storing hierarchical data?

history.content:
Co clustering is kind of like storing two separate tables as a joined table, both ordered by the same thing. The Courses $$\rightarrow$$ Enrolments of the first assignment is a good example of something that could be co-clustered efficiently.

Say we have data like this:

Courses                 Enrolment
CNum  | CName           CNum  | SNum
------|-------          ------|-----
CS348 | Database        CS348 | 100
CS135 | Racket          CS348 | 200
                        CS135 | 200
                        CS348 | 300
                        CS135 | 100

Enrolments can be thought of as belonging to courses, so this is hierarchical. If we index these two tables separately by CNum, we'll end up with something like this:

Courses                 Enrolment
CNum  | CName           CNum  | SNum
------|-------          ------|-----
CS348 | Database        CS348 | 100
CS135 | Racket          CS348 | 200
                        CS348 | 300
                        CS135 | 100
                        CS135 | 200

If we had this coclustered, then for the physical arrangement of this data, we would end up with one file, which you can imagine as something like this:

CS348, Database, 100
CS348, Database, 200
CS348, Database, 300
CS135, Racket,   100
CS135, Racket,   200

Both tables pre-joined, clustered by the same CNum, and it naturally makes a lot of sense. Queries like "find all students who know Racket" can be made now pretty easily, since it doesn't actually need to do a join and search two tables, we can just search the one time. The common usage of hierarchical data benefits from this layout greatly.

If we had some non-hierarchical data that we co-clustered, the layout would be similar, but the meaning of the relationship is less present in the physical data, and it doesn't as obviously provide the same utility for queries as it does in this case.

history.subject: what exactly is a physical query plan?

history.content:
The query plan is the steps that will be taken to compute the result of your query.

Say we had a list of 1000 names and you wanted to find mine, then there are a few plans that exist, the most obvious being:

  1. Scan the list in order until you find it
  2. Sort the list and do a binary search

For the database though, the plan will be much more complicated as both the queries and the data structures involved are much more complex.

The query optimizer should be able to figure out what the best plan is, taking into account your indexes, the joins required, and (maybe) equivalent queries that would be easier to compute. It won't always get the cheapest, but it can usually come close. This plan is visible by using the db2expln tools, as shown on the slides.

The reason the query optimizer exists is because there are multiple implementations of each query, and that we want the cheapest plan. The reason the plan exists though is kind of just... that it exists... We couldn't get any data if no plans existed.

history.subject: LOGGING
history.content:
Can someone give me a brief refresher on why we do a backward and forward pass on the LOG file when restoring the database? I had it figured in class but didn't write it down :/

Thanks!

The backwards pass is first, where we undo all the uncommitted actions, up to some point where we know the database was valid.

Then we do the forward pass, when we redo all the things that were committed. This is to bring the database back to the state where it should be, at which point it must also be valid because the last full commit was successful.

The things that were not committed yet (transactions started, but not finished) are lost, since we just undid them and don't know how to finish them.

Found a powerpoint online which is much better than the one we have for this. Lots of extra stuff but seems to be legit: https://www.cs.duke.edu/courses/fall11/cps216/Lectures/notes10_small.ppt

The backwards pass is first, where we undo all the actions, up to some point where we know the database was valid. This includes both the uncommitted actions and the committed actions because we don't know how far the database got into actually performing the writes when it crashed. We may have some uncommitted actions in the database because of the undo rule, and we might have some <commit> entries in our log that have not actually been executed because of the redo rule.

Then we do the forward pass, when we redo all the things we just undid, up to the last commit. This is to bring the database back to the state where it should be, at which point it must also be valid because the last full commit was successful.

The things that were not committed yet (transactions started, but not finished) are lost, I guess, since we don't know how to finish them.

Found a powerpoint online which is much better than the one we have for this. Lots of extra stuff but seems to be legit: https://www.cs.duke.edu/courses/fall11/cps216/Lectures/notes10_small.ppt

children.subject: Doesn't the powerpoint say to only undo the transactions that have no commit/abort and then redo only the transactions that have committed?
Oh yeah that makes a lot more sense...

Let's T1 changes A from 0 to 1, and it's aborted, then db crashed. 

[at this state, db should have A as 0 right]?

Then after db is recovered, should A be 0 or 1?
In any case here, the correct value for A would be 0 (since whether or not we actually manage to execute everything as planned, we abort the T1 and revert A to 0)
Why do we need to undo the uncommitted if they already don't exist after restart the system? since they were never committed to make the change...?

I think this is dependent on the database system. It is still allowed to write the change immediately after its log entry is recorded, even if the commit message hasn't come yet, and be ready to undo it later. As an onlooker we do not know anything about the implementation so to ensure that we have a consistent database we have to do every step of the recovery process.

history.subject: Week 8 slide 15
history.content:
Could someone explain what this algorithm is doing?

I am confused about what X^+ stands for.

$$F$$ is the set of functional dependencies that are explicitly part of the data.

Elements of this set take the form $$X\rightarrow Y$$, where X is (usually) a primary key, and Y is some set of attributes that are implied by X (often the rest of the table).

$$X^+$$ is the set of all attributes that are implied by $$X$$ given $$F$$. That is, $$X\rightarrow X^+$$, and there's nothing more we could add to $$X^+$$ to keep this statement true.

The algorithm starts with Armstrong axiom #1. Since $$X\subseteq X^+$$, start with $$X^+ := X$$.

Then use Armstrong axiom #3 repeatedly (in that loop) to determine what other attributes are implied by $$X$$.

Eventually we get all the things in $$X^+$$.

Armstrong's second axiom is irrelevant here.

children.subject: Shouldn't Armstrong axiom #1 be the opposite? X is a subset of X+
Yup, that's a typo

Just a follow up:

Why exactly are we calculating X+ here? Why not just calculate F+?

$$F^+$$ is the full set of all existing functional dependencies, while $$X^+$$ is just a set of all attributes that are derived by $$X$$. Though related, they are different outputs, and each have their own uses.
I am still a little lost. Could someone please give an example that runs along this algorithm?

$$F = \{ A\rightarrow B, B\rightarrow C, B \rightarrow D, AB \rightarrow E, BC \rightarrow F \}, X=\{ B \} $$

Step 1: $$X^+=\{ B \} $$

Enter loop:

If (...) finds $$B \rightarrow C$$, so we set $$X^+=\{ B \} \cup \{ C \}$$

If (...) finds $$B \rightarrow D$$, so we set $$X^+=\{ B, C \} \cup \{ D \}$$

If (...) finds $$BC \rightarrow F$$, so we set $$X^+=\{ B, C, D \} \cup \{ F \}$$

If (...) finds nothing, so exit

Return $$X^+=\{ B, C, D, F \}$$, which are all the attributes implied by $$B$$.

We can now conclude that $$B\rightarrow BCDF \in F^+$$
Where does this X attribute set come from? It seems kinda of arbitrary.
Yeah it is completely arbitrary. It's just some argument to the function. Pick any X you want and this function will compute the $$X^+$$ for that X.

So wait, if $$X = $$ set of all attributes of R, and run ComputeX+(X,F), it should give me $$F+$$ right?

And how does this help us figure out if a FD is implied by F quickly? So if we want to test for example if $$ B --> CD $$ is a valid FD, we would set X = B and run the algo right?

If you run ComputeX+(R, F) you will just get back R again (since trivially $$R \rightarrow R$$). $$X^+$$ is just a bunch attributes, not functional dependencies.

For figuring out if $$B \rightarrow CD$$ was implied by F quickly, we would run ComputeX+(B, F) and check if the output set contains C and D, yes.
In the example given, shouldn't X+ initially be {B,C} instead of just {B} ? [(B->C) is part of F]

X is the parameter to the function, and the first step of the function is $$X^+:=X$$, so I'd say we set $$X^+$$ to $${B}$$ first. Adding C to $$X^+$$ occurs in the loop, once we start looking at the FDs.

history.subject: BCNF
history.content: Hi, Could anyone explain what is meaning of R_i - (Y - X) please??

So $$R$$ is the database schema (a set of individual attributes (columns), $$R=\{ R_1, \ldots R_n \}$$).

Note that $$Result$$ is a set of sets. A list of tables.

Say we have some database like the one on the slides:

Sno | Sname | City | Ino | Iname | Price
----|-------|------|-----|-------|------

Then $$ R = \{ Sno, Sname, City, Ino, Iname, Price \} $$, and $$ Result = \{ R \} $$ (so $$R_1 = R$$. Maybe think of $$R_i$$ as $$Result[i]$$).

Given some functional dependency of this table then, say $$ Sno \rightarrow Sname, City $$, we'll "replace $$ R_i $$ by $$R_i - (Y - X)$$":

$$Y=\{ Sname, City \} \\ X=\{ Sno \} \\ (Y-X)=\{ Sname, City \} \\ R =\{ Sno, Sname, City, Ino, Iname, Price \} \\ R - (Y - X) = \{ Sno, Ino, Iname, Price \} $$

Then once we add $$\{ X, Y \} = \{ Sno, Sname, City \} $$ to $$Result$$ (with the modified $$R_i$$), then we have:

$$Result = \{ \{ Sno, Ino, Iname, Price \}, \{ Sno, Sname, City \} \} $$.

The single giant mega table with all the attributes has now been broken up into two smaller tables. Keep repeating this and you'll end up with the BCNF form of the database.

Why does the $$R_i = R_i - (Y - X)$$ have to subtract X, you ask? In this example, $$X\cap Y$$ was empty, but I guess maybe that's not always the case? We're checking all functional dependencies in $$F^+$$ remember, and technically, if $$X\rightarrow Y$$, then $$X \rightarrow X, Y$$, so to avoid this causing problems we have to do that $$(Y-X)$$ step.

So $$R$$ is the database schema (a set of individual attributes (columns), $$R=\{ R_1, \ldots R_n \}$$).

Note that $$Result$$ is a set of sets. A list of tables.

Say we have some database like the one on the slides:

Sno | Sname | City | Ino | Iname | Price
----|-------|------|-----|-------|------

Then $$ R = \{ Sno, Sname, City, Ino, Iname, Price \} $$, and $$ Result = \{ R \} $$ (so $$R_1 = R$$. Maybe think of $$R_i$$ as $$Result_i$$).

Given some functional dependency of this table then, say $$ Sno \rightarrow Sname, City $$, we'll "replace $$ R_i $$ by $$R_i - (Y - X)$$":

$$Y=\{ Sname, City \} \\ X=\{ Sno \} \\ (Y-X)=\{ Sname, City \} \\ R =\{ Sno, Sname, City, Ino, Iname, Price \} \\ R - (Y - X) = \{ Sno, Ino, Iname, Price \} $$

Then once we add $$\{ X, Y \} = \{ Sno, Sname, City \} $$ to $$Result$$ (with the modified $$R_i$$), then we have:

$$Result = \{ \{ Sno, Ino, Iname, Price \}, \{ Sno, Sname, City \} \} $$.

The single giant mega table with all the attributes has now been broken up into two smaller tables. Keep repeating this and you'll end up with the BCNF form of the database.

Why does the $$R_i = R_i - (Y - X)$$ have to subtract X, you ask? In this example, $$X\cap Y$$ was empty, but I guess maybe that's not always the case? We're checking all functional dependencies in $$F^+$$ remember, and technically, if $$X\rightarrow Y$$, then $$X \rightarrow X, Y$$, so to avoid this causing problems we have to do that $$(Y-X)$$ step.

history.subject: Functional Dependency Definition
history.content:
Given the functional dependency example in the slides

how would you formally define the SIN -> ENAME dependency formally (i.e using the definition above)

children.subject: bad question
eat shit
wow :(

history.content:
The definition defines the term, but that long logical statement is just a definition of the term. You can't use it to define the $$ SIN \rightarrow ENAME $$ dependency because there are an (theoretically) infinite number of valuations for X and Y, and that statement asks for all valuations.

Instead, you can explain the definition using $$ SIN \rightarrow ENAME $$ as an example.

R is the set of all the attributes, and X and Y are subsets of that, X being all the attributes on the left of the arrow, and Y all the attributes on the right:

$$X = \{ \texttt{SIN} \} \\Y = \{ \texttt{ENAME} \} \\$$

So now we have to use that expression:

$$ \displaystyle \forall v_1, \ldots, v_k, w_1,\ldots,w_k. (R\langle v_1, \ldots, v_k\rangle \wedge R\langle w_1, \ldots w_k \rangle \wedge \left(\bigwedge_{i\in X} v_i = w_i \right) \rightarrow \left(\bigwedge_{j \in Y} v_j = w_j\right) $$

So what does this actually say:

  1. For every possible valuation of our database: $$ \{ v_1, \ldots, v_k \} $$, $$ R\langle v_1, \ldots, v_k\rangle $$
  2. And every other valuation of our database: $$ \{ w_1, \ldots, w_k \} $$, $$R\langle w_1, \ldots, w_k\rangle $$
  3. If all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{i\in X} v_i = w_i $$
  4. Then all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{j \in Y} v_j = w_j $$

Or summarized in more normal words, for a given set of values for X, Y will always be the same. Consider this database:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|---------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This is ok. For every value of SIN, it always has the same ENAME

What about this:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|--------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 123 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This one is no good anymore, since the SIN "123" has two associated ENAME ("David" and "Grant"). It can no longer be considered a function.

Now this one?

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | Grant
3    | 123 | David

This is ok. For all the values of SIN, the ENAME is the same every time.

And the last possibility:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | David
3    | 789 | David

Here the names are repeated, but since we still follow the "for every SIN, the ENAME is always the same" rule, then this is still a functional dependency.

For those who think best in code (if there are any of you out there), then if you could write a function (a pure function, so think like in Racket or something with no side effects) that takes SIN as input and outputs the right ENAME according to the database, then there exists a functional dependency:

(define (SIN->ENAME sin)
  (case
    [(= sin 123) ("David")]
    [(= sin 456) ("Grant")]
    [else (error "No such SIN number")]))

The definition defines the term, but that long logical statement is just a definition of the term. You can't use it to define the $$ SIN \rightarrow ENAME $$ dependency because there are an (theoretically) infinite number of valuations for X and Y, and that statement asks for all valuations.

Instead, you can explain the definition using $$ SIN \rightarrow ENAME $$ as an example.

R is the set of all the attributes, and X and Y are subsets of that, X being all the attributes on the left of the arrow, and Y all the attributes on the right:

$$X = \{ \texttt{SIN} \} \\Y = \{ \texttt{ENAME} \} \\$$

So now we have to use that expression:

$$ \displaystyle \forall v_1, \ldots, v_k, w_1,\ldots,w_k. (R\langle v_1, \ldots, v_k\rangle \wedge R\langle w_1, \ldots w_k \rangle \wedge \left( \left(\bigwedge_{i\in X} v_i = w_i \right) \rightarrow \left(\bigwedge_{j \in Y} v_j = w_j\right) \right) $$

So what does this actually say:

  1. For every possible valuation of our database: $$ \{ v_1, \ldots, v_k \} $$, $$ R\langle v_1, \ldots, v_k\rangle $$
  2. And every other valuation of our database: $$ \{ w_1, \ldots, w_k \} $$, $$R\langle w_1, \ldots, w_k\rangle $$
  3. If all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{i\in X} v_i = w_i $$
  4. Then all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{j \in Y} v_j = w_j $$

Or summarized in more normal words, for a given set of values for X, Y will always be the same. Consider this database:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|---------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This is ok. For every value of SIN, it always has the same ENAME

What about this:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|--------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 123 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This one is no good anymore, since the SIN "123" has two associated ENAME ("David" and "Grant"). It can no longer be considered a function.

Now this one?

-----|-----|------
1    | 123 | David

This is ok. For all the values of SIN, the ENAME is the same every time.
