So what does this actually say:

  1. For every possible valuation of our database: $$ \{ v_1, \ldots, v_k \} $$, $$ R\langle v_1, \ldots, v_k\rangle $$
  2. And every other valuation of our database: $$ \{ w_1, \ldots, w_k \} $$, $$R\langle w_1, \ldots, w_k\rangle $$
  3. If all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$i$$ in $$X$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{i\in X} v_i = w_i $$
  4. Then all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the first valuation have the same values as all the attributes $$j$$ in $$Y$$ in the second valuation: $$ \bigwedge_{j \in Y} v_j = w_j $$

Or summarized in more normal words, for a given set of values for X, Y will always be the same. Consider this database:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|---------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This is ok. For every value of SIN, it always has the same ENAME

What about this:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|--------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 123 | Grant
3    | 789 | Feridun

This one is no good anymore, since the SIN "123" has two associated ENAME ("David" and "Grant"). It can no longer be considered a function.

Now this one?

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | Grant
3    | 123 | David

This is ok. For all the values of SIN, the ENAME is the same every time.

And the last possibility:

PNUM | SIN | ENAME
-----|-----|------
1    | 123 | David
2    | 456 | David
3    | 789 | David

Here the names are repeated, but since we still follow the "for every SIN, the ENAME is always the same" rule, then this is still a functional dependency.

For those who think best in code (if there are any of you out there), then if you could write a function (a pure function, so think like in Racket or something with no side effects) that takes SIN as input and outputs the right ENAME according to the database, then there exists a functional dependency:

(define (SIN->ENAME sin)
  (case
    [(= sin 123) ("David")]
    [(= sin 456) ("Grant")]
    [else (error "No such SIN number")]))

history.subject: Generalization Primary/Foreign Key
history.content:
Say I have entities A and B, where the primary key for both is (c,d). I generalize A and B into entity G.

Then G has primary key (c,d). 

But now for A and B, is (c,d) a primary key or a foreign key referring to G?

If it's a foreign key, can A and B then not have primary keys?

A foreign key can also be a primary key at the same time, so long as they will still always be unique (i.e. 1 to 1 relationship)

This is ok:

CREATE TABLE G (
  c INT NOT NULL,
  d INT NOT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (c, d)
);
CREATE TABLE A (
  c INT NOT NULL,
  d INT NOT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (c, d),
  FOREIGN KEY (c, d) REFERENCES G (c, d)
);

If the relationship is not 1 to 1, then you just have to add something to differentiate:

CREATE TABLE B (
  c INT NOT NULL,
  d INT NOT NULL,
  e INT NOT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (c, d, e),
  FOREIGN KEY (c, d) REFERENCES G (c, d)
);

history.subject: How do we get this theorem?

history.content:
That one kind of just comes from the definition of $$ ComputeX^+$$.

$$ComputeX^+$$ computes all the attributes ($$X^+$$) that are implied by some set of relations $$X$$ and the set of given functional dependencies ($$F$$). By this definition, $$X\rightarrow X^+$$, so if $$Y\subset X^+$$, then $$X\rightarrow Y$$. This is the $$\leftarrow$$ direction.

For the other way, its basically the same thing. If $$X\implies Y\in F^+$$, then $$Y$$ is, by definition, a subset of $$X^+$$.

Edit: rewrote stuff more correctly.

That one kind of just comes from the definition of $$ ComputeX^+$$.

Recall that $$ F^+$$ is the set of all derived functional dependencies, and $$ ComputeX^+$$ computes all the functional dependencies ($$X^+$$) that are implied by the set of given functional dependencies ($$F$$) and some set of relations $$X$$. $$X^+$$ is then a subset of $$F^+$$. This gives us the $$\leftarrow$$ direction of the IFF.

For the other way, you'd have to analyze that algorithm I guess, but if we assume that $$ComputeX^+$$ works, then that's basically just a mathematical expression of the result of the function ($$ComputeX^+(X, F)$$ is computing all the implications that are derived from $$ X \rightarrow Y \in F^+$$)

history.subject: Question about the ER Diagram
history.content: Is it incorrect to have two copies of the same entity set in one ER diagram? For example, can multiple entity sets have the same set of specializations?

history.subject: Question about the ER Diagram
history.content: Is it incorrect to have two copies of the same entity in one ER diagram? For example, can multiple entity sets have the same set of specializations?

Though technically not incorrect, it is probably a sign of a poorly designed schema if things are duplicated. There is probably a way to generalize your entities further so that the duplicated specializations and attributes can be shared.

For example, not sure if related, but if you've got apples and oranges as separate entities, and recognize that both can become rotten by making a "rotten apples" and "rotten oranges" specialization, then you're better of having "fruit" and "rotten fruit", and making the apples and oranges into more specializations of fruit.

worse:

A    O
|    |
RA   RO

better:

   F
  /|\
RF A O

history.subject: A3 ER Diagram
history.content: If I specify the relationship between two entity sets A,B with (1, positive infinity).  Does it mean that the relational schema enforces that there is at least 1 mapping from A to B?

No. Think about how you would add entries if this was the case. If you try to create an A object, you'll need to first assign it to a B object. If the relationship is a table, you won't be able to create A object in the A table  and insert (A,B) into the relationship table at the same time. If the relationship you specified is not enforced, then you can perform these updates sequentially without any problems.

history.subject: A3 adding things not in the description
history.content: Are we supposed to add categories not in the description (like completed purchase orders)? In particular, a customer may order the same camera twice (at different points in time) but sets do not store duplicates.

Sets don't store duplicates, but databases aren't sets. They use multiset/bag semantics, so they do store duplicates. If we have a duplicate order that is ok, and your system should support it.

If supporting a duplicate order, for example, requires adding your own attributes/columns to a relation, then that will be fine. Whatever makes your database the "best database it could be" is what the profs are looking for.

history.subject: Notation Meaning
history.content: Can someone explain what this notation means?

It's like "and" ($$\wedge$$) but for a whole bunch of stuff. Think $$\sum$$ but with $$\wedge$$ instead of $$+$$.

$$ \bigwedge_{j\in x} f(j) \equiv f(j_1) \wedge f(j_2) \wedge \ldots\wedge f(j_n) $$

history.subject: How can a table have 2^n candidate keys?
history.content:
In the class, Prof Weddell said that a table can have 2^n candidate possible candidate keys (because if there are n attributes, we can have 2^n different subsets of those attributes and each can be a candidate key?). This confuses me, because we know that a candidate key is a "maximal" superkey (i.e no subsets are superkeys). 

How did he arrive at this answer?

two columns that are primary keys. Then we can have 2^n combinations of primary keys: the example Prof Weddell used was having SIN number and project number? as primary key, so you can have n number of different SIN entries for a project number, and vice versa so you have 2^n possibly entries there. 

EDIT: I've read the notes and some stack overflow now. Here's my thoughts:

$$2^n$$ candidate keys is impossible. Maybe you are remembering from class wrong, because there are approximately $$2^n$$ (exactly $$2^n-1$$) superkeys for a relation.

The $$2^n$$ superkeys are found by picking all the possible combinations of attributes in your relation. Say $$R = (A, B, C)$$, and each of A, B, and C are each superkeys on their own, then $$\{ A, B, C, AB, AC, BC, ABC \} $$ are your $$2^n-1$$ superkeys. The one missing is the empty set.

The candidate keys in that case, however, are just A, B, and C. Though your definition of candidate key is good ("no subsets are superkeys"), I'd think of this more as a "minimal" superkey. Don't get that confused.

What is the maximum number of candidate keys then? The maximum of $$ \binom{n}{r} $$, where we have $$n$$ attributes and $$r$$ is the number of attributes we are using to make up the candidate key.

It seems pretty well explained on that stack overflow link there, so check that out if you want, but this one should make sense with some thinking.

I doubt this will be tested anywhere, but cool to know.

two columns that are primary keys. Then we can have 2^n combinations of primary keys: the example Prof Weddell used was having SIN number and project number? as primary key, so you can have n number of different SIN entries for a project number, and vice versa so you have 2^n possibly entries there.

children.subject: Isn't n SIN numbers and n project numbers $$n \times n = n^2$$ candidate keys?

you're probably right Professor Eldridge.

- OP of student answer
don't meddle with the weddel
I was not right plz ignore me. Didn't read notes on superkeys yet, but I will update answer with what I have discovered since then

n is the number of attributes, so the example of SIN, projNo is not relevant. If the attributes A1, ... , An, B1, ..., Bn are the attributes then (A1 or B1) ... (An or Bn) give 2^n candidate keys. Note that this isn't the actual maximum; I think that is (2n choose n), obtained by choosing any n of the attributes.

history.subject: Representing (1,N) in DDL
history.content:
How would you go about representing a (1, N) relationship in DDL?

Or even a (2,N) relationship: for example "Cameras with an ability to replace lenses are related to at least two or more lenses".

The SQL queries that compute violations are just for things you couldn't write a constraint for they want to be able to find all rows that break the rules. If you didn't write a constraint for the rating between 1 and 5, but that was one of the restrictions, then they want to see something like:

SELECT * FROM Evaluations WHERE rating < 1 OR rating > 5

history.subject: What's the purpose served by an indicator variable and a cursor?
history.content: What's the purpose served by an indicator variable and a cursor?

Indicator variables: you want to query for an int.  Imagine it's null.  What value would you expect?  0?  -1?  Those might be actual valid values for the entry to take on.  So you use an indicator variable to tell you if it was null.

Cursor: iterate through the results of a query.  If you're not using cursors you can only operate on queries that result in one row.

history.subject: Sample Midterm 1a)
history.content:
Could someone help me with this question?

(a) Explain why it might be desirable to use an ability to have more than one external schema over an enterprise’s conceptual schema. What kind of data independence is achieved by using this ability?

I don’t really know why it’s necessary to have more than one external schema.

I do know that it’s data independent, so that users won’t need to know the conceptual schema if a external schema is provided.

Let's say your database has information about hockey teams and lacrosse teams.  The conceptual schema specifies a logical structure of all of that data.  But having two external schema, one to the hockey parts of the DB and one to the lacrosse parts would make it easier for users who only care about one sport to interface with the DB.  Also if you change the hockey schema (like an interface change), the lacrosse people don't have to worry about it.

This is an example of logical independence, as opposed to physical independence.

children.subject:
Could you also clarify the difference between physical and logical dependence?

It’s mentioned briefly in the slides but the definitions don’t offer a great understanding.

Thanks!

Just means you're not affected by changes in the physical schema / conceptual schema.

Physical has to do with files and stuff, like if you add an extra hard drive and move some files around.  So physical independence means you're abstracted away from that change.

Logical has to do with how the data are represented in the tables of the conceptual schema, for example whether you store hockey and lacrosse teams in one "team" table or in two different "lacrosse team" and "hockey team" tables.  If you're logically independent, you won't be aware if they make that change (because your external schema abstracts it away).

history.subject: Weak entity?
history.content: So a "weak entity" is just a relationship table? I.e. used for many-to-many relationships between 2.

"a weak entity is an entity that cannot be uniquely identified by its attributes alone; therefore, it must use a foreign key in conjunction with its attributes to create a primary key"

Weak entities don't need to be in many-to-many relationships, or between only two entities. 

For a specific example, consider a schema with a table 'Course', 'Section', 'Campus', 'Professor'. Section would be a weak entity, because it doesn't make sense as a standalone entity. Sections are defined by the class they belong to, the times they are scheduled, the specific instructor, and a specific campus. 

Each section would only be taught by one professor, on one campus (1:1). Courses could have many sections (1:N). etc. etc.

Explain why it might be desirable to use an ability to have more than one external schema over an enterprise’s conceptual schema. What kind of data independence is achieved by using this ability?

By using more than one external schema over an enterprises's conceptual schema, you can achieve logical data independence. If an application relies on only a small subset of the conceptual schema, changes to the schema outside of this subset will not affect the application. This enables developers to continue working on their application without worrying about being affected by changes to other areas of the database. 

Explain how logical data independence can reduce the cost of developing and maintaining an information system.

From above, logical data independence enables developers to continue working on their application without being affected by changes to areas of the conceptual schema their application does not use. If the application was affected by any change to the schema, the application would need to be constantly updated to react to the changes. Maintaining that system would be difficult, knowing that any changes you want to make will affect every application.

history.subject: What is a foreign key contraint?

history.content:
When one table references another, you do it by putting the foreign table's primary key as an attribute in your table. When you do this you have to put a foreign key constraint to ensure that only valid foreign keys are used as values for that column. If a non-existent key is used, it will be rejected.

For example, the appearsin column of the database for A2 had a foreign key constraint. It was referencing pubid's, specifically values that appear in $$\{ \langle p \rangle | \text{Proceedings}\langle p, \texttt{_}\rangle \vee \text{Journal}\langle p, \texttt{_}, \texttt{_}, \texttt{_}\rangle \} $$.

The range for 'taught by' is just clarifying that exactly one professor teaches a certain section. It's not valid to say '0 or 1 professors teach this section'.

history.subject: F2013 3a
history.content:
"In what way can a SQL view behave differently from a SQL table?"

My guess:

- a SQL view can contain data from multiple SQL tables 

- a SQL view is not always stored permanently in the database

Does anyone have a better answer?

A table contains data, a view is just a SELECT statement which has been saved in the database. The advantage of a view is that it can join data from several tables thus creating a new view of it. Say you have a database with salaries and you need to do some complex statistical queries on it. Instead of sending the complex query to the database all the time, you can save the query as a view and then SELECT * FROM view

history.subject: Difference between regular Embedded SQL vs Dynamic Embedded SQL?

history.content:
"Static SQL is SQL statements in an application that do not change at runtime and, therefore, can be hard-coded into the application. Dynamic SQL is SQL statements that are constructed at runtime; for example, the application may allow users to enter their own queries. Thus, the SQL statements cannot be hard-coded into the application." (source: http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1330223&seqNum=2)

For example, adhoc.sqc is a Dynamic SQL application. My understanding is that the program takes in SQL queries as its input, validates them, runs them, and returns the results.

In contrast, a static application would have a set of queries that the user of the application cannot change. 

(Static and Dynamic SQL applications can be written without the use of embedded sql - they are independent concepts)

history.subject: What is the difference between View and With

history.content:
WITH is a way to name a subquery that can be used in place of a relation (table) later on in SQL statements.

A VIEW is an extension of the database schemas that allows you to create customized virtual relations.

$$ WITH $$ is a way to name a subquery that can be used in place of a relation (table) later on in SQL statements.

A $$ VIEW $$ is an extension of the database schemas that allows you to create customized virtual relations.

history.subject: Using a join vs selecting from multiple tables

When do you need to use a join vs. selecting from multiple tables? For example, the F2012 midterm solutions have these two queries, and I'm not sure why they use a join in only one of them.

SELECT Proj.pno, count(*)

FROM Proj, Works

WHERE city = 'Toronto'

AND Proj.pno = Works.pno

GROUP BY Proj.pno, pname

And get the same results?

The issue here is that you are only returning things that are in BOTH the proj.pno AND works.pno.

In the solution, they are using a LEFT JOIN, which returns ALL projects in proj (not just the ones that have a someone working on it, ie. count would be equal to 0), and the projects from works that matches a project number in PROJ.

history.subject: Fall 2012 Q1 ER diagram
history.content:
Few Questions here:

1) What does the arrow represent? Is the same as writing (0,1) on the arrow on the person entity side instead?

2) Why does the dark line represent?

3) Why is colors a weak entity?

4) Why are there no ranges (like (1,N)) shown on the arrows to depict to one to many and many to one relationships?

Thanks!

This diagram is in a slightly different format compared to what we were taught in class, which is why it might be confusing. 

1) In the version we were taught, an arrow represents one entity, and a line without an arrow represents multiple (N) entities. The diagram is saying there is a 1:N relationship between houses and people, since many people can live in one house.

2) I believe this is representing the range (1, N), since a house must be owned by at least one person (one of the restrictions from the question). 

3) Colours is not a weak entity, it is a multivalued attribute. In the version we were taught, you would connect House to Colours using two lines, and Colours would have a single border. (see slide 22 https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~david/cs348/lect-ER-handout.pdf) 

4) The ranges are implied by the type of line you use, and only need to be written in special cases.

5) The question kind of implies that Address is a composite attribute when it says 'three-part address', so it's safe to assume you should draw it as a composite like they did.

history.subject: Answers true in all possible worlds W of an incomplete D.
history.content: Can anyone explain what it means?

So this is explaining the handling of NULL values. When there is no applicable value, you just exclude the row from the result. When there is an unknown value, however, we have to assume that it could be any of the values.

This means that, suppose we had a table with a null value in it, where the null value was representing an "unknown value". Example:

People
Name    | PhoneNumber
--------------------
Cameron | NULL

Here we have a database but we don't know my phone number. I do have a phone though, just the database doesn't know it. Now let's try and query this database:

SELECT * FROM People WHERE PhoneNumber = 555-1234

Should this return my row? It's possible that my phone number is 555-1234. It's also possible that my phone number is not 555-1234. So I guess we can't return it for sure, since we don't know, so we'll leave it out.

Ok, so for lack of better real world example... Let's consider CS348 where no matter what, David Toman has to be teaching at least one section, but the teaching arrangements are not yet lined up for W2018

Classes
cnum  | prof  | term  | section
-------------------------------
CS348 | David | S2017 | 1
CS348 | Grant | S2017 | 2
CS348 | Grant | F2017 | 2
CS348 | David | F2017 | 1
CS348 | NULL  | W2018 | 1
CS348 | NULL  | W2018 | 2

What if I tried to do this query:

SELECT cnum, term FROM Classes WHERE prof = 'David'

Obviously I'll get back

CS348 | S2017
CS348 | F2017

But what about W2018? Based on the rules of the database, we know David has to be a prof for 2018. We just don't know what section, or who the other prof will be. Should we return CS348 | W2018 as well?

The slides say yes. In all possible universes, David will end up teaching CS348 in W2018. It's just that this is super hard to figure out for the DBMS in most cases, so SQL just does that "crude approximation", which is explained on the next slide.

children.subject: Do you mean also explaining what  "crude approximation" does? Does it depend on the operations (bag operation, expression, etc)?

The crude approximation is just the set of operations SQL provides for null. Not sure how it's an approximation of the "all possible universes" thing at all, but just "some stuff that's easy to implement and provides enough power for you to create queries about"

When we do math or other expressions and one of the values is null, the whole thing becomes null. (Like 3 + 5 * 4 - peach, what is the answer? Idk man you can't subtract peach from 20)

Comparisons all return null when one of the values is also NULL, so we can instead check for if the result of an expression is NULL, i.e.

SELECT * FROM People WHERE PhoneNumber IS NULL   --> Cameron

Recall we cannot use NULL in an equality:

SELECT * FROM People WHERE PhoneNumber = NULL    --> [no results]

Counts and aggregates don't count NULLS

SELECT count(prof) FROM Classes GROUP BY cnum    --> 4 (the NULL was not one of the profs) (also, this is not "count distinct prof", so we can have 4)

history.subject: Can someone explain the relational calculus for left join?

The LEFT join in SQL returns all results in one table + results in another table when applicable.

This calculus (2) returns all the results in R, but only where there is no corresponding row in S. I don't believe this is a left join, but part of a left join.

children.subject: can i therefore assume that for the above statement, this relational calculus should be {(x,y,z):R(x,y) ^ S(y,z) | (x,y,null): R(x,y) ^ not (there exists z.S(y,z))}?

There's no real way to combine the two since we can't really get that NULL value in the R-R RC.

Unions like this is not really RC I guess, but something you could do afterwards? I don't know if they would accept this on an exam though. Other posts have said that union was not allowed on the assignment.

$$ \{ \langle x, y, z \rangle | R\langle x, y \rangle \wedge S\langle x, y \rangle \} \cup \{ \langle x, y, \texttt{NULL}\rangle | R\langle x, y \rangle \wedge \neg \exists z. S\langle y, z\rangle \} $$

You could try using the $$ \vee $$ but you'll find that you can't do it following the R-R RC rules because the z would not be a free variable in the right half.

history.subject: Relational calculus: union and set difference?
history.content: Are union and set difference operations allowed in Relational calculus ( I would think not cause I lost marks on the assignment for having them.) If not, how do we express the same idea using operations allowed in relational calculus?

You can use an or ($$\vee$$) for union:

(SELECT pubid FROM Book) UNION (SELECT pubid FROM Journal)

$$ \{ \langle P \rangle | \text{Book}\langle P, \texttt{_}, \texttt{_}\rangle \vee \text{Journal}\langle P, \texttt{_}, \texttt{_}, \texttt{_}\rangle \} $$

Set difference using some sort of negations or something which would make the query equivalent.

(SELECT pubid FROM Book)
EXCEPT
(SELECT pubid FROM Book WHERE year > 2000)

is equivalent to

SELECT pubid FROM Book WHERE year <= 2000

$$ \{ \langle P \rangle | \text{Book}\langle P, \texttt{_}, y \rangle \wedge y \leq 2000 \} $$

Intersection would be done using and ($$ \wedge $$), but this is just a regular and.

history.subject: Roles?
history.content: What are Roles for ER diagrams, I don't really get what they're adding?

A role just describes what the relationship is for. This is especially important when there are two different relationships between the same two entities. Roles still exist for single relationships though, and every relationship has a role.

Honestly I can't think of much other example for two roles on one relationship at this moment, so I'll use the example from the slides (ER, page 10/39)

There's those links between Team and Match. As we know, you need two teams to play a match of most sports, so we draw two lines from the Team box to the Match diamond.

Though in this case it's pretty obvious that these two links are just "the two teams that are playing" there can be less clear reasoning for a double link, so we explicitly label the roles "HomeTeam" and "Visitor" to indicate why we have two links there.

Though the "role" itself doesn't really add anything to the meaning of the diagram, they help when translating the diagrams into SQL tables, so that we can name the columns something meaningful (such as "home_team" and "away_team" rather than "team1" and "team2".

history.subject: EXEC SQL PREPARE vs EXEC SQL EXECUTE IMMEDIATE vs EXEC SQL EXECUTE
history.content: What the the difference between these?

PREPARE compiles the provided SQL statement and saves it somewhere, allowing it to be optimized by the database before you start using it. It's the most similar to how the Static ESQL we used for A2.

EXECUTE is to execute a previously prepared statement.

EXECUTE IMMEDIATE just runs the statement in one shot, and doesn't save the compiled query anywhere. This is good if you only have to use a query once because it's just quick and easy.

history.subject: What do the terms data base instance and data base signature mean?
history.content:
Particularly, I don't really understand slide 7/38 of Relational handout. 

Thanks

A database instance are essentially relations (tables) in a database (DB) with a domain (D). (Ie. a table for each schema in the database, holding the values in the domain).

A database signature are a set of relation schemas (Recall that a schema describes a table).

$$ \rho = (R_1, R_2..., R_n) $$

For example, a database's signature can be:

author(author_id, author_name)

book(author_id, book_id, book_name)

A database instance are essentially relations (tables) in a database (DB). (Ie. a table for each schema in the database).

A database signature are a set of relation schemas (Recall that a schema describes a table).

$$ p = (R_1, R_2..., R_n) $$

For example, a database signature's can be:

author(author_id, author_name)

book(author_id, book_id, book_name)

A database instance are essentially relations (tables) in a database (DB). (Ie. a table for each schema).

A database signature are a set of relation schemas (Recall that a schema describes a table).

$$ p = (R_1, R_2..., R_n) $$

For example, a database signature's can be:

author(author_id, author_name)

book(author_id, book_id, book_name)

children.subject: Ok, that makes sense. Is there a differene between the signature and schema? The schema of a table describes that table, and the signature seems to do the same. I know I am missing something.

See slide 28.

The signature is just a list of the tables. A schema then defines restrictions and such. Finally the instance is the actual implementation of the schema, which can be populated with data.

history.subject: midtermF2013
history.content: Assume relation R has attributes {A, B, C}, with A as the primary key. Can the following SQL query be expressed in the relational calculus satisfying the range restricted syntax? Justify your answer.

You cannot I think.

The issue is that you will count non-distinct entities for B since SQL has bag-semantics and count(*) counts rows (of not distinct values). For this query, we're selecting distinct B's, so that's ok

Here's what I get when I write this as R-R RC:

$$ \{ \langle B \rangle | \exists a_1, a_2, a_3. (R\langle a_1, B, \texttt{_}\rangle \wedge R\langle a_2, B, \texttt{_}\rangle \wedge R\langle a_3, B, \texttt{_}\rangle \wedge a_1 \neq a_2 \neq a_3) \wedge \exists c.(R\langle \texttt{_}, B, c\rangle \wedge c < 10) \rangle $$

You cannot I think.

The issue is that you will count non-distinct entities for B since SQL has bag-semantics and count(*) counts rows (of not distinct values).

You can technically express this in RC but you will get differing results between the RC and SQL.

A TaughtBy does not hold any attributes, and the cardinality is (1, 1) , so there is no table needed.

history.subject: What does a dotted underline represent in ER diagram

The solid underline then identifies a primary key, and the dotted underlines are parts of the subordinate entity primary key.

history.subject: W07 Question 1d. Query safe
history.content:
Is this query safe

{⟨x⟩|∀y(R⟨y⟩ → S⟨x, y⟩)}

In this form, it's pretty hard to tell, so we'll want to rewrite that. Recall from MATH135, that implication can be rewritten:

$$ a \rightarrow b \equiv \neg a \vee b$$

So let's try that with the calculus:

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \forall y.(\neg \text{R}\langle y \rangle \vee S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Already it looks a little sketchy, but let's keep going. Recall how to rewrite forall:

$$ \forall x.y \rightarrow \neg \exists x. \neg y $$

So with the calculus:

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \neg \exists y. \neg(\neg \text{R}\langle y \rangle \vee S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Now let's reduce: $$ \neg (a \vee b) \rightarrow \neg a \wedge \neg b$$

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \neg \exists y. ( \text{R}\langle y \rangle \wedge\neg S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Now it looks like something we're more familiar with. Consider the rules of the range restricted calculus in @243. Quickly you realize that none of them even start with $$\neg \exists$$, and that this query is very much not safe.

In this form, it's pretty hard to tell, so we'll want to rewrite that. Recall from MATH135, that implication can be rewritten:

$$ a \rightarrow b \equiv \neg a \vee b$$

So let's try that with the calculus:

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \forall y.(\neg \text{R}\langle y \rangle \vee S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Already it looks a little sketchy, but let's keep going. Recall how to rewrite forall:

$$ \forall x.y \rightarrow \neg \exists x. \neg y $$

So with the calculus:

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \neg \exists y. \neg(\neg \text{R}\langle y \rangle \vee S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Now let's reduce: $$ \neg (a \vee b) \rightarrow \neg a \wedge \neg b$$

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | \neg \exists y. ( \text{R}\langle y \rangle \wedge\neg S\langle x, y \rangle) \} $$

Now it looks like something we're more familiar with. Consider the rules of the range restricted calculus in @243. Quickly you realize that none of them even start with $$\neg exists$$, and that this query is very much not safe.

history.subject: Relational Calculus Possible
history.content: How do we determine if writing a query in relational calculus is possible? Do we determine this through range restricted queries (@243)?

In general, all I know how to do is just keep trying and stop when I run into something impossible. Range restriction just lets you know if the query is domain independent/safe to be written as SQL.

All range restricted RC can be expressed as SQL, but not all SQL statements can be represented as RC.

Most aggregation functions don't exist in RC, and neither does the ORDER BY clause. GROUP BY doesn't exist, but depending on what you are using the group for sometimes you can do it in other ways. For example, if we need to SELECT ... HAVING COUNT(x) >= 2 GROUP BY y, we may be able to just write $$ \exists x_1, x_2. ( T\langle x_1, y\rangle \wedge T\langle x_2, y\rangle \wedge x_1 \neq x_2) $$.

SELECT MAX() and SELECT MIN() have been explained before, but basically just "not exists something bigger/smaller".

Though technically the LIKE operator doesn't exist, they allowed us to "invent" one for A1. If there are exceptions like this on the exam they'll probably tell us.

For example, if we need to SELECT ... HAVING COUNT(x) >= 2 GROUP BY y, we may be able to just write $$ \exists x_1, x_2. ( T\langle x_1\rangle \wedge T\langle x_2\rangle \wedge x_1 \neq x_2) $$.

history.subject: Relational Calculus Question
history.content:
I'm going through the previous midterms that were posted, and in W10, there is a problem asking to express in relational algebra:

Which food groups have a food that supplies all the nutrients to combat cancer?

The schema is: 

Class ( food, food_group )

Requirement ( nutrient, minimum_recommendation )

Supplies ( food , nutrient, amount )

Combats ( nutrient, disease)

My question is, is it possible to express this query in relational calculus? If so, how?

history.subject: Relational Calculus Question
history.content:
I'm going through the previous midterms that were posted, and in W10, there is a problem asking to express in relational algebra:

Which food groups have a food that supplies all the nutrients to combat cancer?

The schema is: 

Class ( food , food_group )

Requirement ( nutrient , minimum_recommendation )

Supplies ( food , nutrient , amount )

Combats ( nutrient , disease )

My question is, is it possible to express this query in relational calculus? If so, how?

All relational algebra things are able to be written as relational calculus.

$$\{ \langle G \rangle | \exists f.(\text{Class}\langle f, G \rangle \wedge \neg \exists n,r,a.( \text{Combats}\langle n, \text{Cancer}\rangle \wedge \text{Requirement} \langle n, r \rangle \wedge \neg (\text{Supplies}\langle f, n, a\rangle \wedge a \geq r ) ))\} $$

Major overkill stack overflow answer explaining the differences between then two that I didn't read because its too complicated, but I found the note that says they can both do the same things: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32837278/difference-between-relational-algebra-and-relational-calculus

All relational algebra things are able to be written as relational calculus.

$$\{ \langle G \rangle | \exists f.(\text{Class}\langle f, G \rangle \wedge \neg \exists n.( \text{Combats}\langle n, \text{Cancer}\rangle \wedge \neg \text{Supplies}\langle f, n, \texttt{_}\rangle ) )\} $$

Major overkill stack overflow answer explaining the differences between then two that I didn't read because its too complicated, but I found the note that says they can both do the same things: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32837278/difference-between-relational-algebra-and-relational-calculus

All relational algebra things are able to be written as relational calculus.

$$<br/><br/>\{ \langle G \rangle |<br/><br/> \exists f.(<br/><br/> \text{Class}\langle f, G \rangle<br/><br/> \wedge \neg \exists n.(<br/><br/> \text{Combats}\langle n, \text{Cancer}\rangle<br/><br/> \wedge \neg \text{Supplies}\langle f, n, \texttt{_}\rangle<br/><br/> )<br/><br/> )<br/><br/>\}<br/><br/><br/> $$

Major overkill stack overflow answer explaining the differences between then two that I didn't read because its too complicated, but I found the note that says they can both do the same things: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32837278/difference-between-relational-algebra-and-relational-calculus

I think all relational algebra things are able to be written as relational calculus.

$$ \{ \langle G \rangle | \exists f.( \text{Class}\langle f, G \rangle \wedge \neg \exists n.( \text{Combats}\langle n, \text{Cancer}\rangle \wedge \neg \text{Supplies}\langle f, n, \texttt{_}\rangle ) ) \} $$

history.subject: How do I learn everything in 24 hours?
history.content: Just finished my midterm, and now I need to learn everything in this course for tomorrow... Any idea how/where i should start? I finished assignment 1 and 2 if that helps..

@235 has the midterm samples, gathered from as many places as we could find. It seems that the format doesn't change a lot between years, so they are pretty indicative of what we need. Some include "Relational Algebra" which is not the same as relational calculus, but I don't think they taught that this year since none of us seem to know what it is, so we're probably ok not knowing it...

Make sure you know SQL, and Relational Calculus. If you've done the assignments you should be good, maybe just review them. @28 is still around.

If you are wondering about query safety, see @251, @259, or @67

ESQL is probably good to know but they are not likely to be quizzing your C syntax. Maybe just know the theory behind ESQL, and how/why we go about using it. @237

ER diagrams will probably be involved for at least one question, so read the slides about those. @240 + @256 explains the weird bit, but most of it is pretty easy to get from the slides I think.

Also there are a lot of definition questions for the terms so find all the definitions on the slides I guess? I've explained a few so far if the slides are not good enough. @126, @243, @244

EDIT: Also go over all the slides. Probably should've included that from the start, but I guess it's kind of given anyway. Above are my priorities when studying, but don't take this for guaranteed what will be on the test.

history.subject: did we learn primary keys in class
history.content: have we learnt primary keys in class? the slides don't have it but the textbook chapters hes mentioned has it. also, ,the sample midterm does have a question on it. i understand it's a "SAMPLE" midterm, but just wanna check if i missed anything

Primary key is a pretty fundamental thing in a database, so I would think we have to know it. I think he mentioned it in class. At least it's an easy idea:

The primary key is just a unique identifier for a row in a table. Most often it's just an ID of some sort, like pubid or aid. The big things though are that they are never null and always unique.

They can be referenced in other tables to set up relationships between two rows. This was the case for appearsin. When appearing in a non-primary key location, they are called foreign keys.

A primary key can be made up of a few columns if that makes sense. This was what happened on A1, when the primary key for a Class was the triple (cnum, section, term), which appeared as a foreign key in the Mark table and the Enrollment table.

history.subject: Domain Independent/Range Restricted
history.content:
Does anyone have a good resource on understanding domain-independent queries and range restricted queries?

From my understanding, domain-independent queries are just queries that return the same result for the database under all its' schemas. Can someone give me an example of how a domain-independent query looks like?

And also, for the range restricted queries, do we just observe the form of the query and if it has a particular form as listed in the slides, then it is range restricted? Does one really have to know the properties of range restricted queries or is it derivable?

history.subject: relational calculus
history.content:
Does anyone have a good resource on understanding domain-independent queries and range restricted queries?

From my understanding, domain-independent queries are just queries that return the same result for the database under all its' schemas. Can someone give me an example of how a domain-independent query looks like?

And also, for the range restricted queries, do we just observe the form of the query and if it has a particular form as listed in the slides, then it is range restricted? Does one really have to know the properties of range restricted queries or is it derivable?

For domain independence, see @126.

Range restricted maybe in the morning... ok so,

Range restricted is just a restriction on the things we are allowed to write in the relational calculus. The reason we make this restriction is that if a query is range restricted then it is also domain independent. No idea how to prove that but it says it on the slides so lets go with it. SQL only allows this range restricted sort of query, so if you think like SQL you won't have much problem coming up with range restricted queries on the exam.

That said, it's probably good to know the rules. I'm just taking these from the slides.

Below, we require that all $$ \varphi $$ are range restricted queries in the relational calculus, then any of the following are also range restricted

  1. $$ R\langle x_1, \ldots, x_k \rangle $$
    • Why? If you are selecting from a table, you won't get values that aren't in the table. Remember domain independence was to avoid getting values that aren't in tables.
    • Always include a table/relation in your RC. SQL doesn't let you not include a table.
  2. $$ \varphi_1 \wedge (x_i = x_j) \text{, if } \{ x_i, x_j \} \cap FV(\varphi_1)\neq \emptyset$$
    • Putting this one out of order from the slides because I think it makes more sense to make the distinction here early.
    • An equality must refer to at least one existing free variable (FV) from the rest of the query.
    • If we could start introducing random variables in an equality, we could write stuff like $$ \{ \langle x, y \rangle | x = y \} $$, which we all know by now is BAD.
    • I think this goes for $$ <, >, \le, \ge, \neq $$ as well
  3. $$ \varphi_1 \wedge \varphi_2 $$
    • This one only makes sense. If we have two separate range restricted things, then together they must be range restricted right?
  4. $$ \exists x_i.\varphi_1 \text{, if } x_i \in FV(\varphi_1)$$
    • The restriction here ($$ x_i \in FV(\varphi_1) $$) simply means that we have to use the variable we introduce. If we don't use the value then why did we introduce it?
    • Notice this is the ONLY way we can introduce a new variable when it's not a value in the table.
      • Notice that this variable is a free variable only in the query $$\varphi_1$$, not in the surroundings. We can't output $$ x_i $$
    • TBH to make sure nothing goes wrong, if the variable is not in the output, introduce it with $$ \exists $$, even if you're using it in a table. This makes everything easier to understand. If you're going to take one thing away from this whole post, this is the thing to take. It's pretty hard to write a not-range-restricted query if you follow this rule.
      • The examples on the slide don't do always do this, but then there's slide 16 that says at the bottom that $$ \{ x_1, \ldots x_k \} = FV(\varphi) $$, i.e., "all the outputs are all the free variables in the query" so I guess using free variables and not outputting them is just shorthand for an $$ \exists $$ surrounding the entire query. Follow the slides if you dare.
      • The slides also don't use the _ notation that I think makes more sense for discarded values (I use that in @28). They give it a real name instead. This can only lead to confusion in the long run and the markers accepted the _ I used on my assignment so it seems safe enough to use it, so I'll probably be doing that on the exam and if it makes things easier to understand you can too.
  5. $$ \varphi_1 \vee \varphi_2 \text{, if } FV(\varphi_1) = FV(\varphi_2) $$
    • When we have one thing or the other thing, they have to use the same variables for each. If we didn't, the output would be weird right?
    • What would you say is the output of this? $$ \{ \langle x, y \rangle | T\langle x\rangle \vee S\langle y \rangle \} $$
      • You either have x or y, but not both? One is null? How would we use this result? Why not just make two separate queries? IDK man it just doesn't work out.
    • This is consistent with what I say on #4, that we have to introduce with $$ \exists $$ if it's not in the output. That way your variables is not a free variable in the whole statement, so you can use it in the subquery.
  6. $$ \varphi_1 \wedge \neg \varphi_2 \text{, if } FV(\varphi_2) \subseteq FV(\varphi_1)$$
    • If we need one thing to be true and another to be false, we can't introduce new free variables here.
    • Again consistent with #4. You can only get new variables in a negation if you introduce them with exists to make sure they aren't free in the whole statement.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I guess it's important to define "free variable" too, in case someone doesn't know... It comes up a lot in that definition

A free variable is one that we cannot say anything about the value of. We constrain these free variables with our query, and that is how we get results. If it's in the output of the query, then it better be a free variable, or it will just be a constant (since we already set it).

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | T\langle x\rangle \} $$ - here, $$ x $$ is free. This is the most simple case.

$$ \{ \langle x \rangle | T\langle x \rangle \wedge \exists y.(S\langle y \rangle \wedge x > y) \} $$ - We could not output y with this query, because $$ \exists $$ basically assigns it a value and substitutes that value into the query in the parentheses. Since y has a value in outer query, it is not free. In the parentheses, however, $$ y $$ could be considered free (since we are still able to assign it the value later). If that doesn't make sense, draw up some tables for T and S, and see what you can do.

For domain independence, see @126.

Range restricted maybe in the morning... ok so,

Range restricted is just a restriction on the things we are allowed to write in the relational calculus. The reason we make this restriction is that if a query is range restricted then it is also domain independent. No idea how to prove that but it says it on the slides so lets go with it. SQL only allows this range restricted sort of query, so if you think like SQL you won't have much problem coming up with range restricted queries on the exam.

If you're going to take one thing away from this whole post, this is the thing to take. It's pretty hard to write a not-range-restricted query if you follow this rule.
      • The examples on the slide don't do always do this, but then there's slide 16 that says at the bottom that $$ \{ x_1, \ldots x_k \} = FV(\varphi) $$, i.e., "all the outputs are all the free variables in the query" so I guess using free variables and not outputting them is just shorthand for an $$ \exists $$ surrounding the entire query. Follow the slides if you dare.
      • The slides also don't use the _ notation that I think makes more sense for discarded values (I use that in @28). They give it a real name instead. This can only lead to confusion in the long run and the markers accepted the _ I used on my assignment so it seems safe enough to use it, so I'll probably be doing that on the exam and if it makes things easier to understand you can too.

      • You either have x or y, but not both? One is null? How would we use this result? Why not just make two separate queries? IDK man it just doesn't work out.
    • This is consistent with what I say on #4, that we have to introduce with $$ \exists $$ if it's not in the output. That way your variables is not a free variable in the whole statement, so you can use it in the subquery.
  6. $$ \varphi_1 \wedge \neg \varphi_2 \text{, if } FV(\varphi_2) \subseteq FV(\varphi_1)$$
    • If we need one thing to be true and another to be false, we can't introduce new free variables here.
    • Again consistent with #4. You can only get new variables in a negation if you introduce them with exists to make sure they aren't free in the whole statement.

history.subject: What does the double-border represent in ER Models?
history.content: Just trying to figure out what the double border represents here. Does it mean a Section must have a SecitonOf relationship or something? Thank you!

The double border means it's a weak relationship, so the section depends on courses (i.e. You can't have sections without courses).

See here for more info: https://www.smartdraw.com/entity-relationship-diagram

history.subject: F2013 Makeup Exam Q3c

history.content:
If I had to answer that on the exam right now, it would probably be something like below. No guarantees on how right this is though... can't find anything in the notes.

The database must consist of a static set of tables and relations, so that the SQL statements can be compiled and bound to the database.

The domain of the attributes within database must consist only of types that the ESQL protocol supports.

The C program must not need to create/destroy tables, or modify the SQL schema as this could break the other compiled statements.

Also the C program can only make queries that return one tuple at a time, and use cursors to acquire multiple-row results.

Anyone else think of anything more to add?

history.subject: Null can be always avoided?
history.content:
Can someone please explain what this means?




source: https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~david/cs348/lect-BADSQL-handout.pdf

Any time you have some data in your database that is nullable, there is another way to structure your data so that there is no null values.

Consider the authors table from the assignment, which was like:

CREATE TABLE Author (
  aid  INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name CHAR(22) NOT NULL,
  url  CHAR(42)
);

Here, since url is not NOT NULL, url is allowed to be NULL. The same data could be represented in two tables though:

CREATE TABLE Author (
  aid  INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name CHAR(22) NOT NULL
);
CREATE TABLE AuthorURL (
  aid  INT NOT NULL REFERENCES Author (aid),
  url  CHAR(42) NOT NULL
);

This way we can represent authors and their URLs, but there is never a null value in our database. It's a little less efficient to find out if an author exist and has a URL (we have to check two tables), but in some (many) circumstances this would be the better choice.

No matter the location of your NULL value, some alternate solution such as this one is possible. It's just up to the database builder's best judgement how to do it depending on the situation.

children.subject:
Do you have the same warning message?

Yeah I have the same warnings. It's all harmless, just means that the output from check_error may be incorrect. Some of the numbers in the error message may come out looking like not what they are actually supposed to be. It won't affect the proper functioning of your program though.

You might have had them once and didn't notice. Once you deleted util.c it had to be recompiled, and so it is now showing you those warnings as it recompiles the file. history.subject: A2Q1 Cursor query cannot retrieve unique values
history.content:
I've written a basic version of Q1 that does not check for the proceedings/journal the article appears in. When I enter an author, it will retrieve the publications that match the author, but there's some weird behavior that happens with the other fields. The pubids are retrieved fine, but some values are not updated and the indicator variables do not update either. This is an example of the program being run:

/u@/h:/w/$ ./bibauthor "Peter Bumbulis"
Pubid: BB02
Type: article
Title: TITLE
Authors: Peter Bumbulis ▒, Ivan T. Bowman ▒
In:
Pages: 0--0
/u@/h:/w/$ ./bibauthor "Ivan T. Bowman"
Pubid: BB02
Type: article
Title: TITLE
Authors: Peter Bumbulis ▒, Ivan T. Bowman ▒
In:
Pages: 0--0
Pubid: ABC
Type: article
Title: TITLE
Authors: Ivan T. Bowman ▒
In:
Pages: 0--0

For reference, the database is the same as the default BibSchema, but with an extra book with pubid ABC, title TITLE, year 2000, publisher PUB, and author Ivan T. Bowman.

Looks like it might be finding the wrong data? Maybe your query is not doing what you expect it to be doing. Your new "book" you say you added is showing up as an article, so maybe you are detecting the type wrong.

Also what are these?

▒

Is that coming from your program? You might want to make sure that your strings are the right length (@95)

children.subject: In my cursor query, I use the tables author, wrote, and publication, along with two joins on book and article. When I change the types of join, I get different fields that are correct. I can't seem to figure out which joins are correct. Is there another way besides using joins?

Yes there are a few ways to do it. Left joins are the joins you want.

Other options include quering each table one by one until you find the pubid you are looking for, letting WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO <next_type>;  handle the not founds

Use ifs/case statements to select the table name.

history.subject: A2Q1: Not understanding question
history.content:
I've been swamped, including 3 midterms this upcoming week, and I've been trying to read, and re-read and re-read some more of this question, but I still can't seem to understand what we are outputting.

English is not my forte, can someone please kindly explain?

Your program will be run like this:

./bibauthor "Ivan T. Bowman"

Then what you have to do is:

  1. Search the database for all publications that "Ivan T. Bowman" wrote
  2. If the publication you have found is an Article, then you also have to find the proceedings/journal that it appearsin
  3. Sort them by year. When two publications have the same year, sort them in alphabetical order by the first author (the one where aorder = 1)
    • For sorting purposes:
      • The year of the article is the year of that proceedings/journal
      • The author of the proceedings/journal is '' (empty string)
  4. Print out the information that is requested in the PDF for every publication that you found. It will look kind of like this:

Pubid: SIGMOD02  
Type: Proceedings
Title: Proc. ACM SIGMOD Conference on Management of Data                     
Year: 2002

Pubid: BB02      
Type: Article
Title: Proc. ACM SIGMOD Conference on Management of Data                     
Authors: Peter Bumbulis, Ivan T. Bowman
In: SIGMOD02  
Pages: 533--541

Pubid: BOOK3
Type: Book
Title: This is a cool book by Ivan
Authors: Ivan T. Bowman
Publisher: Book company 101
Year: 2004

Pubid: JOURNAL1
Type: Journal
Volume: 1
Number: 3
Year: 2005

Pubid: BB03
Type: Article
Title: I wrote a cool article
Authors: Ivan T. Bowman, Peter Bumbulis
In: JOURNAL1
Pages: 114--116

./bibauthor "Ivan T. Bowman"

  1. Search the database for all publications that "Ivan T. Bowman" wrote

  3. Sort them by year. When two publications have the same year, sort them in alphabetical order by the first author (the one where aorder = 1)
    • For sorting purposes:
      • The year of the article is the year of that proceedings/journal
      • The author of the proceedings/journal is '' (empty string)

history.subject: Q1 how to determine type?
history.content:
I've been looking at this for a couple hours now and I am stuck on how to actually produce this portion of embedded code. I know the SQL concepts, just having trouble putting them into use.

Particularly I'm having trouble with determining the type of each publication just from the pubid.

Any help or even a vague bit of pseudocode would help!
What I did was do a search in each table. If the pubid exists in a certain table then that's the type that I return.

children.subject: Yes, that's what I thought of, but I am not sure about if it doesn't exist, then how do I go back on the SQL?
If it doesn't exist, the WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO label thing should trigger I think.

EXEC SQL SELECT CAST('book' as varchar(20)) AS type INTO :type FROM book WHERE book.pubid = :pubid;
WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO checkArticles;

If I added the whenever here, would it replace the whenever not found that was written earlier?
Yeah it will replace the previous whenever. Put it before the SELECT though. It's like changing the setting for all further lines of code, as in lines in the file, not lines to be run.

Just a tip to anyone struggling with this. The easiest way to return type is to have it as a field in your SQL query.

You can have string literals in select statements so when you select from a specific publication table, just place the type in the select statement:

SELECT .... CAST('Article' AS varchar(20)) AS type .... FROM article ....
thx

history.subject: Have two questions here
history.content:
First one:

When I use bibauthor, I found there should always be article and book these two types, is this correct?

Second one:

What does this mean "A shell script named compile. Typing “./compile” should suffice to compile all submitted application programs."

Or how to correctly submit my files?

1. There should be articles and books found in the database yes, and then any articles will cause the proceedings/journals that the article appearsin to be printed as well.

2. You need to submit all your source files and then a script that compiles it for the markers. I assume for development you have been using make to compile your programs. That only compiles one program at a time, and the markers don't want to have to figure out how to get make to work for each program you wrote.

The compile script doesn't need to be too fancy. You can just copy all the lines that start with "gcc" or "db2" from the output of make and put it in a file, or you can even pass the name variable to make and just call make once for each program.

This is probably enough for the compile script, assuming everything is in the same directory, just put it in a file called "compile"

make NAME=bibauthor;
make NAME=bibcontent;
make NAME=bibmaint;


You can test it by running chmod u+x compile once, and then ./compile to run the script.

How could we do this if we have multiple rows of the same publication?? I'm confused
Do we count the number of authors in each publication?

They all have to be printed, but not necessarily all in one statement. You can just print the authors one by one, in a loop, all on one line. Something like this:

DECLARE authors CURSOR FOR (...);
// ...
printf("Authors: ");
for(;;) {
  FETCH authors INTO :name; 
  printf("%s", name);
}
printf("\n");

history.subject: Are there any sources for inserting data into a database?
history.content:

Any good sources / references?

INSERT INTO tablename
 (column1, column2)
VALUES
 (value1, value2);

Keep listing out column names, and then put the values you want in the corresponding positions below. See the database populating file for more examples of the syntax of the insert statement.

For the embedding part, it's just as you might expect:

EXEC SQL
  INSERT INTO Author
    (aid, name)
  VALUES
    (:aid, :name);

Any columns you leave out will default to NULL

INSERT INTO tablename
 (column1, column2)
VALUES
 (value1, value2);

Keep listing out column names, and then put the values you want in the corresponding positions below. See the database populating file for more examples of the syntax of the insert statement.

For the embedding part, it's just as you might expect:

EXEC SQL
  INSERT INTO Author
    (aid, name)
  VALUES

Here is my code:

#include <stdio.h>

history.subject: A2Q1 author or empty string?
history.content:
How would you handle this conditional for journals/proceedings?

Would it look something like this?

select 
	if exists( select 1 from ... where wrote.pubid = journal.pubid)
	then author.name
	else ""
from ...

I think the best way to do it would be to use some sort of outer join,, such as LEFT JOIN, and use coalesce to handle the null case:

SELECT coalesce(a.name, '') 
FROM Journal j 
INNER JOIN Publication p ON j.pubid = p.pubid
LEFT JOIN Wrote w ON w.pubid = p.pubid
LEFT JOIN Author a ON a.aid = w.aid

history.subject: multiple rows
history.content:
What kind of C data structure do I use to store the results from

"select * from publication"?

String would not work because there needs to be more than one row

You need to use a cursor for this. See sample3.sqc for how to use a cursor. Something like this:

EXEC SQL DECLARE publications CURSOR FOR SELECT pubid FROM Publication;
EXEC SQL WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO no_more_pubs;
EXEC SQL OPEN publications;
for(;;) {
  FETCH publications INTO :pubid;
}
no_more_pubs:
EXEC SQL CLOSE publications;
EXEC SQL WHENEVER NOT FOUND CONTINUE;

history.subject: Question about queries
history.content:
Why is it that if I try:

select wrote.pubid, author.name, title from author, wrote, publication, article, book where author.name like 'Peter%' and author.aid=wrote.aid and wrote.pubid=publication.pubid and (wrote.pubid=article.pubid or wrote.pubid=book.pubid)

I don't get any results, but if I try:

select wrote.pubid, author.name, title from author, wrote, publication, article where author.name like 'Peter%' and author.aid=wrote.aid and wrote.pubid=publication.pubid and wrote.pubid=article.pubid

I get the result I want.

I know that the result is in fact in the article table and not the book table. Is that the reason why I'm not getting any results for the first query?

I think its because of how selecting from multiple tables works. Apparently it's a CROSS JOIN, which means it will try every combination of rows together:

SELECT * FROM a, b;

TABLE a:
value
-----
1
2

TABLE b:
value
-----
3
4

Result:

a.value | b.value
-----------------
1       | 3
2       | 3
1       | 4
2       | 4

Kind of like a cross product. If there are no values in one table then there are just no values at all.

You'll need to use a different kind of join for this. Probably a LEFT JOIN is the one you want.

history.subject: A2Q1 question
history.content:
select (a or b).year
from a, b, c
where a.id = c.id or b.id = c.id

Is it possible to do something like this in db2? I know c.id can be found in either a.id or b.id (but not both). If it is found in a.id, I want to display a.year. If it is found in b.id, I want to display b.year

SELECT coalesce(a.year, b.year) AS year FROM a, b, c WHERE a.id = c.id OR b.id = c.id

Coalesce will return its first argument which is not null. If both are null then it will return null.

history.subject: label 'dummy_label_name' used but not defined
history.content:
I keep getting this error. How do I define labels?

I am using this label in a whenever statement.

int main() {
  EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR GO TO my_label;
  //...code
my_label: // <-- this defines a label

  // NOTE: a label must be defined within the same function that uses it
  //       so it is a good idea to reset this at the end
  EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR CONTINUE;
}

children.subject: What do you mean by reset?

I just mean that line after,

EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR CONTINUE;

Doing that will reset the "on error" behaviour of the SQL to the default. If you don't do this and you start putting SQL statements in another function then it will fail to compile because the sql statements will try to go to the label in the other function when an error occurs.

What am I doing wrong here?

#include ...

EXEC SQL INCLUDE SQLCA;

EXEC SQL BEGIN DECLARE SECTION;
    char db[6] = "cs348";
    char name[22];
    int aid;
EXEC SQL END DECLARE SECTION; 

void a(){

    EXEC SQL WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO my_label;
    EXEC SQL SELECT DISTINCT aid INTO :aid
	    FROM   author
            WHERE  name = :name;

my_label:
    EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR CONTINUE;   
    return;
     
}

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {        
    // get name command line argument
    strncpy(name,argv[1],22);

	EXEC SQL CONNECT TO :db;

	EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR  GO TO error;
    
	EXEC SQL SELECT DISTINCT aid INTO :aid
	    FROM   author
            WHERE  name = :name;

	a();
error:
    check_error("My error",&sqlca);
    EXEC SQL WHENEVER SQLERROR CONTINUE;

    EXEC SQL ROLLBACK;
    EXEC SQL CONNECT reset;
    exit(1);
}

 Still getting: error: label 'my_label' used but not defined
I am getting this exact same error as well
In function a you have set the WHENEVER NOT FOUND GO TO, but only unset WHENEVER SQLERROR. Should use WHENEVER NOT FOUND CONTINUE after my_label

Yup, can confirm that putting EXEC SQL WHENEVER NOT FOUND CONTINUE; under the label works. 

http://uw.cs.cs348.narkive.com/kwA64ZSX/label-end-used-but-not-defined

see the reply to the question on that link

history.subject: A2 Schema
history.content:
I am quite confused with regards to the schema presented in A2.

Please correct (or add on to) whatever I say:

My current thoughts are:

1) If a pubid occurs in proceedings/journal/book/article, then it also must occur in publication (since there is an arrow from pubid in  proceedings/journal/book/article to pubid in publication)

2) The appearsin attribute in article refers to those articles which appear in proceedings/journals as well. Thus logically, an article can appear in another publication which is a proceeding or a journal.

3) Due to |Pu|=(|B|+|J|+|Pr|+|A|), a single item cannot be a say, book and journal at the same time

4) Because pubids in WROTE will always refer to books/articles, only books/articles can have an attribute in author

5) I guess what I really don't understand is how the table Article fits into all of this. Like what's the point of the appearsin attribute? and if the article "appears" in some publication (say p), does p also have an author? 


Any help will be appreciated. Thanks a lot!

history.subject: A2 Schema
history.content:
I am quite confused with regard to the schema presented in A2.

Please correct (or add on to) whatever I say:

My current thoughts are:

1) If a pubid occurs in proceedings/journal/book/article, then it also must occur in publication (since there is an arrow from pubid in  proceedings/journal/book/article to pubid in publication)

2) The appearsin attribute in article refers to those articles which appear in proceedings/journals as well. Thus logically, an article can appear in another publication which is a proceeding or a journal.

3) Due to |Pu|=(|B|+|J|+|Pr|+|A|), a single item cannot be a say, book and journal at the same time

4) Because pubids in WROTE will always refer to books/articles, only books/articles can have an attribute in author

5) I guess what I really don't understand is how the table Article fits into all of this. Like what's the point of the appearsin attribute? and if the article "appears" in some publication (say p), does p also have an author? 


Any help will be appreciated. Thanks a lot!

For 1-4, all you say is correct. For 5, its basically because proceedings and journals are collections of articles, but the articles themselves are individual publications. The appearsin is just to tell you which publication it appears in so that for Bibauthor you can print that publication out too.

The proceedings/journals do not have authors, so when doing that "minor sort on first author name" you just put it first automatically ("publications with no author sort by empty string" is referring to this case)

history.subject: Domain-Independence
history.content: Can someone explain what $$ \Theta $$ represents in this definition? I'm not sure I understand what this means, especially the relationship between $$ DB_1 $$ and $$DB_2$$.

At long last maybe I am able to explain this... here goes:

So $$ \varphi $$ is our expression in the relational calculus, which uses the free variables $$ x_1, \ldots, x_k $$. We want to find all the tuples in our database that satisfy this relational calculus expression.

$$ \theta $$ is the valuation. A valuations is just the way we set the variables $$ x_1, \ldots, x_k $$ to their possible values, which lie in the domain of the database: D.

For SQL, you can think of the domain as "all the INTs, all the CHAR(1)s, all the CHAR(2)s, all the CHAR(3)s, etc." That is, all the values you could possibly stick into a database.

As for "what does $$ \theta $$ represent", the best I can come up with is "the actual data that's currently in the database." This interpretation of it will work here and in most cases. Formally, that's not what it is, but whatever.

Just remember not to write that as the definition on the exams, and use the one from the slides instead ("valuation" and all that).

Now for the other question: we have DB1 and DB2, which are our databases. They are basically the same database, the only difference being the domain. The relations (tables, R1, ..., Rk) are the same for both. So are the constraints. Everything is the same except the domain.

Next, to make sense of the definition of "Domain Independent Query", don't think about SQL because the domain is always the same (everything) and way too big to think about (it is everything). We have to think super tiny. Here's the domain's we'll be working with:

$$ D_1 = \{ 1 \} \\ D_2 = \{ 1, 2 \} $$

Notice that the domains are different, and in particular, D2 is a superset of D1. This means that so long as the data is valid in DB1, then it is also valid in DB2, even though they aren't the same database. This means they can share a $$ \theta $$.

Let's fill them with data. To make things easy, let's say that each database has one table called T (remember both databases must have the same tables), and T just has one column N, which holds a number. Here's a picture:

DB1            DB2

T              T
N              N
---            ---
1              1

So what are we supposed to be noticing here? Both databases, with their one table with one column, have one row, which holds the number 1. Both databases hold the same data ($$ \theta $$), and look exactly the same, but they are still "different databases" because the domains are different (we could but a 2 into DB2, but not into DB1).

Now let's make a query: $$ \{ \langle n \rangle | n = n \} $$. Does this query make you scared? Because it is unsafe? Yes that is the point. This query is unsafe because it doesn't care about what's in the database. Instead it cares about the domain of the database.

Let's see what happens when we query our databases. I'd write some SQL for this but it's literally impossible. They designed SQL so that we can't make unsafe queries, so we're going theoretical:

DB1          DB2

n            n
---          ---
1            1
             2

We got a different answer for each database! What does this mean? The query was domain dependent. Domain dependent is bad. Domain dependent is unsafe. Nobody likes domain dependent. Forget it even exists.

So what does domain independent look like? Basically all the queries any of us have ever written. No matter what the query is, even though DB1 and DB2 are "different databases" with different domains, if the query is domain independent the result will be the same. So long as the databases hold the same data anyway.

$$ \{ \langle n \rangle | \text{T}\langle n \rangle \} \equiv $$ SELECT * FROM T

Normal query, normal answer:

DB1          DB2

n            n
---          ---
1            1

Same in both databases. It didn't matter what the domain was, it would always be the same. This is domain independence. Domain independence is good. If your query is domain independent, it is safe.

================================================================================================

Sources:

https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~david/cs348/lect-RELATIONAL-handout.pdf

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuple_relational_calculus

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_model

children.subject:
I made a huge table too, but how can I combine year column together.

ie. I want to combine journal.year, book.year, proceedings.year and if no year is available, left as null.
SELECT NULL AS year FROM <table>

No that is wrong. What you want is the coalesce function

SELECT coalesce(j.year, b.year, p.year) AS year FROM Journal j -- ...

It will return its first parameter that is not NULL.

That is just to set year as NULL when year is not available. After that can do: 

SELECT pubid, ..., NULL AS year FROM <table>
UNION
SELECT pubid, ..., year FROM <other-table-with-year>

Just make sure the column names for each table have same names and order.

history.subject: What's the input for bibmaint?
history.content:
I read through the instructions but I'm still confused by it.. What's "standard input"? Is it similar to part 1 where it's just 

./bibauthor "bob%"

or is it something else? A text file?

Standard input is STDIN.

For C++ that means use getline:

#include <string>
//...

string line;
while(getline(cin, line)) {
  // use line
}

And for C that means use getline:

#include <stdio.h>

char * line = NULL;
size_t line_len = 0;
while(getline(&line, &line_len, stdin) != -1) {
  // use line
}

Then you'll see when you run your program it just sits there doing nothing. It's waiting for you to start typing lines. Every time you hit enter, getline will go and your loop will start. When you're done writing lines press Ctrl-D to end.

int line_len = 0;
while(getline(&line, &line_len, stdin) != -1) {
  // use line
}

Then you'll see when you run your program it just sits there doing nothing. It's waiting for you to start typing lines. Every time you hit enter, getline will go and your loop will start. When you're done writing lines press Ctrl-D to end.

The newline shouldn't matter if you are using strtok to process it as was suggested. If you really must remove the newline, just set the last character to a 0:

char* line = NULL;
size_t line_len = 0;
getline(&line, &line_len, stdin);
line[line_len - 1] = 0;

history.subject: How to handle NULL when fetching?
history.content:
I have code like this

EXEC SQL FETCH saved_cursor INTO :pubid, :year

if year is blank (for example for articles), it'll be a NULL. when the C program tries to execute that it returns 

ERROR occurred : My error.
SQLCODE : 4294966991
SQL0305N  The NULL value cannot be assigned to a host variable because no
indicator variable is specified.  SQLSTATE=22002

Anyone know how to support NULL values?

Indicator variables, my dude.

In your declarations, include:

short year_ind;

Then change your SQL to:

EXEC SQL FETCH saved_cursor INTO :pubid, :year INDICATOR :year_ind;

Now, if `year` is NULL, `year_ind` will be non-zero.

e.g.

if(!year_ind) printf("%d", year);

history.subject: How to use C++ with embedded SQL for A2
history.content:
Hey all,

I figure some people will want to use C++ instead of C for this assignment.

All you have to do is:

  1. Change your .sqc file to .sqx
  2. In the Makefile:
    1. change CC=gcc to CC=g++
    2. Find+replace "sqc" with "sqx" (there should be 2 occurrences)
  3. In "util.h", delete anything inside "ifdef _cplusplus" (there's an extern "C" {, and another at the end with a })
  4. Run "make", and it should work!

edit: See @89, Dave beat me to it

  4. Run "make", and it should work!

Basically, this is a linker error. Somehow, you're not compiling util.C, and thus cannot link it. Just add util.C to your list of files you want to compile and you're good to go.

$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c $(NAME).C util.C

history.subject: How do you guys work efficiently with this db2?
history.content:
I downloaded a copy of mysql and mysql workbench just to make stuff like editing queries and visualizing tables easier. However sometimes the query written in mysql is not fully compatible with db2.

Just wondering - how do you guys do it?
I've been using a Vagrant box (ubuntu/xenial64) with a regular install of db2. It's also what I use for CS 343, since I don't have an Ubuntu machine otherwise.

children.subject:
@JackZhou

Is there a tutorial I can follow where I can do the same on my local machine?

The process is something like: 1. Install vagrant. 2. Make a directory for the configuration file, then from there, vagrant init ubuntu/xenial64. This will drop a Vagrantfile in the directory. Feel free to configure it as you'd like, e.g. change memory/CPU allotments, add shared directories, etc. 3. vagrant up from the config directory. 4. vagrant ssh from the config directory. You'll be dropped into a terminal from there, just like a regular environment. Here, install DB2: 5. Not sure it's 100% needed, but run sudo apt install build-essential to be on the safe side. 6. Get a copy of DB2 from here: https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/downloads/im/db2express/. The easiest way is probably to set up a shared directory and download it from your host OS, but you can also just curl the file. 7. tar -xvf that_file.tar.gz 8. cd into the extracted directory and try to ./db2install. It'll probably complain about missing dependencies. I don't remember what all of them were, but you can find them on Google if needed. I believe the PAM dependency can be ignored. It'll allow you to install it regardless. 9. source $HOME/sqllib/db2profile (add it to your shell profile to not have to do it every time). That's all for that. Make sure to create database cs348 after running db2. If you are also in CS 343, you can git clone the uCPP directory and build it from the source directory. There may be oddities with g++ since the stock version on Xenial may not be the right one, so you might need to install gcc-6 (from the PPA here https://launchpad.net/~ubuntu-toolchain-r/+archive/ubuntu/test?field.series_filter=xenial) and change the executable from g++ back to g++-6. Let me know if something is not working or wrong. Good luck! EDIT: Ah, also, vagrant halt shuts the machine down when you're done, and you might want to consider using something like tmux/screen so that you can restore your session if you want to close the terminal. I've found it doesn't have a huge hit on my battery life (maybe 10-20% worse), so I can keep it around without shutting it down, but YMMV here.
