history.subject: Relational Calculus
history.content:
Are we allowed to use for all or there does not exist in relational calculus?
They aren't safe according to the slides.

You can use not exists or for all, so long as your resulting query is safe. It's unsafe when things that aren't in your database could show up in the answer for your relational calculus. Using the example from the slides

$$\{ \langle x, y\rangle | x = y \}$$

This is unsafe because you could get any result back. Doesn't matter if it's in the database or not, a value can still equal another value.

$$\{ \langle y \rangle | \neg \exists x.\text{author}\langle x, y \rangle \}$$

This is unsafe because there are again an infinite number of results. Doesn't matter if it's in the database or not, just that it is not paired with an x in the database. Anything not in the database is not paired with an x.

It's probably harder to come up with a usage of not-exists that is unsafe, especially when basing your relational calculus on the SQL statements from part 1, so don't worry too much of it. I added a not exists example to @28

You can use not exists, so long as your resulting query is safe. It's unsafe when things that aren't in your database could show up in the answer for your relational calculus. Using the example from the slides

$$\{ \langle x, y\rangle | x = y \}$$

This is unsafe because you could get any result back. Doesn't matter if it's in the database or not, a value can still equal another value.

$$\{ \langle y \rangle | \neg \exists x.\text{author}\langle x, y \rangle \}$$

This is unsafe because there are again an infinite number of results. Doesn't matter if it's in the database or not, just that it is not paired with an x in the database. Anything not in the database is not paired with an x.

history.subject: A1Q4: Writing "like" in RC

history.subject: Error when using "with"
history.content:
When I use 'with' to define a temporary table, an error is raised:

|SQL0104N An unexpected token ")" was found following "...".
Expected tokens may include: ")". SQLSTATE=42601

SQL0204N "{userid}.T" is an undefined name. SQLSTATE=42704

Does anyone know how to resolve this?
Can you give a simple example of what you're doing (i.e. without the actual selects and whatnot)? It's probably a syntactical problem.
Can you give a simple example of what you're doing (i.e. without the actual selects and whatnot). It's probably a syntactical problem.

children.subject: I am just trying to define a temporary table T using "with" so that the final query is easier to express. When I compile using the option -tf no errors occur. But when I add "\" to every line except the last one and removing the semi-colon on the last line, the error above occurs.

Maybe you've done the slashes wrong. Probably best to make sure the slash is separated from any other letters by a space, and does not have a space after it. Even lines which only contain a ) still need a slash. Since it works with -tf then you know it's just something about how you're breaking it up...

WITH T AS ( \
  SELECT * FROM Class \
) \
SELECT * FROM Mark, Class
I figured it out... the issue is you can't have a newline between the end of the with clause and the select clause. Thanks everyone.

history.subject: Test with -tf
history.content: If you're testing your script as you are editing it and you are running it with db2 -f file.sql, you can use db2 -tf file.sql which allows you to semicolon-delimit commands instead and not need line-continuation slashes. Possibly a little easier to test and debug, just make sure to add them back after (and remove the semicolons).

history.subject: a1q2 - I don't know how to begin this
history.content:
I am having trouble figuring out where exactly I should get the information about whether a professor has taught a course before. 

Any help would be great.

Thank you

If a Mark exists for an Enrollment, it means that the Class that the Enrollment was for has been completed. The Professor who taught that Class then has taught a course in the past if there is a mark recorded for an enrollment in their class.

children.subject:
See, I'm still a bit confused, because from what I understand you're saying: A class has been done the first time if its the Marks for it don't exist. 

But here, marks CAN exist for CS245 even before the professor started teaching it, and those marks don't keep track of the professor who taught it.

Well a Professor (from the professor table) teaches a Class (from the class table).

A Class has Enrollments (in the Enrollment table) which may have Marks (in the mark table).

Courses (in the course table) are a different thing. Classes are about Courses, and a Professor teaches a Class.

Marks may exist for a Course (maybe for a previous term's offering of CS245), but the will not exist for the exact Class (CS245, F2017, 5) that a Professor is teaching if the term has not yet ended.

A Mark does, in a way, have a Professor who taught it, just this information is stored in the Class table, rather than the Mark table. You can get this together using a join:

Class c INNER JOIN Mark m ON c.cnum = m.cnum AND c.term = m.term AND c.section = m.section

Maybe take some time to study that diagram in the PDF file, and figure out what all the lines and connections on it mean.

children.subject:
Can someone quickly summarize what primary keys, foreign keys and references are?

I don't think I understand them quite well..

Primary keys - uniquely identify an entry.  Sometimes needs more than 1 data point to make it unique.  e.g. it takes a student number, class number, term, and section to uniquely identify a mark.

Foreign key - keys that has meaning in one or more other tables. e.g. a class has a professor id which is also used in the professor table.

Primary keys are used to uniquely identify each row of a table. In the case of a student, it's just snum. For a class, its the combination of (cnum, term, section)

A foreign key is when you store the primary key of some table (table A) in a different table (table B) in this case, it is said that table B references table A.

For our student table example, the Enrollment table references Student AND Class. We cannot enroll a non-existent student in a class, nor can we enroll a student in a non-existent class.

history.subject: Fastest way to learn relational calculus?
history.content: I'm not in CS, so this is completely new to me. How would I go about learning this? From the posts here it seems like only question 1, 2, 3, 4/9 can be done with RC..

Have you taken MATH135? Uses a lot of symbols they taught there.

Basically goes like this:

You have some tables with some columns. For the examples, this is what I'll use

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

Then relational calculus and their respective SQL queries are like this:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, 1, \_ \rangle \}$$

Explanation:

  1. On the left of the |, we have the values we want to output. These values correspond to variables used on the right side of the |
  2. On the right side of the |, it says Books. This means we are asking something about the books table.
  3. In the brackets by books we have 3 kinds of values.
    1. The underscore for I don't care about this column (the ID/pub_year)
    2. The N for I don't care about the value of this column, but we'll call that value N (the name)
    3. The 1 for this column has to be 1 (the author)
  4. When evaluated, we then get a set of all book names where the author is 1

Result:

Name
--------------
Harry Potter 1
Harry Potter 2

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Authors WHERE birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists a.(\text{Authors}\langle \_, N, \_, a\rangle \wedge a > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Now there is the added "exists" thing, which has a variable a, and a query in parentheses. Read this as "There exists a value a such that (query)"
  2. With this variable "a" introduced, we find all authors whose birth_year is a
  3. To restrict a, we then require that at the same time, a > 1950, using the and symbol

Result:

name
----------
JK Rowling
Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT book_id, b.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors ON author = author_id WHERE is_dead = True

$$\{ \langle I, N\rangle | \exists a.(\text{Books}\langle I, N, a, \_ \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, \_, True, \_\rangle)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. The exists query can be arbitrarily complex, and the requirements you impose on variables does not have to be based on a number
    1. This time, we require that at the same time as "the book has author a", that "the author a is dead"
  2. A join is represented by writing the same variable in BOTH tables

Result:

book_id | name 
---------------- 
5       | Hamlet

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON author = author_id WHERE b.pub_year > 2000 AND a.birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N_B, N_A \rangle | \exists a, p, b.( \text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, a, p \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, N_A, \_, b \rangle \wedge p > 2000 \wedge b > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we have lots of restrictions, so we introduce lots of variables with that exists guy
  2. As before:
    1. Where we join tables, we show the same variable in each table
    2. Where we have simple restrictions, we just write those restrictions

Result:

b.name  | a.name
----------------
Eragon  | Chris
Eldest  | Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name, pub_year FROM Books a WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books b WHERE a.pub_year > b.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N, P \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, \_, P \rangle \wedge \neg \exists x.(\text{Books}\langle \_, \_, \_, x\rangle \wedge P > x) \}$$

Explanation:

  1. To say that in RC, just translate the not exists into... not exists!
    1. There have been some concerns that not exists is "unsafe", but that's not the case. It's just you have to be careful not to include things that... don't exist. @67 for explanation

Result

name   | pub_year
-----------------
Hamlet | 1603

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT max(birth_year) FROM Author

$$\{ \langle B \rangle | \text{Author} \langle \_, \_, \_, B \rangle \wedge \neg \exists x.(\text{Author}\langle \_, \_, \_, x\rangle \wedge x > B)\} $$

Explanation:

  1. There is no aggregation in RC, but sometimes you can represent aggregation in another way.
  2. For MAX, you could also think of it as "the value for which there are no larger values"
  3. Just translate that into RC. Using "Not exists" helps for things like this. For all would work as well, but this is left as an exercise to the reader...

Have you taken MATH135? Uses a lot of symbols they taught there.

Basically goes like this:

You have some tables with some columns. For the examples, this is what I'll use

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

Then relational calculus and their respective SQL queries are like this:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, 1, \_ \rangle \}$$

Explanation:

  1. On the left of the |, we have the values we want to output. These values correspond to variables used on the right side of the |
  2. On the right side of the |, it says Books. This means we are asking something about the books table.
  3. In the brackets by books we have 3 kinds of values.
    1. The underscore for I don't care about this column (the ID/pub_year)
    2. The N for I don't care about the value of this column, but we'll call that value N (the name)
    3. The 1 for this column has to be 1 (the author)
  4. When evaluated, we then get a set of all book names where the author is 1

Result:

Name
--------------
Harry Potter 1
Harry Potter 2

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Authors WHERE birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists a.(\text{Authors}\langle \_, N, \_, a\rangle \wedge a > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Now there is the added "exists" thing, which has a variable a, and a query in parentheses. Read this as "There exists a value a such that (query)"
  2. With this variable "a" introduced, we find all authors whose birth_year is a
  3. To restrict a, we then require that at the same time, a > 1950, using the and symbol

Result:

name
----------
JK Rowling
Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT book_id, b.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors ON author = author_id WHERE is_dead = True

$$\{ \langle I, N\rangle | \exists a.(\text{Books}\langle I, N, a, \_ \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, \_, True, \_\rangle)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. The exists query can be arbitrarily complex, and the requirements you impose on variables does not have to be based on a number
    1. This time, we require that at the same time as "the book has author a", that "the author a is dead"
  2. A join is represented by writing the same variable in BOTH tables

Result:

book_id | name 
---------------- 
5       | Hamlet

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON author = author_id WHERE b.pub_year > 2000 AND a.birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N_B, N_A \rangle | \exists a, p, b.( \text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, a, p \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, N_A, \_, b \rangle \wedge p > 2000 \wedge b > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we have lots of restrictions, so we introduce lots of variables with that exists guy
  2. As before:
    1. Where we join tables, we show the same variable in each table
    2. Where we have simple restrictions, we just write those restrictions

Result:

b.name  | a.name
----------------
Eragon  | Chris
Eldest  | Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name, pub_year FROM Books a WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books b WHERE a.pub_year > b.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N, P \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, \_, P \rangle \wedge \neg \exists x.(\text{Books}\langle \_, \_, \_, x\rangle \wedge P > x) \}$$

Explanation:

  1. To say that in RC, just translate the not exists into... not exists!
    1. There have been some concerns that not exists is "unsafe", but that's not the case. It's just you have to be careful not to include things that... don't exist. @67 for explanation

Result

name   | pub_year
-----------------
Hamlet | 1603

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT max(birth_year) FROM Author

$$\{ \langle B \rangle | \text{Author} \langle \_, \_, \_, B \rangle \wedge \neg \exists x.(\text{Author}\langle \_, \_, \_, x\rangle \wedge x > B)\} $$

Explanation:

  1. There is no aggregation in RC, but sometimes you can represent aggregation in another way.
  2. For MAX, you could also think of it as "the value for which there are no larger values"
  3. Just translate that into RC. Using "Not exists" helps for things like this.
  4. Looks the same as the previous one? That's because it is basically the same thing. Aggregation is usually just SQL syntax sugar.

Result:

birth_year
----------
1983

SELECT name, pub_year FROM Books ORDER BY pub_year ASC LIMIT 1

=

SELECT name, pub_year FROM Books a WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Books b WHERE a.pub_year > b.pub_year)

$$\{ \langle N, P \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, \_, P \rangle \wedge \neg \exists x.(\text{Books}\langle \_, \_, \_, x\rangle \wedge P > x) \}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we want to get the oldest book from the books table. There's no aggregation or sorting in RC, but we can represent some of those features in other ways.
  2. The MIN can be thought of as "The value for which there are no smaller values"
    1. Ok I know there's no MIN used in this query, and I have no idea how to write this exact query by aggregation, but it's kind of similar.
  3. To say that in RC, just translate the not exists into... not exists!
    1. There have been some concerns that not exists is "unsafe", but that's not the case. It's just you have to be careful not to include things that don't exist.

Result

name   | pub_year
-----------------
Hamlet | 1603

Basically goes like this:

You have some tables with some columns. For the examples, this is what I'll use

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

Then relational calculus and their respective SQL queries are like this:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, 1, \_ \rangle \}$$

Explanation:

  1. On the left of the |, we have the values we want to output. These values correspond to variables used on the right side of the |
  2. On the right side of the |, it says Books. This means we are asking something about the books table.
  3. In the brackets by books we have 3 kinds of values.
    1. The underscore for I don't care about this column (the ID/pub_year)
    2. The N for I don't care about the value of this column, but we'll call that value N (the name)
    3. The 1 for this column has to be 1 (the author)
  4. When evaluated, we then get a set of all book names where the author is 1

Result:

Name
--------------
Harry Potter 1
Harry Potter 2

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Authors WHERE birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists a.(\text{Authors}\langle \_, N, \_, a\rangle \wedge a > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Now there is the added "exists" thing, which has a variable a, and a query in parentheses. Read this as "There exists a value a such that (query)"
  2. With this variable "a" introduced, we find all authors whose birth_year is a
  3. To restrict a, we then require that at the same time, a > 1950, using the and symbol

Result:

name
----------
JK Rowling
Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT book_id, b.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors ON author = author_id WHERE is_dead = True

$$\{ \langle I, N\rangle | \exists a.(\text{Books}\langle I, N, a, \_ \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, \_, True, \_\rangle)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. The exists query can be arbitrarily complex, and the requirements you impose on variables does not have to be based on a number
    1. This time, we require that at the same time as "the book has author a", that "the author a is dead"
  2. A join is represented by writing the same variable in BOTH tables

Result:

book_id | name 
---------------- 
5       | Hamlet

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON author = author_id WHERE b.pub_year > 2000 AND a.birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N_B, N_A \rangle | \exists a, p, b.( \text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, a, p \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, N_A, \_, b \rangle \wedge p > 2000 \wedge b > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we have lots of restrictions, so we introduce lots of variables with that exists guy
  2. As before:
    1. Where we join tables, we show the same variable in each table
    2. Where we have simple restrictions, we just write those restrictions

Result:

b.name  | a.name
----------------
Eragon  | Chris
Eldest  | Chris

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  1. Here we want to get the oldest book from the books table. There's no aggregation in RC, but we can represent some of the aggregation functions in other ways.
  2. The MIN can be thought of as "The value for which there are no smaller values"
  3. To say that in RC, just translate the not exists into... not exists!
    1. There have been some concerns that not exists is "unsafe", but that's not the case. It's just you have to be careful not to include things that don't exist.

Result

name   | pub_year
-----------------
Hamlet | 1603

$$\{ \langle N_B, N_A \rangle | \exists a, p, b.( \text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, a, p \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, N_A \_, b \rangle \wedge p > 2000 \wedge b > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we have lots of restrictions, so we introduce lots of variables with that exists guy
  2. As before:
    1. Where we join tables, we show the same variable in each table
    2. Where we have simple restrictions, we just write those restrictions

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I think this was enough to cover what we had to do for A1Q2. Will add more when there is more to be added.

Have you taken MATH135? Uses a lot of symbols they taught there.

Basically goes like this:

You have some tables with some columns, say like this:

Books
book_id | name           | author   | pub_year
----------------------------------------------
1       | Harry Potter 1 | 1        | 1997
2       | Harry Potter 2 | 1        | 1998
3       | Eragon         | 2        | 2002
4       | Eldest         | 2        | 2005
5       | Hamlet         | 3        | 1603

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | birth_year
---------------------------------|-----------
1         | JK Rowling | False   | 1965
2         | Chris      | False   | 1983
3         | Shakespeare| True    | 1564

Then relational calculus and their respective SQL queries are like this:

SELECT name FROM Books WHERE author = 1

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \text{Books}\langle \_, N, 1, \_ \rangle \}$$

Explanation:

  1. On the left of the |, we have the values we want to output. These values correspond to variables used on the right side of the |
  2. On the right side of the |, it says Books. This means we are asking something about the books table.
  3. In the brackets by books we have 3 kinds of values.
    1. The underscore for I don't care about this column (the ID/pub_year)
    2. The N for I don't care about the value of this column, but we'll call that value N (the name)
    3. The 1 for this column has to be 1 (the author)
  4. When evaluated, we then get a set of all book names where the author is 1

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT name FROM Authors WHERE birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists a.(\text{Authors}\langle \_, N, \_, a\rangle \wedge a > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Now there is the added "exists" thing, which has a variable a, and a query in parentheses. Read this as "There exists a value a such that (query)"
  2. With this variable "a" introduced, we find all authors whose birth_year is a
  3. To restrict a, we then require that at the same time, a > 1950, using the and symbol

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT book_id, b.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors ON author = author_id WHERE is_dead = True

$$\{ \langle I, N\rangle | \exists a.(\text{Books}\langle I, N, a, \_ \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, \_, True, \_\rangle)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. The exists query can be arbitrarily complex, and the requirements you impose on variables does not have to be based on a number
    1. This time, we require that at the same time as "the book has author a", that "the author a is dead"
  2. A join is represented by writing the same variable in BOTH tables
  3. The restrictions simply list the restriction

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Books b INNER JOIN Authors a ON author = author_id WHERE b.pub_year > 2000 AND a.birth_year > 1950

$$\{ \langle N_B, N_A \rangle | \exists a, p, b.( \text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, a, p \rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle a, N_A \_, b \rangle \wedge p > 2000 \wedge b > 1950)\}$$

Explanation:

  1. Here we have lots of restrictions, so we introduce lots of variables with that exists guy
  2. As before:
    1. Where we join tables, we show the same variable in each table
    2. Where we have simple restrictions, we just write those restrictions

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

children.subject:
How would I express "and"? For example:

SELECT name FROM Authors WHERE age < 100 and birthyear > 1990

Would it be

{⟨N⟩|∃a,b.(Authors⟨_,N,_,a⟩∧a<100, Authors⟨_,N,_,b⟩∧b>1990)}

With Authors defined as

Authors
author_id | name       | is_dead | age | birthyear
--------------------------------------------------

I'd write something like this:

$$\{ \langle N \rangle | \exists a, b (\text{Authors}\langle \_, N, \_, a, b\rangle \wedge a < 100 \wedge b > 1990) \}$$

Thank you! What if it's from 2 tables, something like:

SELECT name FROM Authors, Books WHERE age < 100 and Books.author = Authors.author_id

Would it be 

{⟨N⟩|∃a,b(Authors⟨id,N,_,a,b⟩∧a<100∧Books(_,_,books_author)∧id=books_author)}

In that case, just introduce a variable for the author_id with the existence, and require that both the book and author have the same author_id using that. The query you listed there can't actually be executed, but here's another:

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Authors a, Books b WHERE b.author = a.author_id AND age < 100

which I guess is equivalent to

SELECT b.name, a.name FROM Authors a INNER JOIN Books b ON b.author = a.author_id WHERE age < 100

$$\{ \langle N_A, N_B \rangle | \exists a, c (\text{Books}\langle \_, N_B, c\rangle \wedge \text{Authors}\langle c, N_A, \_, a, \_\rangle \wedge a < 100) \}$$
Thanks man. Got it now :)
How would you write down the notation for a query involving if there exists such a result?

The whole relational calculus is just selecting things where results exist, so this is pretty invisible. You just have to write something that gets the meaning across.

SELECT name FROM Book b WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM Author a WHERE b.pub_year < a.birth_year)

$$ \{ \langle N \rangle | \exists b, p. (\text{Book}\langle \_, N, \_, p\rangle \wedge \text{Author}\langle \_, \_, \_, b\rangle \wedge p < b) \} $$
Thank you!
Bless your kind soul

history.subject: question about !=
history.content:
Hi all

Assume I have two table called A and B.

Both of them have only one column called number.

A: number {1,2,3,4,5}

B: number {4,5}

If I run a query

select a.number
from A a, B b
where a.number != b.number

Then the output is 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

If I run another query

select number
from A
where number not in B

Then the output is 1, 2, 3

Can anyone explain why the first query gives 1, 2, 3, 4, 5?

Because putting A a, B b as the table you are selecting from performs a cross join, which looks something like this:

A.number B.number
1        4
2        4
3        4
4        4
5        4
1        5
2        5
3        5
4        5
5        5

The where clause then works on rows of this final table one at a time, and since there are pairs where a.number != b.number even for 4 and 5, they are included in the output

Because putting A a, B b as the table you are selecting from performs a cross join, which looks something like this:

1   4
2   4
3   4
4   4
5   4
1   5
2   5
3   5
4   5
5   5

so there are pairs where a.number != b.number even for 4 and 5, so they outputted.

children.subject: So how can I get 4 and 5 if I want to use !=?

If I'm interpreting your question right I'm not sure you can really... could be done using NOT EXISTS, but this is really just expanding your NOT IN solution to its full form.

SELECT a.number
FROM A
WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM B WHERE a.number = b.number)
I got it. Thank you very much!

history.subject: Please help I'm so lost
history.content:
Alright so, I haven't started this assignment, and I am pretty confused about this whole class in general, I just need some help right now. 

How do I use this IBM DB2  thing to test if my queries are outputting the right thing?

So far, I took the contents of https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~david/cs348/StudentCourseSchema.txt and put it into a file called class.file and then did:

%db2 -f class.file

into my command line

now, this is where I am lost. How do I use this to write my assignment queries to check if the right answer is being outputted? Thanks!

db2 to go into a db2 shell

Do "list tables" to make sure it's working.

You can do SQL queries from the db2 shell to test things out.

To run a query from a file (e.g. a1.sql), do db2 -f a1.sql.

To run a query from command line do db2 "select * from ..."

Don't forget to db2 connect to cs348 before you try to do anything

"db2" to go into a db2 shell

Do "list tables" to make sure it's working.

You can do SQL queries from the db2 shell to test things out.

To run a query from a file (e.g. q1.sql), do "db2 -f q1.sql".

history.subject: A1 Query 4

history.subject: A1 Query 5
history.content:
How do you compare times in SQL? I tried using TIME and TIMESTAMP to convert the string to a time object and compared using '<' and '>' but I get an error which says that the two things being compared are not numeric. Can I get some suggestions on how to go about comparing times? 

Thanks!

no

EDIT: Not helpful. 

EDIT: I made the assumption of a 24 hr time and compared in lex order.

Real answer: Use TIME(time1) < TIME(time2) and it will cast to times and allow proper comparison, i.e. TIME(time) < TIME('12:00') for before noon.

no

EDIT: Not helpful. 

EDIT: I made the assumption of a 24 hr time and compared in lex order.

Real answer: Use `TIME(time1) < TIME(time2)` and it will cast to times and allow proper comparison, i.e. `TIME(time) < TIME('12:00')` for before noon.

EDIT: I made the assumption of a 24 hr time and compared in lex order.

history.subject: A1 Query 7 clarify
history.content:
I don't quit understand the requirements for query 7.

For each pair of professors who have taught the same course in the same term, their average enrollment counts and average final grades in the course for that term. For each of the two professors, the result should include the number of the professor, the course number, the term, and the required two statistics.

Let's say professor A,B,C teaches CS348 in Fall 2016, and professor A has enrollment 50, average grade 80;  B has enrollment 40, average grade 90; C has enrollment 30, average 70.

If we call this query, what does the output look like? (and what does average enrollment mean?)

Does it look like this:

Professor        CourseNumber     Term        AverageEnrollment?       AverageGrade
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A                CS348            F2016        ?                       80
B                CS348            F2016        ?                       90
C                CS348            F2016        ?                       70

Result columns are pnum1, pnum2, cnum, term, avgenrol1, avggrade1, avgenrol2, avggrade2.

If you list (pnum1, pnum2), don't also list (pnum2, pnum1).

Average enrollment is the average of the number of students enrolled in the class over all sections taught by that prof in that term.

This is based on my email to Prof Weddell.

Result columns are pnum1, pnum2, cnum, term, avgenrol1, avggrade1, avgenrol2, avggrade2.

If you list (pnum1, pnum2), don't also list (pnum2, pnum1).

Average enrollment is the average of the number of students enrolled in the class over all sections taught by that prof in that term.

This is based on my email to Prof Weddell.

children.subject: What's the average enrolment? Is it the average enrollment for a professor's different sections?
Average enrollment is the average of the number of students enrolled in the class over all sections taught by that prof in that term.
how to list (pnum1, pnum2) only? I keep getting both (pnum1, pnum2) and (pnum2, pnum1)
Could do a `WHERE pnum1 < pnum2`
If we have three profs teaching the same course in a term (as in the example in the original question), should we list (A,B), (A,C) and (B,C) assuming profA.pnum < profB.pnum < profC.pnum?
I believe so. The question does ask "For each pair of professors..." and those are indeed more pairs of professors
are these supposed to be unique, i.e. is (A A) a valid pair?
A, A is not valid

So, let's treat this as any other piazza group and make the most out of it. 

Cheers!

history.subject: Welcome to Piazza!
history.content:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!
